In FireFox, select FILE then SAVE FILE AS from your browser's toolbar above. In Chrome, select right click (with your mouse) on this page and select SAVE AS


Record: 1
Title:
‘A single societal community with full citizenship for all’: Talcott Parsons, citizenship and modern society.
Authors:
Sciortino, Giuseppe, Universita di Trento, Trento, Italy, giuseppe.sciortino@unitn.it
Address:
Sciortino, Giuseppe, Dipartimento di Sociologia e Ricerca Sociale, Universita di Trento, Via Verdi 26, 38122, Trento, Italy, giuseppe.sciortino@unitn.it
Source:
Journal of Classical Sociology, Vol 10(3), Aug, 2010. pp. 239-258.
Page Count:
20
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
1468-795X (Print)
1741-2897 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
societal community, citizenship, Talcott Parsons, modern society
Abstract:
The main claim of this paper is to show that any canon of citizenship studies should include Talcott Parsons. Contrary to the received views, Talcott Parsons provides an innovative view of citizenship as a key sociological structure, rooted in his theory of modern society. In doing so, he anticipates contemporary debates on the topic by highlighting the relationship between citizenship and cultural pluralism in modern Western societies. The paper provides both an interpretative account of Parsons’ analysis of citizenship and an assessment of its contemporary relevance. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Citizenship; *Communities; *Modernization; *Society
PsycINFO Classification:
Social Processes & Social Issues (2900)
Population:
Human
Male
Age Group:
Adulthood (18 yrs & older)

Release Date:
20101004
Copyright:

Record: 2
Title:
A large scale study of the assessment of the social environment of middle and secondary schools: The validity and utility of teachers' ratings of school climate, cultural pluralism, and safety problems for understanding school effects and school improvement.
Authors:
Brand, Stephen, U Rhode Island, Kingston, RI, US, sbrand@uri.edu
Felner, Robert D., U Louisville, Louisville, KY, US
Seitsinger, Anne, U Rhode Island, Kingston, RI, US
Burns, Amy, U Rhode Island, Kingston, RI, US
Bolton, Natalie, U Louisville, Louisville, KY, US
Address:
Brand, Stephen, sbrand@uri.edu
Source:
Journal of School Psychology, Vol 46(5), Oct, 2008. pp. 507-535.
Page Count:
29
Publisher:
Netherlands : Elsevier Science
ISSN:
0022-4405 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
middle schools, secondary schools, teacher ratings, school climate, cultural pluralism, safety problems, school improvement, adolescent development, student ratings, adjustment, academic achievement
Abstract:
Due to changes in state and federal policies, as well as logistical and fiscal limitations, researchers must increasingly rely on teachers' reports of school climate dimensions in order to investigate the developmental impact of these dimensions, and to evaluate efforts to enhance the impact of school environments on the development of young adolescents. Teachers' climate ratings exhibited a robust dimensional structure, high levels of internal consistency, and moderate levels of stability over 1-and 2-year time spans. Teachers' climate ratings were also found to be related consistently with students' ratings. In three large-scale samples of schools, teachers' climate ratings were associated significantly and consistently with students' performance on standardized tests of academic achievement, and with indexes of their academic, behavioral, and socio-emotional adjustment. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Adolescent Development; *Junior High Schools; *School Environment; *Student Attitudes; *Teacher Attitudes; Academic Achievement; Junior High School Students; Middle Schools; Middle School Students; Safety; Secondary Education; Social Adjustment; Multiculturalism
PsycINFO Classification:

Record: 3
Title:
A metastructure for multicultural professional psychology education and training: Standards and philosophy.
Authors:
Adams, Diane, Alliant International U, California School of Professional Psychology, Alameda, CA, US
Source:
The California School of Professional Psychology handbook of multicultural education, research, intervention, and training. Davis-Russell, Elizabeth (Ed); pp. 20-36; San Francisco, CA, US: Jossey-Bass; 2002. xvii, 344 pp.
Page Count:
17
ISBN:
0-7879-5763-1 (Hardcover)
Language:
English
Keywords:
multicultural psychology development, basic premises, cultural pluralism, psychosocial & sociocultural perspectives, community & systems intervention, professional psychology education
Abstract:
In this chapter, stages in the development of multicultural psychology within professional psychology are reviewed, and the controversy and dialogue that accompanied changes in curricula and institutions are discussed. This dialogue took place around some of the basic premises of multicultural psychology. Those basic premises are identified here as a culturally pluralistic philosophy, a psychosocial and sociopolitical perspective on development and treatment, and a community and systems intervention strategy in addition to individual intervention strategies. The history and theoretical bases of these premises are described and posited as an organizing metastructure for education, training, and practice of professional psychology. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Community Psychology; *Psychology Education; *Psychosocial Factors; *Sociocultural Factors; *Multiculturalism; Intervention; Values
PsycINFO Classification:
Professional Education & Training (3410)
Population:

Intended Audience:

Record: 4
Title:
Active versus passive pluralism: A changing style of civil religion?
Authors:
Hecht, Richard D., University of California, Santa Barbara, CA, US
Source:
Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science, Vol 612(1), Jul, 2007. pp. 133-151.
Page Count:
19
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0002-7162 (Print)
1552-3349 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
cultural pluralism, civil religion, US immigration
Abstract:
The reform of the United States Immigration Act in 1965 transformed what Robert Bellah identified as "American civil religion" and one of its central components: America's unique religious pluralism. At mid-century, Will Herberg showed how religion functions in the creation of American identity through what we call here "passive pluralism." This passive pluralism allowed the mainline religions of America to claim a presence within the nation. But the new immigration patterns have created what the author calls here "active pluralism," which lays assertive claim to the meanings of public time and space. This argument is explored through the construction of an Orthodox Jewish ritual space or eruv in Los Angeles. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Immigration; *Religion; *Multiculturalism
PsycINFO Classification:
Social Processes & Social Issues (2900)
Population:
Human
Location:
US
Format Covered:
Electronic
Publication Type:
Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal
Document Type:
Journal Article
Release Date:
20070917
Correction Date:
20111017

http://dx.doi.org.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/10.1177/0002716207301071
Accession Number:
2007-10891-008
Number of Citations in Source:
25
UR:
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2007-10891-008&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2007-10891-008&site=ehost-live&scope=site

Record: 5
Title:
Aetiology and mutability of commodification.
Authors:
St John, Jeremy, Centre for Applied Philosophy and Public Ethics, School of Philosophy, Archaeology and Social Inquiry, University of Melbourne, Melbourne, VIC, Australia, jstjohn@unimelb.edu.au
Address:
St John, Jeremy, jstjohn@unimelb.edu.au
Source:
Electronic Journal of Business Ethics and Organization Studies, Vol 13(2), 2008. pp. 84-91.
Page Count:
8
Publisher:
Finland : Business and Organization Ethics Network (BON)
ISSN:
1239-2685 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
aetiology, mutability, commodification, philosophy, political philosophers, relativism, marketing
Abstract:
Concerns over the erosion of a comprehensive public conception of morality are longstanding in political philosophy, but while some contemporary political philosophers see the relevant cause as being an increase in the acceptance of ethical relativism, others see this trend as the result of an increased intrusion of a market-based ethos into various social spheres that have traditionally been the province of non-market values. Thus while both accounts agree on the normative claim that there are certain values appropriate to particular areas of our lives, and on the descriptive claim that these values seem to be under threat, each postulate a different aetiology for the perceived phenomenon. This paper tentatively accepts the two claims over which both accounts agree, and examines the question over which they do not; the issue of causation, as well as looking at the feasibility and desirability of reversing the perceived progression. Taking into account cross-cultural longitudinal empirical studies of attitudinal change towards various socio-cultural issues, this paper postulates in qualified accordance with the first proposed aetiology, suggesting ethical and cultural pluralism to be prior to market forces, while accepting the probability that each play a significant role, and looks at the likelihood and advisability of change. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Etiology; *Relativism; *World View; *Philosophers; Marketing
PsycINFO Classification:
Industrial & Organizational Psychology (3600)
Population:
Human
Format Covered:
Electronic
Publication Type:
Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal
Document Type:
Journal Article
Release Date:
20100104
Accession Number:
2009-02388-008
Number of Citations in Source:
17
UR:
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2009-02388-008&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2009-02388-008&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2009-02388-008&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Aetiology and mutability of commodification.</A>
Database:

Record: 6
Title:
Alain Locke on race and reciprocity: The necessity of epideictic rhetoric for cultural pluralism.
Authors:
Danisch, Robert, Concordia University, Montreal, PQ, Canada, rdanisch@alcor.concordia.ca
Address:
Danisch, Robert, Concordia University, 6580 Rue De La Roche, Montreal, PQ, Canada, H2S 2E3, rdanisch@alcor.concordia.ca
Source:
Howard Journal of Communications, Vol 19(4), Oct-Dec, 2008. pp. 297-314.
Page Count:
18
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
1064-6175 (Print)
1096-4649 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
epideictic rhetoric, cultural pluralism, aesthetic sensibilities, race, reciprocity
Abstract:
In this essay, Alain Locke's work is read as a search for an epideictic rhetoric. Locke, through his philosophy and editorial work, helps rethink the significance of epideictic rhetoric by articulating a pluralist notion of values and accounting for competition between value-systems. He suggested that race can and should be celebrated, and that acts of celebration should use aesthetic sensibilities capable of displaying the value of race. Showing the connections between Locke's philosophy and the rhetorical tradition illustrates the value and potential of a multi-cultural citizenry and the necessity of epideictic rhetoric in producing, maintaining, and negotiating relationships within such a community. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Race (Anthropological); *Reciprocity; *Rhetoric; *Multiculturalism; Aesthetic Preferences
PsycINFO Classification:
Social Processes & Social Issues (2900)
Population:
Human
Format Covered:
Print

Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal

20090706

Record: 7
Title:
Anglo–native relations in Australia, New Zealand and the USA.
Authors:
Havighurst, Robert J., U Queensland, Brisbane, Australia
Source:
Educational Research Quarterly, Vol 8(4), 1984. Special Issue: Culture, language, education in Alaska, Canada, Hawaii, Guam, Puerto Rico, Australia, New Zealand: Implications for US mainland educators. pp. 103-112.
Page Count:
10
Publisher:
US : U. of Southern Calif. Sch. of Educ
ISSN:
0196-5042 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
interaction of Western culture & primitive cultures, Australia & New Zealand & US
Abstract:
Examines the interaction of Western culture with primitive cultures in what are now Australia, New Zealand, and the US. Relations between Anglo emigrants and the Aborigines, the Maoris, and the American Indians are traced. It is concluded that Anglo–Native relations point to assimilative and acculturative forces, and that, despite the wrongs inflicted on the language and culture of these native groups, there are signs that these societies are moving toward acceptance of cultural pluralism. (9 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Acculturation; *Racial and Ethnic Relations; Cross Cultural Differences

Record: 8
Title:
Antecedents and Components of Majority Attitudes toward Multiculturalism in the Netherlands.
Authors:
Breugelmans, Seger M., Faculty of Social & Behavioral Sciences, Tilburg U, Tilburg, Netherlands, Sbreugcl@uvt.nl
van de Vijver, Fons J. R., Faculty of Social & Behavioral Sciences, Tilburg U, Tilburg, Netherlands
Address:
Breugelmans, Seger M., Dept of Psychology, Faculty of Social & Behavioural Sciences, Tilburg U, P.O. Box 90153, 5000 LE, Tilburg, Netherlands, Sbreugcl@uvt.nl
Source:
Applied Psychology: An International Review, Vol 53(3), Jul, 2004. pp. 400-422.
Page Count:
23
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Blackwell Publishing
Other Journal Titles:
International Review of Applied Psychology
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
ISSN:
0269-994X (Print)
1464-0597 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
majority attitudes, multiculturalism, predictors, level of education, models
Abstract:
Predictors and components of attitudes toward multiculturalism were studied in 341 native Dutch people. Attitudes were found to have a unidimensional structure, but the level of support for multiculturalism was found to vary significantly over societal domains. Level of education and living in city districts with few non-natives were the only background variables that were (positively) related to support for multiculturalism. A path model, with psychological background variables (knowledge, life satisfaction, life opportunities, perceived social norms about multiculturalism as a threat and support for multiculturalism, and social desirability) predicting attitudes and behavior, showed a good fit. Generally, exclusionist positions were not endorsed by majority Dutch, but cultural pluralism was not seen as a valuable asset of their society, and they are not inclined to put much effort into minority integration. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Adult Attitudes; *Racial and Ethnic Attitudes; *Multiculturalism; Educational Attainment Level; Models
PsycINFO Classification:
Culture & Ethnology (2930)
Population:
Human
Male
Female

Netherlands
Age Group:

Methodology:

Persistent link to this record (Permalink):

Record: 9
Title:
Art and Consciousness--The Pedagogy of Art and Transformation.
Authors:
Grady, Michael, John F. Kennedy University, Orinda, CA, US
Source:
Visual Arts Research, Vol 32(1,issue62), 2006. pp. 83-91.
Page Count:
9
Publisher:
US : University of Illinois Press
Other Journal Titles:
Review of Research in Visual Arts Education; Review of Research in Visual and Environmental Education
ISSN:
0736-0770 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
art education, consciousness, pedagogy, cross cultural awareness, community service, spiritual awareness
Abstract:
The world has changed profoundly in the past 50 years, but our approaches to educating artists have not. This paper describes the evolution and unique educational approaches of the Department of Arts and Consciousness at John F. Kennedy University in California - a studio art program that uses innovative holistic techniques to lead students into the integration of body, mind, spirit and culture, through art. The program stresses cross-cultural awareness, community service and spiritual awareness. The historical and cultural foundations for the re-emergence of art as a non-religious, spiritual, and self-integrative practice are examined. These foundations include ideas associated with the Bauhaus, Asian art and the Automatist branch of the Surrealist movement. The department's educational philosophies and curriculum are discussed within the context of overlooked spiritual legacies of modernism, cultural pluralism, and the changing roles of art as professional practice. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Art Education; *Community Services; *Consciousness States; *Spirituality; *Multiculturalism; Teaching
PsycINFO Classification:

Human

Database:

Record: 10
Title:
Beyond curriculum 2000: Some national and international perspectives on A level English literature.
Authors:
Snapper, Gary, Institute of Education, London, United Kingdom
Source:
International Journal of Adolescence and Youth, Vol 14(1), 2007. pp. 13-29.
Page Count:
17
Publisher:
United Kingdom : AB Academic Publishers
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
0267-3843 (Print)
2164-4527 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
curriculum, A level English literature, post-16 education, cultural pluralism
Abstract:
This paper discusses and compares post-16 English Literature curricula in Australia and the UK, and the International Baccalaureate diploma, in the context of issues about breadth and depth in post-16 education, reflecting on the different structures and philosophies which have influenced approaches to teaching and learning at this level. It argues that, if A Level English students are to manage the transition to higher education effectively, and/or develop a broad, contemporary understanding of literature and literary studies, the post-16 literature curriculum in the United Kingdom needs to develop further in progressive directions informed by contemporary developments in higher education English, and by notions of critical literacy and cultural pluralism, as in the other systems described. It suggests that the effect of central government reforms in the United Kingdom, and the consequent weakening of professional networks at national and regional levels, as well as conflicts within the profession about the nature of literature teaching, are responsible for lack of progress in this regard. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Curriculum; *Higher Education; *Literature; *Multiculturalism
PsycINFO Classification:

Record: 11
Title:
Beyond national culture: Implications of cultural dynamics for consumer research.
Authors:
Craig, C. Samuel, Stern School of Business, New York University, New York, NY, US, scraig@stern.nyu.edu
Douglas, Susan P., Stern School of Business, New York University, New York, NY, US
Address:
Craig, C. Samuel, scraig@stern.nyu.edu
Source:
International Marketing Review, Vol 23(3), 2006. pp. 322-342.
Page Count:
21
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Emerald Group Publishing Limited
ISSN:
0265-1335 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
national culture, cultural dynamics, consumer research, global environment
Abstract:
Purpose: To develop a more thorough understanding of culture in a rapidly changing global environment. Design/methodology/approach: The recent literature dealing with ways in which cultural dynamics are influencing the nature and meaning of culture are examined. Different perspectives of culture related to three key components of culture, intangibles, material culture and communication, are explored. Based on this, directions for research on the content of culture are discussed as well as how it should be approached. Findings: Culture is becoming increasingly deterritorialized and penetrated by elements from other cultures. This is resulting in cultural contamination, cultural pluralism and hybridization. It has become more difficult to study culture as it is becoming diffuse. At the same time, it is becoming more important to study it because of its pervasive influence on consumer behavior. Research limitations/implications: Given that culture is no longer a phenomenon defined by and isolated to a particular locale, research on culture must carefully specify the role of culture, define the appropriate unit of analysis, isolate confounding influences and expand the range of contexts. Originality/value: The parallel trends of globalization and multiculturalism make it increasingly important to develop a deeper understanding of culture and its various manifestations. For progress to be made, research designs must account for this complexity and span multiple contexts to establish the generality of findings. This will result in improved knowledge of culture and its role in molding consumption behavior. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Consumer Behavior; *Consumer Research; *Globalization; *Sociocultural Factors
PsycINFO Classification:
Consumer Psychology (3900)

Record: 13
Title:
Can't We All Just Get Along?
Authors:
Triandis, Harry C., Dept of Psychology, U Illinois, Champaign, IL, US, triandis@uiuc.edu
Address:
Triandis, Harry C., Dept of Psychology, U Illinois, 329 Psychology Bldg, 603 East Daniel Street, Champaign, IL, US, 61820, triandis@uiuc.edu
Source:
PsycCRITIQUES, Vol 46 (1), Feb, 2001. pp. 53-55.
Page Count:
3
Publisher:
US : American Psychological Association
Reviewed Item:
Prentice, Deborah A. (Ed); Miller, Dale T. (Ed). (1999) Cultural Divides: Understanding and Overcoming Group Conflict New York: Russell Sage, 1999. 507 pp. $49.95 0-87154-690-6.
ISSN:
1554-0138 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
intergroup relations, cultural differences, dominant culture, ethnic hierarchy
Abstract:
Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 2001, Vol 46(1), 53-55. Reviews the book "Cultural Divides: Understanding and Overcoming Group Conflict" edited by Deborah A. Prentice and Dale T. Miller (see record 1999-02753-000). Starting in 1992 a group of social psychologists, invited by the Russell Sage Foundation, discussed the implications of contemporary psychological research on culture and identity for predicting, understanding, and improving intergroup relations. The group met for six years, and this book is the fruit of these efforts. The distinguished social psychologists contributing examined four perspectives: (a) the ethnic hierarchy model, in which a dominant group claims rights and privileges not to be shared with other subordinate groups; (b) the one-way assimilation model, which requires minorities to abandon their culture and fully adopt the dominant culture; (c) the cultural pluralism model, according to which ethnic groups can maintain their distinct cultures, while adhering to a set of rules and understandings that enable them to live with other groups; and (d) the separatism model, in which culturally distinct groups withdraw from mainstream society and form autonomous, self-governing communities. This volume is particularistic: It presents very little work that purports to be universal and much that is based on cultural differences. There are many more sins of omission than of commission. Overall, this book is well worth the price. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Cross Cultural Differences; *Intergroup Dynamics; *Social Psychology; Conflict; Ethnic Identity; Racial and Ethnic Groups; Racial and Ethnic Relations

Record: 14
Title:
Chadors, feminists, terror: The racial politics of U.S. media representations of the 1979 Iranian women’s movement.
Authors:
Chan-Malik, Sylvia, Department of American Studies, University of California, Santa Cruz, CA, US
Source:
Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science, Vol 637(1), Sep, 2011. pp. 112-140.
Page Count:
29
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0002-7162 (Print)
1552-3349 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
chadors, feminists, terror, racial politics, media representations, Islam, Iranian women's movements
Abstract:
On March 8, 1979, Iranian women took to the streets of Tehran for International Women’s Day. This article examines American media representations of the weeklong protests and explores how the event occasioned the emergence of a distinctly American—and deeply racialized—“discourse of the veil,” in which “Islam” was rendered a national catchphrase for terror and the figure of the “Poor Muslim Woman” entered U.S. cultural discourse as a symbol of a new world order. Through analysis of U.S. media coverage, this piece tracks how discourses of second-wave feminism, a post–civil rights rhetoric of racial and cultural pluralism, and late–Cold War logics of secularism and liberal democracy intersected to create a racial-orientalist discourse of the veil, which would subsequently be deployed to justify U.S. military aggression in the Middle East while perpetuating state violence against women, immigrants, and people of color throughout the 1980s and into the post-9/11 era. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Islam; *Mass Media; *Politics; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Womens Liberation Movement; Activism; Feminist Psychology; Terrorism

Record: 15
Title:
Challenging Cognitive and Moral Imperialism.
Authors:
Mantovani, Giuseppe, Department of General Psychology, University of Padua, Padua, Italy, giuseppe.mantovani@unipd.it
Address:
Mantovani, Giuseppe, Department of General Psychology, University of Padua, Via Venizia 8, 35131, Padua, Italy, giuseppe.mantovani@unipd.it
Source:
PsycCRITIQUES, Vol 49 (6), Dec, 2004. pp. 756-759.
Page Count:
4
Publisher:
US : American Psychological Association
Reviewed Item:
Shweder, Richard A. (2003) Why Do Men Barbecue? Recipes for Cultural Psychology Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 2003. 419 pp. $22.95 0-674-01135-X (Paperback).
ISSN:
1554-0138 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
culture, cultural psychology, cross cultural differences
Abstract:
Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 2004, Vol 49(6), 756-759. Review of book Why Do Men Barbecue? Recipes for Cultural Psychology by Richard A. Shweder (see record 2003-00366-000). This lucid, engaging, splendidly written book discusses issues of the utmost social and scientific relevance with passion and courage. Defending a pluralist conception of culture, presenting moral worlds encountered in field studies, and rejecting tacit or explicit beliefs of Western superiority are the main aims of Shweder's discourse. Against those moral activists who seem to possess too firm a sense of what is objectively and universally right or wrong. Shweder claims that different cultures should be considered equal in dignity. Shweder's defense of cultural pluralism is illuminating and courageous but seems to rely on an idea of culture as too fixed and self-contained to acknowledge the positive role that agency and moral activists can play in promoting change across different moral worlds. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Record: 16
Title:
Changes in racial stereotypes among college students.
Authors:
Maykovich, Minako K., Sacramento State Coll
Source:
British Journal of Social Psychiatry & Community Health, Vol. 6(2), 1972. pp. 126-133.
Page Count:
8
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Avenue Publishing Company
Language:
English
Keywords:
racial stereotyped attitude change, white & black & Japanese college students, 1932-1970
Abstract:
Examined the changes in stereotypical images of whites, blacks, and Japanese between 1932 and 1970. Using the same method as the pioneer study of D. Katz and K. W. Braly, 100 white, 100 Japanese, and 100 black male and female university students were asked to choose the 5 traits from a list of 84 attributes that they deemed most characteristic of each racial group. Results were compared to similar studies conducted since 1932. It was found that the image of whites, predominantly one of progressivism, individualism, and intelligence in previous testing from 1932 to 1960, changed in the 1970 testing to an emphasis on materialism and hedonism, especially in the eyes of politically active Japanese American Ss. The classical primitive image held of the blacks from 1932 to 1950 contrasted with the 1970 image of aggressiveness and straightforwardness along with their persistent trait of musicality. The Japanese image had emerged in 1970 as ambitious, industrious, loyal to family, reserved, and quiet. The greater degree of stereotypy among racial images which in the 1930's tended to support white ascendancy has become more diversified to accommodate the changing ideological transformation from white ascendancy to cultural pluralism. (35 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Blacks; *Longitudinal Studies; *Racial and Ethnic Attitudes; *Stereotyped Attitudes; *Whites; Racial and Ethnic Groups; Social Change
PsycINFO Classification:
Social Processes & Social Issues (2900)
Population:
Human
Methodology:
Empirical Study; Longitudinal Study
Format Covered:
Print
Publication Type:
Journal; Peer-Reviewed Status-Unknown
Document Type:
Journal Article
Release Date:
19731201

1973-31145-001
UR:

Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=1973-31145-001&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=1973-31145-001&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Changes in racial stereotypes among college students.</A>
Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 17
Title:
Changes in racial stereotypes among college students.
Authors:
Maykovich, Minako K., Sacramento State Coll
Source:
Human Relations, Vol. 24(5), Oct, 1971. pp. 371-386.
Page Count:
16
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0018-7267 (Print)
1741-282X (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
racial stereotype changes, comparison of 1932 & 1970 studies, black vs. white vs. Japanese undergraduates
Abstract:
Reviews previous studies of racial stereotypes and compares changes with current stereotypes. A sample of 100 white, 100 black, and 100 Japanese students at Sacramento State College were administered the same instrument as in the 1932 Katz and Braly study. In earlier studies whites had been described as intelligent, ambitious, industrious, materialistic, and pleasure-loving. In 1970 white traits emphasized were materialistic, pleasure-loving, straightforward, and ambitious. Earlier studies of black stereotypes held them to be superstitious, slovenly, religious, happy-go-lucky, ignorant, and pleasure-loving. The 1970 image had shifted radically to include aggressiveness and straightforwardness along with the persistent black trait of musicality. The Japanese stereotypes of intelligence, industriousness, and progressiveness showed a relative lack in consensus, but in 1970 showed greater stereotypy than in earlier studies. By 1950 racial images had become more diversified and less stereotypical, reflecting the changing ideology from white conformity to cultural pluralism. Current tendencies reveal a trend toward reverse racism, re-emphasizing racial distinctions which had previously become blurred. (35 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Blacks; *College Students; *Racial and Ethnic Attitudes; *Stereotyped Attitudes; *Whites; Attitude Change; Racial and Ethnic Groups

Cut and Paste:

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 18
Title:
Civic education and changing definitions of American identity, 1900-1950.
Authors:
Mirel, Jeffrey, U Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, US, jmirel@umich.edu
Address:
Mirel, Jeffrey, U Michigan, 4114 School of Education Building, 610 E. University St., Ann Arbor, MI, US, jmirel@umich.edu
Source:
Educational Review, Vol 54(2), Jun, 2002. pp. 143-152.
Page Count:
10
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
0013-1911 (Print)
1465-3397 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
immigration, civic education, assimilation, cultural pluralism, ethnic identity, Americanization, 1900-1950, US
Abstract:
Examines how different views of American nationalism, ideas about cultural, racial, and religious pluralism, and policies and practices about civie education have interacted in the US from 1900 to the early 1950s. Definitions of American identity changed dramatically between 1900 and 1950, challenged by millions of immigrants who came to the US early in the century. Responding to this challenge, assimilationists demanded that immigrants shed their ethnic identities entirely, while cultural pluralists emphasized maintaining ethnic roots. Although public schools created programs to "Americanize" immigrant children, that goal was realized in an ironic way as children blended their American and ethnic identities. During the Great Depression and World War II, civic education played a role in this process by encouraging students to redefine American identity as a commitment to broad civic ideals, including respect for diversity rather than strict assimilation of Anglo-American Protestant norms. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Education; *Ethnic Identity; *History; *Immigration; Acculturation; Multiculturalism
PsycINFO Classification:
Curriculum & Programs & Teaching Methods (3530)
Population:
Human
Location:
US
Conference:
Meeting of the International Standing Conference for the History of Education (ISCHE), 23rd, Jul, 2001, Birmingham, AL, US

Cut and Paste:

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 19
Title:
Communal and pietistic identification as related to size and concentration of Jewish population.
Authors:
Gordon, Leonard, Arizona State U
Mayer, Albert J.
Source:
Journal of Psychology & Judaism, Vol 5(1), Fal-Win 1980. pp. 28-37.
Page Count:
10
Publisher:
Germany : Springer
ISSN:
0700-9801 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
size & concentration of Jewish population, cultural pluralism & communal & pietistic identification
Abstract:
Drawing on the National Jewish Population Study of 1970–1971, the authors make the following conclusions: (a) There is a core of pietistic (i.e., those who strictly adhere to religious practices), Jews, particularly in the New York City area. (b) There is considerable cultural pluralism within Jewish communities. (c) There are generic points of Jewish identification. (d) A high degree of Jewish/non-Jewish formal and informal interaction, particularly in newer communities, raises questions about the future degree of communalistic Jewish identity in predominantly nonpietistic environments. (22 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Communities; *Ethnic Identity; *Judaism; *Population; *Sociocultural Factors
PsycINFO Classification:
Religion (2920)
Population:
Human
Format Covered:
Print
Publication Type:
Journal; Peer-Reviewed Status-Unknown
Document Type:
Journal Article
Release Date:
19811001
Accession Number:

Record: 21
Title:
Contemporary South Asian women in the Canadian mosaic.
Authors:
Naidoo, Josephine C., Wilfrid Laurier U, Waterloo, Canada
Source:
International Journal of Women's Studies, Vol 8(4), Sep-Oct, 1985. Special Issue: Women in groups and aggression against women. pp. 338-350.
Page Count:
13
Publisher:
Canada : Eden Press Women's Publications
ISSN:
0703-8240 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
values & attitudes & Anglo-Saxon conformity vs cultural pluralism ethnic integration expectations, South Asian females vs White males & females, Canada
Abstract:
Assessed unfavorable attitudes of White Canadians toward South Asian (SA) immigrants by examining value differences between the 2 cultural groups. Expectations were viewed in the context of 2 models of ethnic integration: the Anglo conformity model and the cultural pluralism model. In Study 1, 2-session interviews were conducted in the homes of 105 SA women and a matched group of 105 White women. In Study 2, 76 females and 65 males (primarily students) who were White responded to a questionnaire. Data show a duality in the SA women's attitudes: traditional with respect to family, religion, and marriage but contemporary regarding education and opportunity. Their selective cultural outlook met with limited social approval by White Canadians. The latter favored integration toward Anglo-Saxon norms and values rather than the cultural pluralism of official Canadian policy. (30 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Acculturation; *Cross Cultural Differences; *Ethnic Values; *Racial and Ethnic Attitudes; *Whites; Asians; Immigration; South Asian Cultural Groups

Culture & Ethnology (2930)

Record: 22
Title:
Context, identity, and intergroup relations.
Authors:
Gurin, Patricia, U Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, US
Peng, Timothy
Lopez, Gretchen
Nagda, Biren A.
Source:
Cultural divides: Understanding and overcoming group conflict. Prentice, Deborah A. (Ed); Miller, Dale T. (Ed); pp. 133-170; New York, NY, US: Russell Sage Foundation; 1999. xvi, 507 pp.
Page Count:
38
ISBN:
0-87154-690-6 (Hardcover)
Language:
English
Keywords:
group identity & boundary salience in living-learning program, intergroup relations, college students
Abstract:
The authors contend that diversity and group identity can, under certain circumstances, be congenial to democracy and community. They report on the Intergroup Relations, Conflict, and Community Program, a circular and living-learning program aimed at helping students understand the relationship between groups and democracy. The program incorporates elements of many psychological approaches to improving intergroup relations but also focuses more heavily than most approaches on difference and on making group boundaries salient. The chapter examines the impact of this program on intergroup perceptions, attitudes, and behaviors. It also examines the role of preexisting power differentials, hypothesizing that group identity is threatening for members of dominant but not of subordinate groups. The research reported here attests to the importance of both of these factors, serving as an experiment in cultural pluralism. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (book)
Subjects:
*Boundaries (Psychological); *Intergroup Dynamics; *Social Groups; *Social Identity; *Social Learning; Educational Program Evaluation; Group Identity; Program Evaluation

Title:
Counseling special populations.

Larson, Paul C., VA Medical Ctr, Dayton, OH

Other Journal Titles:

Language:
English
Keywords:
considerations for successful counseling, minority group clients, literature review
Abstract:
Reviews recommendations for successful counseling with members of various minority groups, including ethnic background, age, sex, sexual orientation, and disability groups. Implications for counseling theory, research, practice, and training are described. Bridging potential gaps between clients and counselors requires fundamental commitment to the value of cultural pluralism, trained sensitivity, and concepts to aid in resolving role conflicts. Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 24
Title:
Counselling in cross-cultural perspective.
Authors:
Klineberg, Otto
Source:
International Journal for the Advancement of Counselling, Vol 6(2), 1983. pp. 83-92.
Page Count:
10
Publisher:
Germany : Springer
ISSN:
0165-0653 (Print)
1573-3246 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
cross cultural perspective, counseling
Abstract:
Presents the opening address to the 18th Round Table for the Advancement of Counseling held in Lausanne, Switzerland. The author discusses the ethical responsibility of counselors and therapists to know their clients' cultural values and the relative importance of universals in human culture vs cultural variations. It is noted that both of these tenets must be kept in the counselor's frame of reference, a difficult task in light of the extensive and complex social changes taking place throughout the world. The importance of cultural pluralism and the search for a positive cultural identity has paralleled the global acceptance of and desire for technological change. Examples of the harmonious integration of these developments, such as in Japan, and of cultures where conflict has arisen, such as among Blacks in Africa, are presented. Four qualities—empathy, skill in communication, sensitivity, and willingness to inform clients about the nature of the counseling process—are regarded as important for therapists and counselors in this context. Techniques for training counselors to be effective in cross-cultural situations are outlined. The particular problems encountered by foreign students in adapting to their new environments are described, and research projects designed to address these issues are proposed. (10 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Counseling; *Sociocultural Factors
PsycINFO Classification:
Health & Mental Health Services (3370)

Record: 25
Title:
Creating a culturally pluralistic classroom: Theories and practice.
Authors:
Rodriguez, Ana M., San Diego State U, Coll of Education
Plank, Carmen C.
Source:
Spanish Speaking Mental Health Research Center Monographs, Mono No 8, 1981. pp. 35-44.
Page Count:
10
Publisher:
US : Spanish Speaking Mental Health Research Center
Language:
English
Keywords:
theories & practical applications for culturally pluralistic classrooms
Abstract:
Provides educators with specific suggestions for creating classrooms in which all manifestations of a student's culture are valued, tapped, and encouraged. The approach is to introduce several variables in "implicit" culture that, if not understood by the teacher, can result in negative consequences for the student. Examples of teacher–student dissonance are cited primarily from ethnographic classroom studies. Pragmatic suggestions are made in the form of methods and activities. It is contended that only through the deliberate application of theory and research findings will teachers promote cultural pluralism and provide successful conditions for the culturally and linguistically different student. (6 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Title:
Cultural and social influences on career guidance: An overview.
Authors:
Wehrly, Bea, Western Illinois U, Macomb
Source:
International Journal for the Advancement of Counselling, Vol 5(2), 1982. pp. 131-140.
Page Count:
10
Publisher:
Germany : Springer
ISSN:
0165-0653 (Print)
1573-3246 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
cultural & social influences, career guidance & counseling
Abstract:
Reviews recent literature related to cultural and social influences on guidance and counseling and discusses how these factors have an impact on the career guidance process in the contemporary world of cultural pluralism. The socialization process is critically important to career development. Family influences, social class, and sex-role stereotyping influences have been studied in many countries. Political ideologies have both a cultural and a legal effect on career guidance programs. Schools reflect dominant society values. Societal changes (e.g., as a result of development or unemployment) offers a catalyst for career guidance. (36 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 28
Title:
Cultural dimensions of resilience among adults.
Authors:
Ungar, Michael, Dalhousie University, School of Social Work, Halifax, NS, Canada
Source:
Handbook of adult resilience. Reich, John W. (Ed); Zautra, Alex J. (Ed); Hall, John Stuart (Ed); pp. 404-423; New York, NY, US: Guilford Press; 2010. xix, 540 pp.
Page Count:
20
ISBN:
978-1-60623-488-4 (Hardcover)
Language:
English
Keywords:
cultures, resilience, adults, adaptation, minorities, stress, coping
Abstract:
In this chapter, I review the conceptual and empirical challenges that we encounter when trying to understand (and nurture) resilience across different cultures and contexts. Definitional ambiguity and contextual influences muddy the conceptual waters; research design and measurement similarly confound efforts to investigate resilience empirically. To address both the conceptual and empirical problems culture introduces to the study of resilience, I offer a definition that accounts for both processes and outcomes associated with adaptation in culturally meaningful ways. I also review the literature that does exist for a construct that still finds its empirical footing mostly in the minority world. Based on what is available, I argue that there is both homogeneity and heterogeneity in outcomes and processes associated with resilience when cultural pluralism and contextual variation are introduced into how we both conceptualize and investigate stress and coping in resource-poor ecologies. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Adaptation; *Adult Development; *Cross Cultural Differences; *Resilience (Psychological); *Stress; Coping Behavior; Minority Groups
PsycINFO Classification:
Personality Traits & Processes (3120)
Culture & Ethnology (2930)
Population:

Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2010-10101-019&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Cultural dimensions of resilience among adults.</A>
Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 29
Title:
Cultural evidence in courts of law.
Authors:
Good, Anthony, Edinburgh University, Scotland
Source:
The objects of evidence: Anthropological approaches to the production of knowledge. Engelke, Matthew (Ed); pp. 44-57; Wiley-Blackwell; 2009. xi, 156 pp.
Page Count:
14
ISBN:
978-1-4051-9296-5 (Paperback)
Language:
English
Keywords:
evidence, courts of law, anthropologists, culture, expert witnesses, anthropology, asylum appeals
Abstract:
The mantle of 'culture expert' sits uneasily upon the hapless anthropologist's shoulders, however, for a variety of epistemological, moral, ethical, and professional reasons. This chapter—prompted by my own experience of playing such a role in asylum appeals—concerns the problems arising when culture is teleologized in courts of law, transformed from a conceptual tool of anthropological analysis into 'objective evidence', or asserted as the direct cause of persecution or delinquency. The issues are complex, and their treatment is necessarily partial. For example, there is no space here to examine the crucial differences in how lawyers and social scientists are trained to think and reason. The discussion starts by explaining the role of expert witnesses, and the kinds of evidence they can and cannot provide. It addresses the widespread use, especially in the United States, of the 'cultural defense' in cases involving immigrant or minority defendants. It summarizes anthropological approaches to the notion of culture; the ongoing debate between rights-based and culture-based approaches to international law; and the impact upon anthropology of current notions of legal and cultural pluralism. It concludes by briefly addressing the treatment of anthropological evidence in English courts, with special reference to asylum appeals. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Adjudication; *Anthropology; *Culture (Anthropological); *Expert Testimony; *Legal Evidence; Anthropologists
PsycINFO Classification:
Culture & Ethnology (2930)
Forensic Psychology & Legal Issues (4200)
Population:
Human
Location:
US
Intended Audience:
Psychology: Professional & Research (PS)
Grant Sponsorship:
Sponsor: Economic and Social Research Council
Grant Number: R000223352
Other Details: Field research
Recipients: No recipient indicated
Format Covered:
Print
Publication Type:
Book; Edited Book
Document Type:
Chapter
Release Date:
20100111

2009-04629-004

78
UR:

Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2009-04629-004&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Cultural evidence in courts of law.</A>
Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 30
Title:
Cultural identity and tolerance in a multicultural world.
Authors:
Jones, Annie Lee
Source:
PsycCRITIQUES, Vol 53 (10), 2008.
Publisher:
US : American Psychological Association
Reviewed Item:
Sniderman, Paul M.; Hagendoorn, Louk. (2007) When ways of life collide: Multiculturalism and its discontents in the Netherlands Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press. 155 pages. $24.95 978-0-691129068.
ISSN:
1554-0138 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
cultural identity, tolerance, multicultural world, multiculturalism, cultural pluralism
Abstract:
Reviews the book, When ways of life collide: Multiculturalism and its discontents in the Netherlands by Paul M. Sniderman and Louk Hagendoorn (see record 2007-05881-000). Sniderman and Hagendoorn systematically examine what happens to deeply held cultural, social, and political beliefs and practices when a nation confronts the presence of difference, for instance, Muslim presence. Their book When Ways of Life Collide: Multiculturalism and Its Discontents in the Netherlands has a basic premise. They suggest that the key concerns of multicultural efforts by any government are to promote a respect for cultural pluralism in the greater society. According to the authors, this premise also includes beliefs that minority groups have a right to respect for their unique cultural practices and beliefs, without close examination of the individual citizen's perception of him- or herself as part of the national character of a country. The authors also hold that the results of governmental policies and practices can have unintended effects on the social and political character of a nation. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Tolerance; *Multiculturalism; Minority Groups; Society; Sociocultural Factors
PsycINFO Classification:
Culture & Ethnology (2930)

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 31
Title:
Cultural issues in developing e-government in Malaysia.
Authors:
Seng, Wong Meng, Queen’s University Management School, Belfast, United Kingdom
Jackson, Stephen, Queen’s University Management School, Belfast, United Kingdom
Philip, George, Queen’s University Management School, Belfast, United Kingdom, g.philip@qub.ac.uk
Address:
Philip, George, Queen’s University Management School, Belfast, United Kingdom, BT7 1NN, g.philip@qub.ac.uk
Source:
Behaviour & Information Technology, Vol 29(4), Jul, 2010. pp. 423-432.
Page Count:
10
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
0144-929X (Print)
1362-3001 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
cultural issues, developing e-government, Malaysia, information & communication technology
Abstract:
In recent years, information and communication technologies (ICTs), particularly web-based technologies, have created a more complex and challenging information technology (IT) environment for governments throughout the world. As more and more activities are migrating from physical to virtual media, users and employees have been faced with relentless pressure to use technology. This calls for a greater understanding of the human, social and cultural issues involved in the acceptance of IT systems by all stakeholders of the organisation. Indeed increasingly it has been acknowledged that one of the main determinants of IT success is organisational culture, and consequently the purpose of this research is to examine cultural barriers and enablers which have impeded or facilitated the implementation of E-Government initiatives in Malaysia. An anthropological framework based on the Grid and Group Cultural Theory of Mary Douglas is used to study this issue in more depth. This framework identifies four cultural cosmologies—hierarchism, egalitarianism, individualism and fatalism. We argue that cultural cosmologies can have both enabling and constraining characteristics and that cultural pluralism in the enabling forms of hierarchism, egalitarianism and individualism is essential for the successful implementation and operation of E-Government services. We illustrate these points through two case studies in Malaysia—one displaying constraining characteristics, which impeded IT implementation/use and the other displaying enabling characteristics, which facilitated IT implementation/use. Finally, a cross comparison of the two case studies on cultural issues is also provided. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

*Communication; *Cross Cultural Differences; *Government; *Information Technology; Technology
PsycINFO Classification:

Engineering & Environmental Psychology (4000)

Title:
Cultural pluralism and Asian-Americans: Culturally sensitive social work practice.
Authors:
Kim, Yoon-Ock, Chungbuk National U, Coll of Social Science, Dept of Social Welfare, Chonju, South Korea
Source:
International Social Work, Vol 38(1), Jan, 1995. pp. 69-78.
Page Count:
10
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0020-8728 (Print)
1461-7234 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
culturally competent social work practice, Asian Americans
Abstract:
Focuses on culturally competent social work practice with Asian-Americans. This article describes the social and economic problems of Asian-Americans and examines the underattention of social work to them. A perspective to guide culturally competent social work practice is suggested. Asian culture and clinical considerations for Asian-American clients are also considered. The value placed on filial piety, respect for self-control, and shame avoidance by Asian-Americans is noted. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Title:
Cultural pluralism and linguistic equilibrium in Switzerland.
Authors:
Mayer, Kurt, Brown U., Providence, R. I.
Source:
American Sociological Review, 16, 1951. pp. 157-163.
Page Count:
7
Publisher:
US : American Sociological Assn
Other Publishers:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0003-1224 (Print)
1939-8271 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
SWITZERLAND, LANGUAGE EQUILIBRIUM, & CULTURE, LANGUAGE, EQUILIBIRIUM, CULTURE, & LANGUAGE EQUILIBRIUM, CULTURES & CULTURAL RELATIONS
Abstract:
Cultural diversity commonly is the rallying point for conflict within European nations; the linguistic pluralism in Switzerland is a striking exception. The equilibrium among the 4 national languages of Switzerland originated before language became a symbol of nationalism and has been maintained by demographic factors—differential fertility among the language groups, offset by trends in internal migration—and political measures designed to prevent language groups from attaining a minority status. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
No terms assigned

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 34
Title:
Cultural pluralism and moral identity.
Authors:
Wong, David B., Duke University, Durham, NC, US
Source:
Personality, identity, and character: Explorations in moral psychology. Narvaez, Darcia (Ed); Lapsley, Daniel K. (Ed); pp. 79-105; New York, NY, US: Cambridge University Press; 2009. viii, 456 pp.
Page Count:
27
ISBN:
978-0-521-71927-8 (Paperback)
978-0-521-89507-1 (Hardcover)
978-0-511-59070-2 (PDF)
Language:
English
Keywords:
cultural pluralism, moral identity, theories, anthropology, philosophy, cultural differences, individuality
Abstract:
Under the naturalistic theory of morality I have defended (Wong, 2006), moralities are parts of cultures. In this essay I give a brief introduction to the motivations for the theory, explain the sense in which it is relativistic, and address some of the difficulties that confront any theory that explains moralities in terms of cultures. In particular, these difficulties concern the internal diversity and contestation within cultures, as well as the fuzziness and variability of boundaries between cultures. The first section introduces the naturalistic explanation of moralities in terms of cultures. The second section surveys the ways in which difficulties for the concept of culture have been raised in recent anthropological and philosophical literature. The third section proposes a concept of culture as conversation that takes these difficulties into account. The fourth section traces implications of the concept of culture as conversation for the question of how cultures differ from one another, and for the question of the moral identity of the individual as a participant in cultural conversations. The proposed concept of culture, it will be argued, helps to defuse the problem of fuzziness and variability of boundaries between cultures, helps us to reconcile the autonomy with the cultural embedding of moral identity, and calls into question traditional understandings of healthy and developed moral identity as possessing the properties of consistency, integration, and stability. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Cross Cultural Differences; *Morality; *Self Concept; *Multiculturalism; Anthropology; Individuality; Theories
PsycINFO Classification:
Culture & Ethnology (2930)
Population:
Human
Intended Audience:
Psychology: Professional & Research (PS)
Grant Sponsorship:
Sponsor: National Humanities Center
Other Details: Fellowship
Recipients: No recipient indicated
Format Covered:
Print
Publication Type:
Book; Edited Book
Document Type:
Chapter
Release Date:

Record: 35
Title:
Cultural pluralism and prejudice reduction.
Authors:
Carpenter, Sandra, Department of Psychology, The University of Alabama, Huntsville, AL, US, carpens@uah.edu
Zárate, Michael A., Department of Psychology, University of Texas, El Paso, TX, US
Garza, Azenett A., Department of Psychology, Weber State University, Ogden, UT, US
Address:
Carpenter, Sandra, Department of Psychology, The University of Alabama in Huntsville, Huntsville, AL, US, 35899, carpens@uah.edu
Source:
Cultural Diversity and Ethnic Minority Psychology, Vol 13(2), Apr, 2007. pp. 83-93.
Page Count:
11
Publisher:
US : Educational Publishing Foundation
Other Journal Titles:
Cultural Diversity and Mental Health
Other Publishers:
US : John Wiley & Sons, Inc.
ISSN:
1099-9809 (Print)
1939-0106 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
prejudice reduction, intergroup differentiation, cultural pluralism, cultural assimilation, ethnic group differences
Abstract:
Predictions derived from models of cultural pluralism and cultural assimilation were tested. Previous research has shown that highlighting differences between ethnic groups, in conjunction with self-focus, can reduce prejudice. The presented research tested the following questions: (a) does highlighting differences function to reduce prejudice between groups that are dissimilar to each other as well as between those that are highly similar, (b) is prejudice reduction due to distinctiveness a function of the lessened ingroup positivity or lessened outgroup negativity, (c) does making distinctiveness salient reduce prejudice toward only the distinctive outgroups or to outgroups more generically, and (d) does the manipulation equally impact African American, Mexican American, Mexican National, and White American participants? Results demonstrated that highlighting differences while simultaneously focusing on the self reduces prejudice, although similarity mediates the relationship with those who are perceived as more different. Distinctiveness also reduced outgroup negativity and generalized to other outgroups. Finally, the manipulation reduced prejudice only for White Americans, Mexican Americans, and Mexican Nationals. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Acculturation; *Ingroup Outgroup; *Prejudice; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Multiculturalism

ISSN:
1554-0138 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
counseling, cultural pluralism, Mexican American youth, sensitive psychologist, preconceptions and processes
Abstract:
Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1978, Vol 23(4), 261-262. Reviews the book, Counseling with Mexican American Youth: Preconceptions and Processes by Richard R. DeBlassie (1976). This is a book, if read carefully, that could make a difference in the practices of counseling with people of Mexican ancestry. Sprinkled throughout this book is common-sensical and data-based information on characteristics and needs of individuals of Mexican ancestry. Two pages on standardized testing and similarly brief sections on bilingual issues, psychiatric classification problems, educational concerns, and others are so short as to be almost misleading. This book represents an important beginning by a warm and sensitive psychologist. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Title:
Cultural Pluralism in Mental Health Training.
Authors:
Jackson, Anna M., University of Colorado School of Medicine, Denver, CO, US
Source:
PsycCRITIQUES, Vol 29 (8), Aug, 1984. pp. 664-665.
Page Count:
2
Publisher:
US : American Psychological Association
Reviewed Item:
Chunn, Jay C. II (Ed); Dunston, Patricia J. (Ed); Ross-Sheriff, Fariyal (Ed). (1983) Mental Health and People of Color: Curriculum Development and Change Washington, DC: Howard University Press, 1983. 493 pp. $24.95
ISSN:
1554-0138 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
mental health, curriculum development, mental health care
Abstract:
Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1984, Vol 29(8), 664-665. Reviews the book, Mental Health and People of Color: Curriculum Development and Change by Jay C. Chunn II, Patricia J. Dunston, and Fariyal Ross-Sheriff (Eds.) (1983). The challenge of cultural pluralism in mental health training is faced boldly in this book. It represents an ambitious effort to assess shortcomings in the sensitive area of mental health education for four racial groups, by practicing clinicians who are members of these racial groups. The avowed purpose of the book is to provide both a state-of-the-art assessment of curricula in the respective mental health care areas and a format for incorporating vital cultural data into the core mental health professions. Although the writing styles vary, the book is highly readable and easily understood. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 40
Title:
Cultural pluralism: Black and White styles.
Parent Book Series:
Communication textbook series: Intercultural communication
Authors:
Kochman, Thomas, U Illinois, Dept of Communication & Theatre, Chicago, IL, US
Source:
Cultural communication and intercultural contact. Carbaugh, Donal (Ed); pp. 219-224; Hillsdale, NJ, England: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, Inc; 1990. xix, 439 pp.
Page Count:
6
ISBN:
0-8058-0167-7 (Hardcover)
0-8058-0727-6 (Paperback)
Language:
English
Abstract:
links . . . contrastive features of mode and level of [verbal] expressiveness [of Blacks and Whites] to more general issues of cultural style, arguing toward a goal of cultural diversity in which different styles are heard and understood, with the potential contributions of each to contexts being acknowledged, as such, rather than unknowingly being debased or devalued (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (book)

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 41
Title:
Cultural unity, cultural pluralism and the school: Toward a pedagogical synthesis.
Authors:
Reagan, Timothy, Gallaudet Coll
Source:
Journal of Research & Development in Education, Vol 18(2), Win 1985. pp. 21-25.
Page Count:
5
Publisher:
US : University of Georgia
ISSN:
0022-426X (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
ideals of liberal vs multicultural education
Abstract:
Argues that the debate in contemporary American education between those advocating the "liberal" cultural ideal and those who support the "multicultural" ideal for public schooling may be somewhat less dichotomous in nature than is generally believed. Differences between the 2 viewpoints in their conceptions of culture and educational goals are discussed. It is concluded that seeing the 2 viewpoints as complementary product and process goals allows the adoption of the positive pedagogical features of the anthropological sense of culture found in multicultural education, as well as the benefits of the liberal cultural idea. (27 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Culture (Anthropological); *Education
PsycINFO Classification:
Educational Psychology (3500)
Population:

PsycINFO
Record: 42
Title:
Culturally and linguistically diverse college-age students.
Authors:
Kaufman, Judith, Fairleigh Dickinson University, NJ, US
Sanchez, Jonell, Fairleigh Dickinson University, NJ, US
Source:
Handbook of multicultural school psychology: An interdisciplinary perspective. Esquivel, Giselle B. (Ed); Lopez, Emilia C. (Ed); Nahari, Sara G. (Ed); pp. 597-613; Mahwah, NJ, US: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates Publishers; 2007. xxvii, 747 pp.
Page Count:
17
ISBN:
0-8058-4562-3 (Paperback)
978-0-8058-4562-4 (Paperback)
0-8058-4561-5 (Hardcover)
978-0-8058-4561-7 (Hardcover)
1-4106-1414-X (Electronic)
978-1-4106-1414-8 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
international students, college students, needs, positive adjustment, school psychologist, campus environment
Abstract:
Although the change in the overall complexion of universities provides exciting educational, cultural, and social opportunities, there are significant concerns about facilitating positive adjustment of the culturally and linguistically different student, as well as the international student. If the acculturation process is not successfully negotiated and supported, there can be a significant impact on self-esteem and challenges to the transition to productive adulthood. Research targeting the culturally and linguistically diverse (CLD) and the international student is limited, although a body of literature does exist that focuses on the meaning of college to students in general. Further, there is a limited amount of research focusing on second-language learning for the college student population and even less evidenced-based research clarifying the mental health needs of CLD, immigrant, and international students. The remainder of the chapter identifies the particular needs for the three identified groups, focusing on the campus environment as well as individual and interpersonal issues. Although less than 8% of colleges and universities employ school psychologists, the potential role of the school psychologist in program development, direct service, and consultation is addressed. Suggestions for prevention, early intervention, and treatment, as well as the importance of developing an environment of cultural pluralism and training individuals who are culturally competent, are addressed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (create)
Subjects:
*College Students; *Immigration; *School Psychologists; *Multiculturalism; Acculturation; Campuses; Colleges; Education; School Environment; School Psychology

Record: 43
Title:
Culturally sustaining pedagogy: A needed change in stance, terminology, and practice.
Authors:
Paris, Django, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI, US, dparis@msu.edu
Address:
Paris, Django, Department of Teacher Education, Michigan State University, 329 Erickson Hall, East Lansing, MI, US, 48824-1034, dparis@msu.edu
Source:
Educational Researcher, Vol 41(3), Apr, 2012. pp. 93-97.
Page Count:
5
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0013-189X (Print)
1935-102X (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
culturally sustaining pedagogy, linguistics, literacy, cultural differences
Abstract:
Seventeen years ago Gloria Ladson-Billings (1995) published the landmark article “Toward a Theory of Culturally Relevant Pedagogy,” giving a coherent theoretical statement for resource pedagogies that had been building throughout the 1970s and 1980s. I, like countless teachers and university-based researchers, have been inspired by what it means to make teaching and learning relevant and responsive to the languages, literacies, and cultural practices of students across categories of difference and (in)equality. Recently, however, I have begun to question if the terms “relevant” and “responsive” are really descriptive of much of the teaching and research founded upon them and, more importantly, if they go far enough in their orientation to the languages and literacies and other cultural practices of communities marginalized by systemic inequalities to ensure the valuing and maintenance of our multiethnic and multilingual society. In this essay, I offer the term and stance of culturally sustaining pedagogy as an alternative that, I believe, embodies some of the best research and practice in the resource pedagogy tradition and as a term that supports the value of our multiethnic and multilingual present and future. Culturally sustaining pedagogy seeks to perpetuate and foster—to sustain—linguistic, literate, and cultural pluralism as part of the democratic project of schooling. In the face of current policies and practices that have the explicit goal of creating a monocultural and monolingual society, research and practice need equally explicit resistances that embrace cultural pluralism and cultural equality. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Cross Cultural Differences; *Teaching; Linguistics; Literacy
PsycINFO Classification:
Curriculum & Programs & Teaching Methods (3530)
Population:
Human
Format Covered:
Electronic
Publication Type:
Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal
Document Type:
Journal Article
Publication History:
Accepted: Feb 9, 2012; Revised: Feb 4, 2012; First Submitted: Sep 4, 2011
Release Date:
20120604
Copyright:
AERA. 2012
Digital Object Identifier:
http://dx.doi.org.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/10.3102/0013189X12441244
Accession Number:
2012-08712-002
Number of Citations in Source:
46
UR:
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2012-08712-002&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2012-08712-002&site=ehost-live&scope=site

Record: 44
Title:
Culture Moulds Psychiatric Conditions.
Authors:
Fabrega, Horaccio Jr., University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA, US, hfabregajr@adelphia.net
Holloway, Harry C., (Ed)
Address:
Fabrega, Horaccio Jr., 257 Kenforest Drive, Pittsburgh, PA, US, 15216, hfabregajr@adelphia.net
Source:
Psychiatry: Interpersonal and Biological Processes, Vol 67(4), Win 2004. pp. 419-435.
Page Count:
17
Publisher:
US : Guilford Publications
Other Journal Titles:
Psychiatry: Journal for the Study of Interpersonal Processes
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
Reviewed Item:
Moore, Carmella C. (Ed); Matthews, Holly F. (Ed). (2001) The Psychology of Cultural Experience New York: Cambridge University Press, 2001. 247 pp. $24.99

Roccatagliata, Giuseppe. (1986) A History of Ancient Psychiatry Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1986. 296 pp. $42.00

Littlewood, Ronald. (2002) Pathologies of the West New York: Cornell University Press, 2002. 286 pp. $24.95
ISSN:
0033-2747 (Print)
1943-281X (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
psychiatric condition, ancient psychiatry, pathology
Abstract:
Review three books "The Psychology of Cultural Experience," edited by Carmella C. Moore and Holly F. Mathhews (2001), "A History of Ancient Psychiatry," by Giuseppe Roccatagliata (1986) and "Pathologies of the West," by Roland Littlewood (2002). The first book, The Psychiatry of Cultural Experience, provides an anchoring platform for a cultural psychiatry. It lays the theoretical basis for a cultural psychology and it might consist of. It does so by illustrating the pervasive and insinuating way in which culture burrows into the mind and shapes what an individual feels, believes, orients to group mates, and how he or she acts out his or position in a society. While not addressing basic parameters of psychiatric conditions, chapters nonetheless strongly suggest that character is likely to be shaped and molded by culture. This book provides one with material with which one can make inferences about how psychiatric conditions are likely to be constructed psychologically and socially. The second book, A History of Ancient Psychiatry, reviews in a broad sweep the ideas and formulations the about human phenomena we now construe as mental illness or psychiatric disorder during the formative period of European history. While predominantly conceptual, theoretical, and historical, it provides nonetheless an opening for one to propose how "real persons" burdened by emotional and social problems were thought about and dealt with by the literate elite or experts. Furthermore, insofar as the latter produced knowledge out of clinical encounters, engaged their clients (or patients, apprentices) in dialogues, and the knowledge they produced percolated through (perhaps restricted) segments of the population, this book provides a view of how persons burdened by psychiatric-related conditions behaved and made sense of their predicament, and also how indigenous psychiatry was conceptually organized during antiquity and handled through forms of healing. The diversity of views, the cultural pluralism inherent in the configuration of psychiatric conditions and indigenous psychiatry, is analyzed and categorized. The third book, Pathologies of the West, brings one to the present and illustrates the maturity that the field of interest--cultural psychiatry--has attained. It discusses in detail "real" syndromes, describing not only how culture configures them as symbolic entities, expressive entities, but also as social and historical realities. The influence of psychiatry as an intellectual as well as medical institution in modern society is made abundantly clear by a creative examination of culture and modern social and intellectual history. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Culture (Anthropological); *History of Psychology; *Mental Disorders; *Pathology; *Psychiatry
PsycINFO Classification:

Population:

Record: 45
Title:
Cultures and creativity within hierarchical organizations.
Authors:
Koberg, Christine S., U Colorado Coll of Business, Boulder, US
Hood, Jacqueline N.
Source:
Journal of Business and Psychology, Vol 6(2), Win 1991. pp. 265-271.
Page Count:
7
Publisher:
Germany : Springer
ISSN:
0889-3268 (Print)
1573-353X (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
hierarchical level, bureaucratic & innovative & supportive organizational cultures, public accounting firm employees
Abstract:
Examined the extent to which bureaucratic, innovative, and supportive organizational cultures coexist in different hierarchical levels and different functional units of 8 large public accounting firms. The degree of creativity among 122 individuals in different organizational positions and units was also examined, and the relationship of culture to creativity and other job-related variables was analyzed. Ss completed various questionnaires, including the Remote Associates Test. As hypothesized, organizations exhibit cultural pluralism along the lines of hierarchy. Organizational culture was significantly related to hierarchical level, with the top level of management perceiving the culture of the organization as significantly more innovative and supportive than either middle level management or lower level accountants. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Creativity; *Organizational Climate; *Organizational Structure; *Working Conditions; Business and Industrial Personnel

Database:

Record: 46
Title:
Der Einflu–S der Kultur des deutschen Sprachraums auf Freuds Denken.
Translated Title:
The influence of German-language culture on Freud's thought.
Authors:
Anzieu, Didier
Source:
Jahrbuch der Psychoanalyse, Vol 19, 1986. pp. 15-35.
Page Count:
21
Publisher:
Germany : Frommann-Holzboog
ISSN:
0075-2363 (Print)
Language:
German
Keywords:
eclectic linguistic & cultural influences, background & psychoanalytic thought of Freud, conference presentation
Abstract:
Traces the eclectic linguistic and cultural influences that played a paramount role in shaping Freud's background and psychoanalytic thought. Freud exploited the conceptual and expressive nuances and peculiarities of the German language to describe the perversely polymorphous fantasies of childhood (e.g., voyeuristic, masochistic). He used English and French words, sometimes with a German prefix or suffix, in connection with those aspects of the self that Freud experienced simultaneously as familiar and mysterious. He used Latin and Ancient Greek words and mythological figures and legends to formulate his theories and the Unconscious (e.g., interpretation of dreams). According to the author, psychoanalysts need a linguistic and cultural pluralism in their background similar to Freud's, which provides the intermediary thoughts, or compromise formations for their preconscious elaborations. (German & English abstracts) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Freud (Sigmund); *Language; *Psychoanalytic Theory; *Sociocultural Factors
PsycINFO Classification:
History & Systems (2140)
Population:
Human
