Record: 47
Title:
Development of community psychology in New Zealand: A Waikato perspective.
Authors:
Robertson, Neville R., U Waikato, Hamilton, New Zealand
Thomas, David R.
Dehar, Mary-Anne B.
Blaxall, Michelle
Source:
New Zealand Journal of Psychology, Vol 18(1), Jun, 1989. pp. 13-24.
Page Count:
12
Publisher:
New Zealand : New Zealand Psychological Society
ISSN:
0112-109X (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
research process & methods & program development for community psychology, New Zealand
Abstract:
Outlines the origins of community psychology (CMP) in the US and its development in New Zealand at the University of Waikato (UW). CMP is seen as a specific subdiscipline within psychology, having a distinctive conceptual orientation, an explicit value base, and an emphasis on research methodologies compatible with applied research. Three general themes are relevant to the UW conceptual orientation of community psychology: an ecological approach, competence enhancement, and prevention. Explicit values guiding CMP interventions include: empowerment, diversity and cultural pluralism, social innovation and evaluation, community development and participation, and collaboration. Research methods that give a primary emphasis to qualitative data are elaborated. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 48
Title:
Developmentalism deconstructed.
Authors:
Howley, Aimee, Ohio U, Educational Administration Program, OH, US
Spatig, Linda
Howely, Craig
Source:
Rethinking intelligence: Confronting psychological assumptions about teaching and learning. Kincheloe, Joe L. (Ed); Steinberg, Shirley R. (Ed); Villaverde, Leila E. (Ed); pp. 27-49; Florence, KY, US: Taylor & Frances/Routledge; 1999. xi, 270 pp.
Page Count:
23
ISBN:
0-415-92208-9 (Hardcover)
0-415-92209-7 (Paperback)
Language:
English
Keywords:
conservative & neo-Marxist & cultural pluralism & feminist & postmodern critiques of developmentalism
Abstract:
This chapter evaluates developmentalism as an ideology by presenting a series of critiques from distinct frames of reference: conservatism, neo=Marxism, cultural pluralism, feminism, and postmodernism. All 5 critiques detail the issues of developmentalism from their perspectives. They suggest, sometimes in different and incompatible ways, that developmentalism is a form of restraint. Neoconservatives see it as interfering with parents' and schools' freedom to bend children's characters from evil to virtue. Neo=Marxists see developmentalism as the ideological support for labor discipline that constrains workers' emancipatory desires. Developmentalism is presented as imposing artificial hierarchies of value on cultural patterns by pluralists. And feminists point to the demeaning nature of developmentalism that diminishes their opportunities for self=worth. Finally, postmodernism presents developmentalism as a technology of power whereby developmental discourse and practice control processes of formation of self. Developmentalism appears to be a limiting force. These differences in critique serve to affirm the social construction of developmentalism. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Developmental Psychology; *Feminism; *Philosophies; *Political Attitudes; Multiculturalism
PsycINFO Classification:
Philosophy (2630)
Educational Psychology (3500)

Format Covered:

Document Type:
Chapter

19991101

Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=1999-04027-002&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Developmentalism deconstructed.</A>
Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 49
Title:
Divergent perspectives on citizenship education: A Q-method study and survey of social studies teachers.
Authors:
Anderson, Christopher, U Minnesota, Dept of Political Science, Minneapolis, MN, US
Avery, Patricia G.
Pederson, Patricia V.
Smith, Elizabeth S.
Sullivan, John L.
Source:
American Educational Research Journal, Vol 34(2), Sum 1997. pp. 333-364.
Page Count:
32
Publisher:
US : American Educational Research Assn
Other Publishers:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0002-8312 (Print)
1935-1011 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Q-method study on conceptions of citizenship education, social studies teachers
Abstract:
This study explored the views of contemporary social studies teachers on citizenship education. Q-technique was used to discern the principal conceptions held by teachers in two small samples. Minnesota teachers held 3 perspectives (cultural pluralism, communitarianism, and legalism) and teachers nationally held 4 perspectives (critical thinking, legalism, cultural pluralism, and assimilationism). Analysis of a large national sample survey of social studies teachers shoes the popularity of each perspective generally, and the characteristics of teachers who hold each perspective. Implications for citizenship education in a multicultural society are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:

Record: 50
Title:
Diversity in Classrooms: An Important Response.
Authors:
Barcelo, Nancy Rusty, University of Iowa, Iowa City, IA, US
Source:
PsycCRITIQUES, Vol 39 (8), Aug, 1994. pp. 843.
Page Count:
1
Publisher:
US : American Psychological Association
Reviewed Item:
Adams, Maurianne (Ed). (1992) Promoting Diversity in College Classrooms: Innovative Responses for the Curriculum, Faculty, and Institutions San Francisco: Jossey-Bass, 1992. 145 pp. $15.95 paperback 1-55542-745-6 (Paperback).
ISSN:
1554-0138 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
campus diversity, cultural pluralism, college classrooms, curriculum
Abstract:
Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1994, Vol 39(8), 843. Reviews the book, Promoting Diversity in College Classrooms: Innovative Responses for the Curriculum, Faculty, and Institutions by Maurianne Adams (Ed.) (1992). This collection of readings provides an important response to the challenge of diversity in the academy. The book is divided into three major sections: New Perspectives on Teaching and Learning, Social Diversity in the Curriculum, and Cultural Pluralism and Core Curricula. The first section introduces a model in Chapter 1 that describes four critical dimensions of learning and teaching that affect diverse student bodies. The second section highlights social diversity in the curriculum and begins with Noronha's thesis that the relationship between multicultural and international education needs to be discussed and debated within the context of campus diversity. The final section presents the reader with an overview of the experiences and issues different types of institutions encounter as they implement change in response to shifting campus demographics. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 51
Title:
Diversity—A new mode of incorporation?
Authors:
Faist, Thomas, Department of Sociology, Bielefeld University, Bielefeld, Germany, thomas.faist@uni-bielefeld.de
Address:
Faist, Thomas, Center on Migration, Citizenship and Development (COMCAD), Bielefeld University, D-33501, Bielefeld, Germany, thomas.faist@uni-bielefeld.de
Source:
Ethnic and Racial Studies, Vol 32(1), Jan, 2009. pp. 171-190.
Page Count:
20
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
0141-9870 (Print)
1466-4356 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
diversity, incorporation modes, multiculturalism, social integration, immigration
Abstract:
Lately, cultural diversity in Western societies has, in terms of religions, languages, ethnic we-groups, transnational ties, and countries of origin, once more undergone immense growth. Modes of migrant incorporation reflect endeavours to respond to this change. While some approaches such as assimilation and multiculturalism emphasize the social integration of migrants in the host societies, the vague term 'diversity' harbours innovative measures in two respects. First, diversity addresses not only the incorporation of migrants, but also how societies and particularly their organizations deal with cultural pluralism. Second, diversity can then be understood both as an individual competence of migrants as members of organizations and the civil sphere, and as a set of programmes which organizations adopt to address cultural pluralism. Also, novel forms of diversity have emerged, such as transnationality. Yet in the absence of a rights-based foundation the question arises of how social inequality can be dealt with. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Diversity; *Immigration; *Social Integration; *Multiculturalism; Internalization; Society
PsycINFO Classification:
Social Processes & Social Issues (2900)
Population:
Human
Format Covered:
Electronic
Publication Type:
Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal

Journal Article
Release Date:
20101004
Copyright:
Taylor & Francis. 2009
Digital Object Identifier:
http://dx.doi.org.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/10.1080/01419870802483650
Accession Number:
2010-11155-009

54

https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2010-11155-009&site=ehost-live&scope=site

Record: 52
Title:
Education and will: Aspects of personal capability.
Authors:
Sockett, Hugh, George Mason U, Fairfax, VA, US
Source:
American Journal of Education, Vol 96(2), Feb, 1988. Special Issue: The moral life of schools. pp. 195-214.
Page Count:
20
Publisher:
US : Univ of Chicago Press
Other Journal Titles:
School Review
ISSN:
0195-6744 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
character training & importance of teacher as role model & guide in education
Abstract:
Asserts that character training has been regarded as somewhat disreputable but that the qualities of determination, carefulness, concentration, self-restraint, patience, conscientiousness, and endurance are each different aspects of personal capability that children need to acquire. The author analyzes and indicates the educational importance of each of these qualities within the categories of endeavor, heed, and control, which are regarded as qualities of will (i.e., the effort of striving). It is suggested that from this perspective teachers need to pay particular attention to the relative insignificance of cultural pluralism and to the importance of the teacher's role as model and guide through difficulty. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

*Personality Development; *Role Models; *Student Characteristics; *Teachers; Education; Socialization

Title:
Education et pluralisme culturel: Une expérience d'animation interculturelle en milieu migrant.

Education and cultural pluralism: An intercultural action/activity experiment in a migrant setting.
Authors:
Koykis, Fanny, Free U of Brussels, Belgium

Publisher:
Belgium : Fondation Universitaire de Belgique

Language:
French
Keywords:
pre-primary intercultural program, preschool age children of immigrants
Abstract:
Introduced activities with immigrant children at the pre-primary level using the children's own drawings and stories about family, vacations, holidays, customs, and country. This proved a springboard for discussion about causes of immigration and problems of assimilation—important to the children who existed daily within the 2 cultures of home and school. Feedback among teachers, parents, and children encouraged self-expression and self-growth and fostered a positive psychosociological environment for individual growth. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Record: 54
Title:
Education for Democratic Citizenship and Peace: Proposal for a Cosmopolitan Model.
Authors:
Ahmad, Iftikhar, Long Island University, Brooklyn, NY, US, iahmad@liu.edu
Szpara, Michelle Y., Long Island University, Brooklyn, NY, US
Address:
Ahmad, Iftikhar, Long Island University, C.W. Post Campus, 720 Northern Boulevard, Brookville, NY, US, 11548-1300, iahmad@liu.edu
Source:
Educational Studies: Journal of the American Educational Studies Association, Vol 38(1), Aug, 2005. pp. 8-23.
Page Count:
16
Publisher:
US : Lawrence Erlbaum
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
0013-1946 (Print)
1532-6993 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
democratic citizenship, peace, cosmopolitan mode proposal, paradigmatic techniques
Abstract:
Traditional citizenship education paradigms are inherently state-centered, because they overly emphasize teaching and learning about the structure and functions of government. Their goals have been limited to a nationalist agenda and are inadequate for preparing active, thoughtful, and caring citizens. In an increasingly interdependent and global world, there is an urgent need for reconceptualization of citizenship and the formulation of a new citizenship education paradigm. This new paradigm should redefine good citizenship, underscoring cosmopolitan values of human rights, social consciousness, cultural pluralism, global peace, and cross-cultural deliberation. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

*Citizenship; *Democracy; *Education; *Peace; Government

Record: 56
Title:
Ethnic group members and the correctional system: A question of human rights.
Authors:
Dandurand, Yvon
Source:
Canadian Journal of Criminology & Corrections, Vol. 16(1), Jan, 1974. pp. 35-52.
Page Count:
18
Publisher:
Canada : Canadian Criminal Justice Assn
Other Journal Titles:
Canadian Journal of Criminology; Canadian Journal of Criminology and Criminal Justice
Other Publishers:
Canada : University of Toronto Press
Language:
English
Keywords:
ethnocentrism & ethnism & socio-cultural tolerance, human rights issues in treatment of ethnic minorities in correctional institutions
Abstract:
Considers that the equitable treatment of ethnic minorities in correctional institutions is not a political, administrative, or legal problem, but rather a question of human rights. Intergroup relations are discussed in terms of the concepts of ethnocentrism, socio-cultural intolerance, and the minority's coping processes, cultural pluralism and assimilation, which manifest themselves in intergroup relationships. The relation between minority group membership and psychological, sociocultural, and psychocultural deviance is considered. The major issue is thought to be the individual's right to receive treatment consistent with his cultural identity and needs. Recommendations for correctional workers are presented, and the questions of the dominant group's responsibilities to the minority are discussed. (French abstract) (66 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

*Correctional Institutions; *Ethnocentrism; *Racial and Ethnic Groups

Record: 57
Title:
Ethnic minority identity: A social psychological perspective.
Authors:
Hutnik, Nimmi, U Delhi, Lady Shri Ram Coll, Reader, New Delhi, India
Source:
New York, NY, US: Clarendon Press/Oxford University Press; 1991. 205 pp.
Page Count:
205
ISBN:
0-19-852193-6 (Hardcover)
Language:
English
Keywords:
looks into the theoretical & research perspectives, both sociological & psychological, of ethnic minority identity in Great Britain
Abstract:
[This book looks] into the theoretical perspectives, both sociological and psychological, of ethnic minority identity and . . . [reviews] the empirical work done on ethnicity. Part II of this book will first look at what constitutes an ethnic minority group. It will then go on to investigate the sociology of ethnicity from assimilationism to cultural pluralism. Next, we will look at the psychological theories of ethnic minority identity. In Part III, research issues on ethnicity will be examined, covering areas such as styles of cultural adaptation, strategies of self-categorization, and levels of self-esteem among members of ethnic minority groups. Finally, the implications of these findings will be examined in relation to the integration of ethnic minority groups in Britain. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (book)

Source: Journal of Classical Sociology
Record: 58
Title:
Ethnic minority issues in psychology: A reexamination.
Authors:
Sue, Stanley, U California, Los Angeles
Source:
American Psychologist, Vol 38(5), May, 1983. pp. 583-592.
Page Count:
10
Publisher:
US : American Psychological Association
ISSN:
0003-066X (Print)
1935-990X (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
ethnic minority issues, field of psychology & American Psychological Association
Abstract:
Argues that 2 tasks need to be addressed in view of psychology's growing commitment to cultural pluralism in research, theory, and professional practice: The 1st is that ethnic minority group issues are analogous to antinomies in which cherished values and principles are pitted against one another and need to be recognized as such. These paradoxes are evident in at least 5 conflicts: emic vs etic studies, mainstreaming vs pluralism, equal opportunity vs equality of outcome, modal personality vs individual differences, and presence vs absence of racism today. Attempts to find a single, permanent solution are fruitless; the resolution of these issues should be an ongoing process requiring divergent reasoning and diverse solutions. The 2nd task involves the acquisition of power and influence, since means for implementing proposed solutions are necessary. A brief history is provided of ethnic minority efforts in the governing structure of the American Psychological Association. It is suggested that the search for diverse solutions and the attainment of institutionalized influence are vital in increasing pluralism. (39 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Minority Groups; *Professional Organizations; *Psychology; *Racial and Ethnic Groups
PsycINFO Classification:
Professional Psychological & Health Personnel Issues (3400)
Population:
Human

Print

Record: 59
Title:
Ethnic psychology in the United States.
Authors:
Kaplan, Jonathan S., U California, Doctoral Program in Clinical Psychology, Los Angeles, CA, US
Sue, Stanley
Source:
States of mind: American and post-Soviet perspectives on contemporary issues in psychology. Halpern, Diane F. (Ed); Voiskounsky, Alexander E. (Ed); pp. 342-369; New York, NY, US: Oxford University Press; 1997. xx, 428 pp.
Page Count:
28
ISBN:
0-19-510350-5 (Hardcover)
0-19-510351-3 (Paperback)
Language:
English
Keywords:
ethnicity & racism & discrimination & other historical experiences of & relations between white & nonwhite ethnic minority groups & psychological models in ethnic psychology, US
Abstract:
The goal of this chapter is to present a broad overview of the past, present, and future of ethnic psychology in the US. Discussion covers the following 4 areas: 1. define ethnicity and outline related issues; 2. present a brief overview of the historical experiences of different ethnic groups in the US as a background to facilitate understanding of ethnic relations in this country (both racism and discrimination characterize the historical relationships between white and nonwhite ethnic groups); 3. describe the past and present psychological models that attempt to explain different ethnic differences, including the inferiority model, the deficit model, cultural pluralism, symbolic racism, and human diversity; and 4. outline the challenges that face ethnic researchers in psychology. The major ethnic minority groups discussed are African Americans, Hispanic Americans, Asian Americans, and Native Americans. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Minority Groups; *Race and Ethnic Discrimination; *Racial and Ethnic Groups; *Racial and Ethnic Relations; American Indians; Asians; Blacks; History; Models; Racism; Whites; Latinos/Latinas

Record: 62
Title:
Ethnicity: The search for characteristics and context.
Authors:
Bernstein, George, Montclair State Coll
Source:
Theory Into Practice, Vol 23(2), Spr 1984. pp. 98-103.
Page Count:
6
Publisher:
US : The Ohio State University Press
ISSN:
0040-5841 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
characteristics of ethnic groups
Abstract:
Discusses definitive characteristics and contexts that typify ethnic groups, noting that the recent resurgence of interest in ethnic groups has produced work reflecting the search for adequate concepts and definitions. S. Thernstrom (1980) suggests 14 characteristic features of ethnic groups. Additional characteristics of ethnic groups are conscious group membership, biological relatedness, common descent, and secondary characteristics. Larger contexts for understanding ethnicity include nationality, assimilationism, cultural pluralism, and stages of ethnicity. Types of ethnicity are identified as tribal, adaptive, and revivalist. Implications of ethnicity for multicultural education are discussed. (19 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Record: 63
Title:
Global education: Responding to a changing world.
Parent Book Series:
Teaching and learning social studies
Authors:
Merryfield, Merry M., Ohio State University, OH, US
Source:
Contemporary social studies: An essential reader. Russell, William Benedict III (Ed); pp. 57-76; Charlotte, NC, US: IAP Information Age Publishing; 2011. xix, 604 pp.
Page Count:
20
ISBN:
978-1-61735-671-1 (Paperback)
978-1-61735-672-8 (Hardcover)
978-1-61735-673-5 (PDF)
Language:
English
Keywords:
globalization, education, teachers, students, decision making, citizenship, elementary schools, middle schools, high schools, geography, world studies, history, culture, social studies
Abstract:
What is the role of education in a globally interconnected world? How do teachers ensure that students understand their place as actors on a dynamic and changing world stage? How do students learn to make decisions and engage locally and globally as citizens of the U.S. and members of the world community? Global education, the field of study developed to meet these goals, aims to "develop in youth the knowledge, skills, and attitudes needed to live effectively in a world possessing limited natural resources and characterized by ethnic diversity, cultural pluralism, and increasing interdependence" (National Council for the Social Studies, 2005). Global educators have developed a number of approaches to help elementary, middle and high school students perceive the world as an interconnected system. The study of global interdependence leads to the need to understand diverse cultures, cultural interactions, and human conflicts. In the sections that follow several strategies are explicated that teachers use to infuse global perspectives into the social studies through different grade levels and courses. Elements of global education can unify diverse time periods and world regions and center students' study of local issues within a global framework (Merryfield & Wilson, 2005). (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Culture (Anthropological); *Globalization; *Social Studies Education; *Students; *Teachers; Citizenship; Decision Making; Elementary Education; Geography; High School Education; History; Middle School Education

Title:
Going beyond cultural pluralism: Science education for sociopolitical action.
Authors:
Hodson, Derek, U Toronto, Ontario Inst for Studies in Education, Toronto, ON, Canada
Source:
Science Education, Vol 83(6), Nov, 1999. pp. 775-796.
Page Count:
22
Publisher:
US : John Wiley & Sons
ISSN:
0036-8326 (Print)
1098-237X (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
development of a multicultural science education curriculum
Abstract:
Some guiding principles of antiracist education are combined with Vygotskian notions of education as enculturation in order to produce a set of proposals for a radical form of multicultural science education for sociopolitical action. Major educational goals include: raising participation and attainment levels in science for students from ethnic minority groups; and sensitizing all students to racism, and other forms of discrimination and oppression, in science and technology, science education, and contemporary society. This article outlines a radical form of curriculum development, involving the politicization of teachers, as the only effective way of implementing such a curriculum. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

Record: 65
Title:
'Half the battle'' Cultural resonance, framing processes, and ethnic affectations in contemporary White separatist rhetoric.
Authors:
Berbrier, Mitch, U Alabama, Dept of Sociology, Huntsville, AL, US
Source:
Social Problems, Vol 45(4), Nov, 1998. pp. 431-450.
Page Count:
20
Publisher:
US : University of California Press
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Oxford University Press
ISSN:
0037-7791 (Print)
1533-8533 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
'new racist' rhetoric & cultural resonance & framing processes & ethnic affectations, White separatists
Abstract:
This paper addresses those and other issues in an examination of the "new racist" (NR) rhetoric of contemporary White separatists (WSs) who focus on legitimating their movement using a cultural pluralist master-frame. In the context of theories about social movements, affect, and the social construction of ethnicity, I describe how NRWSs engage in frame-transformation and frame-alignment by (a) consciously packaging a hate-free racism, (b) developing strategies of equivalence and reversal-presenting whites as equivalent to ethnic and racial minorities, and (c) deploying ideas about love, pride, and heritage-preservation to evidence both their putative lack of animosity toward others as well as their ethnic credentials. I interpret these ethnic affectations as contextually bound efforts at truth construction that offer an opportunity to explore the role of affect in social movements. I conclude that the product of these claims is Kultural Pluralism: a blurring of distinctions between cultural pluralism and White supremacist racism, designed to emotionally appeal broadly to moderate and mainstream conservative Whites. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Racism; *Rhetoric; *Social Influences; *Sociocultural Factors; *Whites; Race and Ethnic Discrimination; Social Movements

Record: 66
Title:
Headscarves, human rights, and harmonious multicultural society: Implications of the French ban for interpretations of equality.
Authors:
Wiles, Ellen, Private Practice, London, United Kingdom, ellenwiles@gmail.com
Address:
Wiles, Ellen, 21 Cobden Crescent, Oxford, United Kingdom, OX1 4LJ, ellenwiles@gmail.com
Source:
Law & Society Review, Vol 41(3), Sep, 2007. pp. 699-736.
Page Count:
38
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Blackwell Publishing
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
ISSN:
0023-9216 (Print)
1540-5893 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Muslim headscarves, French school laws, cultural diversity, social equality, social tolerance
Abstract:
Through the lens of the French law prohibiting Muslim headscarves in schools, this article examines the way in which societal tensions that arise in the context of religious and cultural pluralism are translated into legal discourses relating to human rights and equality. It explores the way in which the law is rooted in France's broader sociopolitical structure and history and contrasts it to the United Kingdom and Turkey. It proposes that the law is based on an anachronistic, formal interpretation of equality that is inappropriate for addressing the inevitable cultural diversity of modern French society, and through its permeation into law and policymaking more widely, it is a primary cause of the heightened social tensions involving the Muslim minority. An assessment of the legitimacy of a law that restricts minority groups' cultural practices in this way in any society should be based on a substantive interpretation of equality and should necessarily involve an active endeavor to understand the meanings of those cultural practices for those groups within their distinct context. Upon this foundation, law and policy can be developed in a way that better reconciles the pluralism of modern society with the common objectives of social harmony, stability, and tolerance. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Laws; *Muslims; *Religious Practices; *Social Equality; *Tolerance; Multiculturalism

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 67
Title:
How child welfare workers view their work with racial and ethnic minority families: The United States in contrast to England and Norway.
Authors:
Križ, Katrin, Department of Sociology, Emmanuel College, Boston, MA, US
Skivenes, Marit, Bergen University College, Faculty of Health and Social Sciences, Bergen, Norway, mski@hib.no
Address:
Skivenes, Marit, Bergen University College, Faculty of Health and Social Sciences, Haugeveien 28, 5005, Bergen, Norway, skivenes@me.com
Source:
Children and Youth Services Review, Vol 33(10), Oct, 2011. pp. 1866-1874.
Page Count:
9
Publisher:
Netherlands : Elsevier Science
ISSN:
0190-7409 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
child welfare workers, minority families, racial differences, United States, England, Norway, language proficiency, worker attitudes
Abstract:
This study builds on in-depth, semi-structured interviews with 93 child welfare workers employed in public child welfare agencies in the United States, Norway and England, and examines their perceptions of working with racial and ethnic minority families in contrast to White service users. Almost all workers reported on differences. In the United States, workers regarded cultural pluralism as a given and considered it an inherent feature of their work, regardless of the racial and/or ethnic background of the family. Further, they identified poverty, racism, and lack of feelings of entitlement as dimensions to practicing with minority families. A few mentioned language as an issue. The views of workers in the U.S. stand in stark contrast to the perceptions of workers in both England and Norway. They thought that communication challenges constituted a major problem, and that minority clients' lack of language proficiency and knowledge about society and social systems made it difficult for workers to understand families' meaning and intent (Križ & Skivenes, 2009; 2010b). We discuss how caseworkers' perceptions may influence their decisions and affect minority disproportionality in the child protection system and analyze what factors may account for the cross-country differences we found. We also relate our findings to the broader question of citizenship and social rights in American society. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Adult Attitudes; *Child Welfare; *Minority Groups; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Social Workers; Language Proficiency; Whites

Professional Personnel Attitudes & Characteristics (3430)

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 68
Title:
Human migration and the acculturation of minorities.
Authors:
Smither, Robert, Johns Hopkins U
Source:
Human Relations, Vol 35(1), Jan, 1982. pp. 57-68.
Page Count:
12
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0018-7267 (Print)
1741-282X (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
socioanalytic model of human migration & acculturation of minorities
Abstract:
Majority–minority relations have historically taken the forms of elimination, segregation, fusion, assimilation, or pluralism. Cultural pluralism, the dominant ideology in the world today, is based on the assumptions of tolerance on the part of the majority and a willingness to learn on the part of the minority (acculturation). It is argued that modern theories of acculturation have tended to neglect the importance of individual differences in the process of adaptation. The socioanalytic model based on psychological role theory and studies of natural language is presented. It offers a model of acculturation that accounts for individual differences as well as the situational factors that affect acculturation. (47 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Acculturation; *Human Migration; *Minority Groups

Database:

Record: 69
Title:
Identity conflicts and value pluralism—what can we learn from religious psychoanalytic therapists?
Authors:
Novis‐Deutsch, Nurit
Source:
Journal for the Theory of Social Behaviour, Feb 13, 2015.
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Blackwell Publishing
ISSN:
0021-8308 (Print)
1468-5914 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
identity conflict, value pluralism, religiosity, cognitive complexity, therapists
Abstract:
Abstract Does the way we think about our personal self‐complexity affect how we accept others? Researchers have offered various conceptualizations of how individuals manage their complex identities, while others have identified links between cognitive complexity and acceptance of outgroups. This paper integrates the two bodies of work by positing a route by which personal identity conflicts may lead to cognitive and cultural pluralism. For individuals committed to multiple identities perceived as conflicting, the intra‐psychic experience of value conflicts may lead to a recognition of self‐complexity, which is then transposed from the personal domain to the social one and expressed as a pluralistic attitude towards others. This argument find support in a study of Israeli Jewish Orthodox psychoanalytic therapists who belong to what they perceive as non‐pluralistic religious groups, yet express value pluralism, which they attribute to their complex identities. One of the educational implications of this study is that facilitating engagement with internal complexity, multiple identities and personal value conflicts may promote pluralistic thinking for individuals in religious societies. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
No terms assigned
PsycINFO Classification:
General Psychology (2100)
Format Covered:
Electronic

Database:

Record: 70
Title:
If All the Kids Are White, Stay the Course--Don't Leave Them Behind.
Authors:
Priester, Paul E.
Steinfeldt, Jesse A.
Source:
PsycCRITIQUES, Vol 52 (11), 2007.
Publisher:
US : American Psychological Association
Reviewed Item:
Derman-Sparks, Louise; Ramsey, Patricia G. (2006) What if All the Kids Are White? Anti-Bias Multicultural Education With Young Children and Families New York: Teachers College Press, 2006. 186 pp. $24.95 978-0-8077-4677-6.
ISSN:
1554-0138 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
antibias education, multicultural education, racism, children, families, whites
Abstract:
Reviews the book, What if All the Kids Are White? Anti-Bias Multicultural Education With Young Children and Families by Louise Derman-Sparks and Patricia G. Ramsey (see record 2006-08655-000). By purporting to augment cultural pluralism with critical thinking, antibias/multicultural (AB/MC) education elucidates this paradigm shift from appreciating diversity to working toward social justice. At the heart of AB/MC education is the desire to open new dialogues that increase the probability that children will grow up to challenge and resist racism. This book uses an eye-catching title to directly address issues of racial concern among children; the book does so in a manner that is accessible, making it possible for educators to understand and, more important, to implement the otherwise difficult subject matter of stopping the cycle of hegemonic racism passed down to our children. Derman-Sparks and Ramsey provide a well-articulated account of the necessity of AB/MC for European Americans, but they also detail a comprehensive framework for putting AB/MC concepts into action. As contemporary racism can be conceptualized as less of a desire to harm and more of a reluctance to help or merely a desire to maintain the status quo, their professed social action is evident in practice. This book details how to explore stereotypes with children, how to work with parental resistance, how to facilitate children's reaction to unfair situations, and how to use children's biased remarks as teachable moments. The format of the book allows for a comprehensive attempt to present a myriad of possible strategies to promote inclusiveness across racial, gender, and socioeconomic differences. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

*Child Psychology; *Multicultural Education; *Racism; *Multiculturalism; Family; Psychosocial Development

Record: 71
Title:
Implementation of education that is multicultural in early childhood settings: A case study of two day-care programs.
Authors:
Swadener, Elizabeth B., Pennsylvania State U, School of Education, University Park, US
Source:
The Urban Review, Vol 20(1), Spr 1988. Special Issue: Toward cultural pluralism: Redefining integration in American society. pp. 8-27.
Page Count:
20
Publisher:
Germany : Springer
ISSN:
0042-0972 (Print)
1573-1960 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
curricula on human diversity in mainstreamed day care centers, stereotyped attitudes & interaction, 3.9–5.5 yr olds with Down's syndrome or language delays or developmental disabilities
Abstract:
Conducted an ethnographic case study of 2 mainstreamed, multicultural day-care centers. Center A had 43 children including a child with Down's syndrome and another with language and social delays. Center B had 14 children, 40% of whom had developmental disability or delay. All Ss were aged 3.9–5.5 yrs. Responses to formal and informal curricula dealing with aspects of human diversity (e.g., race, ethnicity, gender, exceptionality) were analyzed, as were interaction patterns. Findings show that, although both programs emphasized acceptance of individual differences, few planned activities dealt with race or cultural diversity. Programs were seen as more consistent with a human relations approach, not fully implementing multicultural education. The use of nonsexist language and nonbiased materials and teachers' attempts to prevent gender stereotyping were found to have positive, though limited, effects. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Child Day Care; *Language Delay; *Mainstreaming (Educational); *Multicultural Education; *Stereotyped Attitudes; Day Care Centers; Developmental Disabilities; Down's Syndrome; Peer Relations

Record: 72
Title:
In-group distinctiveness and self-affirmation as dual components of prejudice reduction.
Authors:
Zárate, Michael A., U Texas at El Paso, Dept of Psychology, El Paso, TX, US, mzarate@utep.edu
Garza, Azenett A., U Texas at El Paso, El Paso, TX, US
Address:
Zárate, Michael A., Dept of Psychology, U Texas at El Paso, El Paso, TX, US, 79968, mzarate@utep.edu
Source:
Self and Identity, Vol 1(3), Jul-Sep, 2002. pp. 235-249.
Page Count:
15
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
1529-8868 (Print)
1529-8876 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
ingroup distinctiveness, self affirmation, prejudice, social identity, self awareness
Abstract:
Hypotheses drawn from Taifel and Turner's (1986) Social Identity Theory and a hypothesized "need for distinctiveness" predict that attention to how two groups differ, as opposed to how they are similar, should reduce prejudice. Previous research, however, indicates that a self-awareness manipulation is needed for prejudice reduction to occur (Zárate et al, 2000). It is possible, however, that the previous self-awareness manipulations acted as self-affirmation procedures, which may complicate any interpretations. Research by Fein and Spencer (1997) based on Self-Affirmation Theory show that self-affirmation procedures enhance self-concept, which acts to reduce expressed prejudice. The present studies test hypotheses concerning a need for distinctiveness and the role of the self in prejudice reduction. 236 participants were asked to focus on between-group similarities or between-group differences, after which participants performed a self-affirmation task (Experiment 1) or a negative self-awareness task (Experiment 2). Results demonstrate that attention to group differences, in conjunction with a self-awareness manipulation, reduces prejudice. The findings are discussed for the relevance to various theories of prejudice and for models of cultural pluralism. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Group Dynamics; *Individuality; *Ingroup Outgroup; *Prejudice; *Self Concept; Social Identity
PsycINFO Classification:
Social Perception & Cognition (3040)
Population:
Human
Male
Female
Location:
US
Age Group:
Adulthood (18 yrs & older)
Conference:
Meeting of the Western Psychological Association, May, 1999, Irvine, CA, US
Conference Notes:
This research was presented at the aforementioned meeting.
Methodology:
Empirical Study

Print
Publication Type:

http://dx.doi.org.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/10.1080/152988602760124865
Accession Number:
2003-00006-003

Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2003-00006-003&site=ehost-live&scope=site

Title:
International Adoption and the Case of China: Implications of Policy, Theory, and Research for Psychoeducation and Counseling.
Authors:
Hoshmand, Lisa Tsoi, Lesley University, Cambridge, MA, US, lhoshman@lesley.edu
Gere, Susan, Lesley University, Cambridge, MA, US
Wong, Yuk-Shuen, Chinese University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, China
Address:
Hoshmand, Lisa Tsoi, Division of Counseling and Psychology, Lesley University, 29 Everett Street, Cambridge, MA, US, 02138, lhoshman@lesley.edu
Source:
Asian Journal of Counselling, Vol 13(1), 2006. Special Issue: International Issues in Psychology and Counseling. pp. 5-50.
Page Count:
46
Publisher:
Hong Kong : Hong Kong Inst of Educational Research
ISSN:
1560-8255 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
international adoption, China, transracial adoption, counseling, psychoeducation, adoptive families, adoptees
Abstract:
This article addresses issues related to international adoption, with China as an illustrative case. It describes the context of international adoption and how China has come to be a leading source of transnational adoption especially for the West. Policy, theory, and research related to transnational and transracial adoption are examined in relation to Chinese adoptees and their adoptive families. Based on the theoretical and research literature as well as clinical experience, a framework for psychoeducation is presented together with resources that can serve adoptive families and professionals who work with mental health, child development, and family issues related to adoption. Further implications for counseling training and practice as well as systemic issues of policy, social justice, and cultural pluralism are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

Record: 74
Title:
Jews as an ethnic minority in the United States.
Authors:
Gittler, Joseph B., Yeshiva U., Ferkauf Graduate School of Humanities & Social Sciences
Source:
International Journal of Group Tensions, Vol. 2(4), 1972. pp. 4-21.
Page Count:
18
Publisher:
US : Kluwer Academic/Plenum Publishers
ISSN:
0047-0732 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
dominant group ethnocentrism, anti-Semitism, Jews in United States
Abstract:
Describes ethnic minority and the exclusion of Jews as an outgroup as a function of ethnocentrism on the part of the dominant group and in terms of the symbolic interaction system of overt affiliation, covert identification, and societal identification. The history of anti-Semitism in the US from the colonial period to the present and the change in stereotypes of Jewishness are reviewed. Jewish reactions to prejudice and discrimination are outlined in terms of 8 factors: (a) feelings of anger and pain, (b) avoidance and withdrawal, (c) hypersensitivity, (d) self-hatred, (e) self-isolation, (f) assimilation, (g) cultural pluralism, and (h) militancy and protest. (29 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 75
Title:
Le 'rapport Parent', point de départ de l'ancrage de l'école québécoise dans la logique anglophone nord-américaine.
Translated Title:
The 'Similar report', not at all any departure of the anchorage of the school quebecoise in the English-speaking logic American north.
Authors:
Lenoir, Yves, Faculté d'Éducation, Université de Sherbrooke, Sherbrooke, PQ, Canada
Source:
Canadian Journal of Education, Vol 28(4), 2005. pp. 638-668.
Page Count:
31
Publisher:
Canada : Canadian Society for the Study of Education
ISSN:
0380-2361 (Print)
Language:
French
Keywords:
sociohistorical analysis, Quebec school system, teaching methods, educational reform
Abstract:
The article offers a socio-historical analysis of the evolution of Quebec school system since the 1960s. It puts forward that during the socio-ideological debates which began after World War II, the Parent report (1963-1965) has lead to the abandonment of the educational model based on the example of France and centred on classical humanities, but also driven by neothomist approaches. Through several changes of curricula and due to social and economic evolution, this educational model was progressively replaced by a more pragmatic one, focused on the adaptation to the economic and utilitarianist expectations of the neoliberal system. This transformation was supported by leading ideological views which evolved from humanities-based humanism to a renewed type of humanism: pluralist humanism - which was presented as being transhistorical since it maintained the continuity between both models - then to a humanist pedagogy and, finally, to cultural pluralism. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Education; *Educational Reform; *History; *Teaching Methods

Title:
Learning to be an outsider: Peer stigmatization in kindergarten.
Authors:
Hatch, J. Amos, U Tennessee, Coll of Education, Knoxville, US
Source:
The Urban Review, Vol 20(1), Spr 1988. Special Issue: Toward cultural pluralism: Redefining integration in American society. pp. 59-72.
Page Count:
14
Publisher:
Germany : Springer
ISSN:
0042-0972 (Print)
1573-1960 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
stigmatization processes, kindergartners
Abstract:
Investigated the stigmatization processes discovered in the peer interactions of a kindergarten class, using an interactionist theoretical perspective. The study was conducted in a morning program. 35 observational visits were made and 112 hrs of child-to-child social behavior were recorded. Data were gathered using passive participant observation, ethnographic interviewing, and the collection of unobtrusive measures. As early data were analyzed, the behavior of a particular child, Lester, and the behavior of other children in relation to Lester became the focus of the study. Findings are analytic descriptions of Lester's rule breaking behaviors in relations with peers and peers' group responses in relations with him. Deviance as a socially constructed phenomenon and implications of being labeled an outsider by child peers are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Kindergarten Students; *Peer Relations; Student Attitudes

Record: 77
Title:
Linguistic landscape and heritage language literacy education: A case study of linguistic rescaling in Philadelphia Chinatown.
Authors:
Leung, Genevieve Y., University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, US, gleung@dolphin.upenn.edu
Wu, Ming-Hsuan, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, US
Address:
Leung, Genevieve Y., University of Pennsylvania, Graduate School of Education, 3700 Walnut Street, Philadelphia, PA, US, 19104, gleung@dolphin.upenn.edu
Source:
Written Language and Literacy, Vol 15(1), 2012. pp. 114-140.
Page Count:
27
Publisher:
Netherlands : John Benjamins
ISSN:
1387-6732 (Print)
1570-6001 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
linguistic & cultural pluralism, Chinese languages, language literacy education
Abstract:
This paper investigates the ways languages are used in Philadelphia Chinatown through qualitative content analysis of 330 photos. Examining the linguistic landscape of public spaces exposes issues of linguistic tensions, language vitality, and language shift in multilingual settings. While Chinese in the form of Mandarin is highly publicized, thereby placing disproportionate emphasis upon one language over others, Philadelphia Chinatown shows diversity, coexistence, and creative uses of multiple Chinese languages alongside English. The signage suggests linguistic rescaling connecting real and imagined audiences, conforming to broader 'Chinese' linguistic norms while localized to connect to a range of Chineses. We show how linguistic and cultural pluralism of 'Chinese' have always existed—and continue to exist—and the importance of developing socially sensitive literacy pedagogy, especially when there is a mismatch between the informal, community-level signage and what is formally taught in 'Chinese' language classrooms in the U.S. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Language; *Linguistics; *Literacy; *Multiculturalism; Dialect
PsycINFO Classification:
Linguistics & Language & Speech (2720)
Population:
Human
Location:
US

Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2012-09611-006&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Linguistic landscape and heritage language literacy education: A case study of linguistic rescaling in Philadelphia Chinatown.</A>
Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 78
Title:
Mainstreaming in an urban middle school: Effects of school organization and climate.
Authors:
Truesdell, Lee A., City U New York Queens Coll, Faculty of Education, Flushing, US
Source:
The Urban Review, Vol 20(1), Spr 1988. Special Issue: Toward cultural pluralism: Redefining integration in American society. pp. 42-58.
Page Count:
17
Publisher:
Germany : Springer
ISSN:
0042-0972 (Print)
1573-1960 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
school organization & climate, mainstreaming in urban middle school
Abstract:
Investigated mainstreaming (e.g., integration of special education students in general education settings) in an urban middle school for 3 yrs. The present author participated as a teacher/educator who consulted regarding individualized instruction, curriculum, and teaching strategies. It was hypothesized that the school's organization and culture would affect mainstreaming. Findings confirm this hypothesis. Homogeneity of academic classes and the requirement that students fit into academic groups limited access for special education students to classes where they could function academically as the students did in general education. Special and general education teachers communicated informally and irregularly about their students' functioning in mainstream classes; and students received little help with their academic mainstream responsibilities. Students from special education were added to regular classes that were already very large, and teacher permission was necessary to include a mainstream student in a general education class. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Educational Administration; *Mainstreaming (Educational); *Middle School Education; *School Environment; Special Education Students

Record: 79
Title:
Making Minorities: Cultural Space, Stigma Transformation Frames, and the Categorical Status Claims of Deaf, Gay, and White Supremacist Activists in Late Twentieth Century America.
Authors:
Berbrier, Mitch, Department of Sociology, University of Alabama, Huntsville, AL, US, berbrim@uah.edu.
Address:
Berbrier, Mitch, Department of Sociology, University of Alabama, Huntsville, AL, US, 35899, berbrim@uah.edu.
Source:
Sociological Forum, Vol 17(4), Dec, 2002. Special Issue: Special Issue on Race and Ethnicity. pp. 553-591.
Page Count:
39
Publisher:
Germany : Springer
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Blackwell Publishing
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
ISSN:
0884-8971 (Print)
1573-7861 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
movement activists, cultural space, stigma transformation frames, categorical status claims, deaf, gay, white supremacist activist, America, minorities
Abstract:
This article compares the efforts of movement activists in three dissimilar groups to replace a stigmatized status with a valued one by portraying their groups as resembling established minorities (claims of "contiguity" in "cultural space") and as differing from groups stigmatized as deviant (claims of "distance"). The most common claims assert similarity to African Americans, and frequently incorporate civil rights themes (exemplifying frame diffusion). Tactically, these minority status claims exploit both the resonance of cultural pluralism and state recognition of minorities. Strategically, minority status framing enables stigmatized groups to claim legitimacy without changing -- simultaneously asserting both normality and difference. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Activism; *Minority Groups; *Social Movements; *Status; *Stigma; Blacks; Deaf; Racial and Ethnic Groups; Whites
PsycINFO Classification:

Record: 80
Title:
Mass society, mass media and the transformation of minority identity.
Authors:
Singer, Benjamin D., U. Western Ontario, London, Canada
Source:
British Journal of Sociology, Vol. 24(2), Jun, 1973. pp. 140-150.
Page Count:
11
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Blackwell Publishing
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
ISSN:
0007-1315 (Print)
1468-4446 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
mass media, development of minority group identity, Negroes
Abstract:
Synthesizes elements from traditional conceptions of communications and asks whether contemporary mass media, particularly TV, might be a force for differentiation rather than homogenization, revolutionary change rather than conservatism, and creation of a new identity rather than production of an identity crisis. The development of black consciousness among American Negroes is used as an example of the influence toward cultural pluralism exerted by TV. The former identity of the Negro, largely bound to interpersonal relationships on a local level, has been weakened by a rise in distrust and fear of violence in the ghetto. Concurrent with the resulting turning inward is an increasing reliance on TV, both for information about the outside world, and for development of a "symbolic community" to replace the lost interpersonal community. The co-occurrence of these 2 processes has contributed significantly to the heightened black consciousness. It is suggested that future developments in mass communications may have similar effects on other interest groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Blacks; *Ethnic Identity; *Group Identity; *Mass Media
PsycINFO Classification:
Social Processes & Social Issues (2900)

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 81
Title:
Middle school improvement and reform: Development and validation of a school-level assessment of climate, cultural pluralism, and school safety.
Authors:
Brand, Stephen, U Rhode Island, School of Education, National Ctr on Public Education & Social Policy, Kingston, RI, US, sbrand@uri.edu
Felner, Robert, U Rhode Island, School of Education, National Ctr on Public Education & Social Policy, Kingston, RI, US
Shim, Minsuk, U Rhode Island, School of Education, National Ctr on Public Education & Social Policy, Kingston, RI, US
Seitsinger, Anne, U Rhode Island, School of Education, National Ctr on Public Education & Social Policy, Kingston, RI, US
Dumas, Thaddeus, U Rhode Island, School of Education, National Ctr on Public Education & Social Policy, Kingston, RI, US
Address:
Brand, Stephen, U Rhode Island, National Ctr on Public Education & Social Policy, 19 Upper College Road, Kingston, RI, US, 02881, sbrand@uri.edu
Source:
Journal of Educational Psychology, Vol 95(3), Sep, 2003. pp. 570-588.
Page Count:
19
Publisher:
US : American Psychological Association
Other Publishers:
US : Warwick & York
ISSN:
0022-0663 (Print)
1939-2176 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
school climate, cultural pluralism, school safety, middle school students, student adjustment, socioemotional adjustment, middle schools, student attitudes, classroom environment
Abstract:
The structure of perceived school climate and the relationship of climate dimensions to adaptation were examined in a large-scale multi-year investigation of students who attend middle-grade-level schools. Analyses of the structure, reliability, interrater convergence, and stability of school climate ratings were conducted in a large-scale sample of over 105,000 students in 188 schools. The climate scales exhibited a stable dimensional structure, high levels of internal consistency, and moderate levels of stability over 1- and 2-year time intervals. The relationship between climate ratings and students' adjustment was examined in 3 increasingly large samples of schools and students that were collected during successive years of this project. Ratings of multiple climate dimensions were associated consistently with indexes of academic, behavioral, and socioemotional adjustment. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Emotional Adjustment; *School Adjustment; *School Environment; *Social Adjustment; *Student Attitudes; Middle Schools; Middle School Students; Safety; Multiculturalism

Title:
Models of American ethnic relations: A historical perspective.
Authors:
Fredrickson, George M., Stanford U, Stanford, CA, US
Source:
Cultural divides: Understanding and overcoming group conflict. Prentice, Deborah A. (Ed); Miller, Dale T. (Ed); pp. 23-34; New York, NY, US: Russell Sage Foundation; 1999. xvi, 507 pp.
Page Count:
12
ISBN:
0-87154-690-6 (Hardcover)
Language:
English
Keywords:
ethnic hierarchy & one-way assimilation & cultural pluralism & group separatism as models of ethnic relations history, US
Abstract:
Describes the varying forms that ethnic relations have taken in US history. The description is organized around 4 models: ethnic hierarchy, one-way assimilation, cultural pluralism, and group separatism. These models have both descriptive and normative significance: each represents the form that relations between ethnic groups have taken at some time and place in the US and also serves as an ideal-type model of the form these relations might take in the future. The author argues that cultural pluralism is the most promising of these alternatives. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (book)

Record: 83
Title:
Models of integration in a settler society: Caveats and complications in the US case.
Authors:
Foner, Nancy, Hunter College, NY, US, nfoner@hunter.cuny.edu
Address:
Foner, Nancy, nfoner@hunter.cuny.edu
Source:
Patterns of Prejudice, Vol 46(5), Dec, 2012. pp. 486-499.
Page Count:
14
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
0031-322X (Print)
1461-7331 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
integration models, settler society, immigration, policies, cultural pluralism
Abstract:
The United States is a classic country of immigration that has long defined itself as having been built by successive waves of immigrants. Social scientists often speak of a multicultural or cultural pluralist ‘model of integration’ in the US that recognizes, sometimes even celebrates, diversity at the same time as it assumes and expects immigrants and their children to assimilate and become American. This article complicates the picture. It brings in history to show how national models of integration in the US are not stable but have changed over time. In fact, the very incorporation of earlier waves of immigrants in the past has contributed to these changes. It also considers local-level variation—that is, differences among US cities in policies as well as in widespread understandings about the integration of immigrants. Despite these complications, there are clearly ways that national models of integration matter in the US, which is the theme of the concluding section. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Government Policy Making; *Immigration; *Social Integration; *Society; *Multiculturalism; Models

Record: 84
Title:
Morality, culture and the dialogic self: Taking cultural pluralism seriously.
Authors:
Haste, Helen, University of Bath, Bath, United Kingdom, helhaste@aol.com
Abrahams, Salie, International Peace University, South Africa
Address:
Haste, Helen, Department of Psychology, University of Bath, Bath, United Kingdom, BA2 7AY, helhaste@aol.com
Source:
Journal of Moral Education, Vol 37(3), Sep, 2008. Special Issue: Towards an integrated model of moral functioning. pp. 377-394.
Page Count:
18
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
0305-7240 (Print)
1465-3877 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
morality, culture, dialogic self, cultural pluralism seriously, moral functioning, social construction, moral development
Abstract:
This paper explores moral reasoning within the framework of contemporary cultural theory, in which moral functioning is action mediated by tools (such as socially available discourses) within a social and cultural context. This cultural model of a dialogic moral self challenges many of the assumptions inherent in the individualistic Kantian position that underlies much moral reasoning research. It provides a model for understanding cultural variation in ethical systems as well as the social context in which individual reasoning operates and develops. This framework derives from the developmental psychology of Vygotsky and from discursive social psychology, drawing on Foucault and Bakhtin. The core processes are discursive: dialectical and dialogic relationships at the intersections of three parts of a system comprising societal-cultural context, dyadic interaction and the individual agent. Key processes include the cultural and social construction of moral narratives and discourses that provide explanations and justifications within shared legitimation, comprehension and value. These provide resources that are drawn upon both in dialogue and in individual reasoning. Interpersonal interaction, a crucible and also a scaffold for both individual reasoning and for social change, involves argumentation, rhetoric and positioning. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Culture (Anthropological); *Moral Development; *Morality; *Psychosocial Development; *Multiculturalism; Dialectics

Title:
Multicultural beginnings and early learning.
Authors:
Wieseman, Robert A., Auburn U, Montgomery, AL, US
Source:
Journal of Instructional Psychology, Vol 13(4), Dec, 1986. pp. 172-176.
Page Count:
5
Publisher:
US : Journal of Instructional Psychology
ISSN:
0094-1956 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
importance of cultural & racial identity & pride & tolerance, children, implications for early childhood education
Abstract:
Discusses issues associated with cultural pluralism in the early educational environment of childcare services. Young children must be made aware of the importance of their cultural and racial backgrounds, and teachers and policy makers must be made aware of special academic and social interventions designed to integrate minority and majority students. Focusing on each child's uniqueness and individuality is an excellent method of emphasizing the importance of cultural pluralism. Learning styles related to specific ethnic groups must also be dealt with by educators. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Title:
Multicultural classroom guidance.

PsycINFO
Record: 87
Title:
Multicultural counseling in schools: A synergetic approach.
Authors:
Herring, Roger D., U Arkansas, Dept of Educational Leadership, Little Rock, AR, US
Source:
Alexandria, VA, US: American Counseling Association; 1997. xxi, 320 pp.
Page Count:
320
ISBN:
1-55620-160-5 (Paperback)
Language:
English
Keywords:
synergetic & developmental approaches to educational counseling, ethnic minority students, guide
Abstract:
As the percentage of ethnic minority students in schools continues to increase, school counselors and counselors-in-training must broaden their cultural knowledge base and develop new strategies that are responsive to the complex challenges these students face. This text provides direction for working within the ethnic minority student's worldview and identifies synergetic and developmental interventions that meet their needs. The author discusses the relationship of changing school demographics to socioeconomic and psychoeducational imperatives; the balance between universalism and cultural pluralism within the schools; the resilience of ethnic/cultural student groups; and ethnic and cultural status as stressors on the normal development of youth. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (cover)
Subjects:
*Cross Cultural Treatment; *Minority Groups; *Racial and Ethnic Groups; *School Counseling; *Multiculturalism; Sociocultural Factors; Students

  The Synergetic Model

  The synergetic approach to school counseling

  The role of culture

  The inalienability of the school's role in culture

II: General issues in school counseling

  School counseling: Content and process concerns

  Socioeconomic and political issues and concepts in school counseling

  Psychoeducational issues and concerns in school counseling

III: The school counselor's role in multicultural schools

  School counselors and teachers: Synergetic partnerships in multicultural education

IV: Multicultural school counseling in the twenty-first century

  Implications for school counselor education for the twenty-first century

  School counseling: Future trends and issues

  Selected case vignettes for study

Appendixes

  A. Selected journals recommended for multicultural and cross-cultural counselors

  B. Selected resources

  C. Association for Multicultural Counseling and Development: Multicultural counseling competencies

  D. American School Counselor Association: Ethical standards for school counselors

Source: Journal of Classical Sociology
Record: 88
Title:
Multicultural education in the United States.
Authors:
Seeberg, Vilma, Kent State U, Graduate School of Education, Kent, OH, US
Swadener, Beth
Vanden-Wyngaard, Marguerite
Rickel, Todd
Source:
International perspectives on intercultural education. Cushner, Kenneth (Ed); pp. 259-300; Mahwah, NJ, US: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates Publishers; 1998. xii, 387 pp.
Page Count:
42
ISBN:
0-8058-2745-5 (Hardcover)
0-8058-2746-3 (Paperback)
Language:
English
Keywords:
history & development of multicultural educational policies & teacher training & relation to history of cultural pluralism, US
Abstract:
Describes the development of multicultural education in the US. The authors discuss the foundations of multicultural education in America, including cultural pluralism, population diversity, and segregation. The authors also provide a history of a segregated society and schooling, touching on the Anglo-Protestant roots of segregated schooling, schooling for the American Dream, and the 20th-century crisis of identity. The authors then discuss common schooling and segregation at the end of the millennium. This topic includes discussion of decentralization and financing of public schools, inequality of school performance by region, urban vs rural environment, and by racial and ethnic status. Schooling for groups by race and culture is discussed. The integration of multicultural education into schools is described, focusing on multicultural education policies, teacher education, and approaches to and theories of multicultural education in the US. A case study of multicultural reform in 1 school is provided to illustrate the authors' points. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Educational Program Planning; *History; *Multicultural Education; *Teacher Education; Multiculturalism
PsycINFO Classification:

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 89
Title:
Multicultural education reform movement.
Authors:
Brandhorst, Allan R., Valparaiso University, Valparaiso, IN, US
Source:
Teaching and studying social issues: Major programs and approaches. Totten, Samuel (Ed); Pedersen, Jon E. (Ed); pp. 217-231; Charlotte, NC, US: IAP Information Age Publishing; 2011. ix, 384 pp.
Page Count:
15
ISBN:
978-1-61735-044-3 (Paperback)
978-1-61735-045-0 (Hardcover)
978-1-61735-046-7 (PDF)
Language:
English
Keywords:
multicultural education, educational reform, social studies education, curriculum, social justice
Abstract:
Multicultural education is a curriculum reform movement expressive of the mainstream of the American sociopolitical tradition. As a reform movement multicultural education has attempted to redress issues of power relationships as expressed in the ideology of the long-established general education program inherent in most U.S. schools, but particularly as nested in the language arts and social studies curriculum. Given its narrative orientation, a paradigmatic definition of multicultural education is extremely difficult. A scholarly attempt at definition is as challenging as herding cats, because the movement is defined not in terms of a common agenda as much as it is defined in terms of opposition to the status quo. Fortunately, one of the more enduring categorizations of the multicultural tradition over the past two decades was created by Sleeter and Grant. Currently in its fifth edition, Making Choices for Multicultural Education draws on five approaches to multicultural education identified by Gibson: 1. education of the culturally different; 2. education about cultural differences; 3. education for cultural pluralism; 4. bicultural education; and 5. multicultural education. Sleeter and Grant, however, move beyond the approach of Gibson to create their own typology: 1. teaching the exceptional and culturally different; 2. human relations approach; 3. single-group studies approach; 4. multicultural education approach; and 5. multicultural social justice approach. The attraction of the Sleeter and Grant approach is that it attempts to capture the evolving nature of the multicultural education reform movement as it has refocused from issues of cultural exclusion to issues of power. This historical view of the multicultural education reform movement gives directionality to the drift of reform, and accordingly provides a vantage point from which to anticipate difficulties for the movement in the future. This chapter will use the Sleeter and Grant categorization as a template for surveying the movement, and as a vantage point for looking ahead. A second organizing principle for this chapter is the dimensional typology provided by James Banks. Banks identifies five dimensions of educational outcomes of particular relevance to multicultural education. These are: 1. content integration; 2. knowledge construction; 3. prejudice reduction; 4. equity pedagogy; and 5. empowering school culture. Drawing on these educational outcomes as they are expressed in each of the approaches of the Sleeter and Grant typology, processes of comparison across approaches will be facilitated. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Curriculum; *Curriculum Development; *Educational Reform; *Multicultural Education; *Social Justice; Multiculturalism
PsycINFO Classification:
Curriculum & Programs & Teaching Methods (3530)

Abstract:

perhaps one of the most vital ways in which to reach children is through our educational system / begin our discussion of educational policies with school desegregation / testing and test bias interact with school placement and classroom-level segregation/integration, and are discussed second / [examines] debates about how language-minority children should be educated / discuss the role of minorities in the policy-making process—what do we know about minority political participation and representation / address the question of what can be done to prepare us as a society as we try to increase the likelihood that policies for children and families will become more culturally sensitive (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)

Title:

Keywords:

Abstract:
Discourses of cultural pluralism in literature, cinema and art today prove that inter-ethnic relations in Europe are moving towards, and in some spaces have already achieved, a spontaneous conviviality, in spite of the presence of racism and social injustice. Though the focus will be on the long-standing British multicultural experience, attention will also be paid to the case of Spain, a much younger country of migration. The specific histories of migration of these countries will also be tackled. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

Title:
Multi-culturalism: A paradigm for educational reform.
Authors:
Stills, Aaron B., Howard U, School of Education, Washington, DC, US
Ellison, Constance M.
Source:

1-880921-70-7 (Paperback)
Language:
English
Keywords:
overall goals & implementation of multicultural education for cultural pluralism & diversity & educational equity
Abstract:
the overall goals of multicultural education are to design systems of education that are inclusive rather than exclusive by providing an equitable education for all students and to ensure that these students develop their fullest potential for academic and vocational success while at the same time, preparing them for the social, political, and economic realities that individuals experience in culturally diverse and complex human encounters / implementing an approach to multicultural education entails a strong commitment to educational equities for all students / this will be a way of moving schools to the realities of cultural pluralism and diversity, and the incorporation of a multicultural perspective into the education process (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)

Title:
Multiple identities: The case of biracial children.
Authors:
Newsome, Chevelle, California State U, Sacramento, CA, US
Source:
Transcultural realities: Interdisciplinary perspectives on cross-cultural relations. Milhouse, Virginia H. (Ed); Asante, Molefi Kete (Ed); Nwosu, Peter O. (Ed); pp. 145-159; Thousand Oaks, CA, US: Sage Publications, Inc; 2001. xx, 347 pp.
Page Count:
15
ISBN:
0-7619-2375-6 (Hardcover)
0-7619-2376-4 (Paperback)
Language:
English
Keywords:
mixed-race children, biracial children, racial identity, communication, assimilation
Abstract:
This chapter examines questions in cross-cultural literature, such as, where do mixed-race children and adults belong in the world of European Americans, African Americans, Asian Americans, Hispanic/Latino Americans, and Native Americans? and what ethnic categorization is assigned to those of a mixed-race origin? Topics discussed include the concept of identity, choice of ethnic identity, identity and social interaction, self-identification. A study surveying 72 high school students (mean age 15 yrs) to investigate how biracial children develop their racial identification and the communication that affects that process. The results indicate that from 3 courses of assimilation, the majority of the participants ascribe to the cultural pluralism model. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (create)

Record: 95
Title:
Music and homeschooled youth: A case study.
Authors:
Silverman, Marissa, John J. Cali School of Music, Montclair State University, Montclair, NJ, US, silvermanm@mail.montclair.edu
Address:
Silverman, Marissa, John J. Cali School of Music, College of the Arts, Montclair State University, 1 Normal Avenue, Montclair, NJ, US, 07043, silvermanm@mail.montclair.edu
Source:
Research Studies in Music Education, Vol 33(2), Dec, 2011. pp. 179-195.
Page Count:
17
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
1321-103X (Print)
1834-5530 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
spirituality, music education, home schooling, learning and teaching strategies, community, cultural pluralism, care, choir
Abstract:
One dimension of music education and community music activity remains virtually unexamined: the homeschooled community. The purpose of this research was to examine the nature, values, and teaching-learning strategies of the North Jersey Homeschool Association (NJHSA) Chorale. This case study, conducted over a period of three months, chronicled numerous musical and social interactions of the NJHSA Chorale. Analyses of the data revealed four themes related to this organization’s nature, values, and teaching–learning processes: care, community, cultural pluralism, and spirituality. The conclusions of the study include (but are not limited to) the following: the aims and values of the NJHSA Chorale resonate with central issues in contemporary educational philosophy and with central aims of community music in particular (e.g., music making for life-long learning and for community well-being). (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
