Record: 96
Title:
Narrating Law and Environmental Body Politics (in Times of War) in 'Indigenous America/America'.
Authors:
Gooding, Susan Staiger, Committee on Ideas and Methods, University of Chicago, Danbury, WI, US, ssg4@midway.uchicago.edu
Address:
Gooding, Susan Staiger, University of Chicago, Committee on Ideas and Methods, c/o 29355 Love Lake Lane, Danbury, WI, US, 54830, ssg4@midway.uchicago.edu
Source:
Law & Society Review, Vol 39(3), Sep, 2005. pp. 697-709.
Page Count:
13
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Blackwell Publishing
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
Reviewed Item:
Burton, Lloyd. (No Year Specified) "Worship and Wilderness: Culture, Religion, and Law in Public Lands Management,"
ISSN:
0023-9216 (Print)
1540-5893 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Native American laws, religious pluralism, multiculturalism
Abstract:
Reviews the book, "Worship and Wilderness: Culture, Religion, and Law in Public Lands Management," by Lloyd Burton. While the author's account distances itself from the conventional, these are all indices of the degree to which this work is over-determined by a desire fully formed within a dominant national imaginary. In a sense, this book makes no bones about this insofar as the historical and other chapters that frame the contemporary case studies to which nearly half of this work is devoted are cast in terms of the First Amendment, the "trust doctrine" in U.S. Indian law, religious and cultural pluralism, and multiculturalism. It is, I suggest, such a formulation of the problematic at stake in the geography the author takes up, and the attendant Americanist ideology of the separate spheres occupied by religion and law, that predict the author's desire to locate nonnative religious-cultural claims alongside their native corollary and discover "coevolution" in these terms. If these American discourses are anything but irrelevant, as his cases and the works hovering in their margin suggest, they form but one discursive layer necessary to critically mapping the mutually constituted geography he has called up. As to this map's configuration, these scenes from the margin bring home law's simultaneities as a colonial-postcolonial site of encounter as the key to framing the more-than-raced histories of difference and democracy in indigenous America/America and beyond. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*American Indians; *Culture (Anthropological); *Laws; *Religion; *Multiculturalism; Politics

Culture & Ethnology (2930)
Population:
Human
Location:

Electronic

Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2005-10264-009&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2005-10264-009&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Narrating Law and Environmental Body Politics (in Times of War) in 'Indigenous America/America'.</A>
Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 97
Title:
Nationalist discourse and the ultra-conservative press in contemporary Poland: A case study of Nasz Dziennik.
Authors:
Starnawski, Marcin, Wrocław University's Institute of Sociology, Poland
Source:
Patterns of Prejudice, Vol 37(1), Mar, 2003. pp. 65-81.
Page Count:
17
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
0031-322X (Print)
1461-7331 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
national identity, ultra conservative press, contemporary Poland, nationalist discourse, nationalist ideology, Nasz Dziennik, diversity, cultural differences, pluralism
Abstract:
After the democratic transition to post-Communist Poland, ultraconservative groups found themselves legitimately able to propagate a nationalist ideology. They focused on an idea of 'national identity' that clearly and restrictively defined the boundaries of the national community. In the late 1990s a far-right movement supported by a radical faction of the Roman Catholic Church gained wide public support and, eventually, political legitimization. The fears of those for whom the transition of the socio-economic system did not bring a change for the better have been exploited by activists and institutions that consistently point to various foreign 'threats' (external and internal) against Poland's political and economic independence and against national integrity. Starnawski analyses forms of anti-pluralist backlash as strategies undertaken by the ultra-conservative media. Provided is a case study of Nasz Dziennik, one of the major Polish newspapers to disseminate a far-right discourse that combines a concept of 'national identity' with radical Catholicism. Such nationalist-oriented media use rhetoric that claims to be representative of the dominant group, and attempt to provide the audience with a restrictive sense of identity that is based on the construction of elements that are considered foreign and threatening to a sense of nationhood, a mobilization of the audience against foreign 'threats', and the exclusion or marginalization of elements depicted as incongruous with collective identity, especially the cultures of national and ethnic minorities (both 'native' minorities and recent immigrants), minority religions and alternative cultures, as well as liberal advocates of diversity. Since Polish society is in large part culturally homogeneous, its members are more often exposed to stereotyped images of minority groups than they are to face-to-face contact with members of minorities. Therefore, Starnawski argues, exploring the contemporary nationalist discourse in 'pluralizing' societies such as Poland is no less essential for the diagnosis of anti-democratic obstacles than studying the actual conditions of minority groups themselves. The future of social and cultural pluralism in Poland heavily depends on the majority's awareness of diversity and its ability to promote attitudes of openness to and understanding of cultural differences on the one hand, and a readiness to extend the notion of 'Polishness' to a wide range of cultural and social categories on the other. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Cross Cultural Differences; *Mass Media; *Nationalism; *Political Conservatism; *Social Identity
PsycINFO Classification:
Social Processes & Social Issues (2900)
Population:
Human
Location:
Poland
Methodology:
Nonclinical Case Study
Format Covered:
Electronic
Publication Type:
Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal
Document Type:
Journal Article
Release Date:
20050620
Digital Object Identifier:
http://dx.doi.org.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/10.1080/0031322022000054349
Accession Number:
2004-21156-004

Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2004-21156-004&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Cut and Paste:

Title:
Nationality, ethnicity, political socialization, and public policy: Some cross-national perspectives.
Authors:
Farnen, Russell F., U Connecticut, Storrs, CT, US
Source:
Nationalism, ethnicity, and identity: Cross national and comparative perspectives. Farnen, Russell F. (Ed); pp. 23-102; Piscataway, NJ, US: Transaction Publishers; 1994. xiv, 538 pp.

Keywords:

Abstract:
analyzes some basic cross-national interrelationships between nationalism and ethnicity on the one hand and political socialization research and public policy proposals on the other / multicultural curricula and educational practices in Sweden, the Netherlands, England, and the US also provides hope for emancipatory, transformative, antidiscriminatory, and prodiversity educational experiences, which may have international validity and relevance / uncover interconnections among democratic values, anti-authoritarianism, internationalism, and multiculturalism, for example, and specific educational policy notions that have proved to be successful in achieving linguistic incorporation, process education, community involvement, and cultural pluralism / a cross-national project to test these and other important interrelationships was initiated in 1991, data gathered through 1992, and preliminary results reported in 1993 national identity, minority status, and ethnicity / public educational policies and civic/political education / producing a survey research instrument for an empirical study (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)

Record: 99
Title:
Needs assessment and cultural pluralism in schools.
Authors:
McNeil, John D., U California, Los Angeles
Laosa, Luis
Source:
Educational Technology, Vol 15(12), Dec, 1975. pp. 25-28.
Page Count:
4
Publisher:
US : Educational Technology Publications
ISSN:
0013-1962 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
needs assessment & cultural pluralism, application at school level in Mexican American community
Abstract:
Approaches needs assessment in such a way as to encourage multicultural orientations. Phases in the process of needs assessment are specified which can be used at many societal levels. Cultural pluralism is viewed as an appreciation of ways in which different peoples satisfy universal needs. It involves learning how to become familiar with unfamiliar cultures (e.g., how to classify objects, ideas, and problems in general categories). A partially contrived example is given of needs assessment for cultural pluralism at the school level in a Mexican-American community. It illustrates formulation of goals, setting goal priorities, identification of enabling goals, translating goals into educational plans and instruction, and selection of measures and techniques for assessing the present status of the learner. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Cross Cultural Differences; *Educational Objectives; *Educational Program Planning; *Mexican Americans; *Needs; Curriculum

Record: 100
Title:
New Deal Navajo linguistics: Language ideology and political transformation.
Authors:
Peery, Char, Department of Anthropology, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM, US, cpeery@unm.edu
Address:
Peery, Char, Department of Anthropology, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM, US, 87131, cpeery@unm.edu
Source:
Language & Communication, Vol 32(2), Apr, 2012. pp. 114-123.
Page Count:
10
Publisher:
Netherlands : Elsevier Science
ISSN:
0271-5309 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Navajo linguistics, language ideology, political transformation
Abstract:
This project is a socio-historical study exploring how linguist Robert Young’s documentation of Navajo supported the federal government’s political and economic agenda for the Navajo reservation during the New Deal. I examine Robert Young’s papers and publications to show how his work in support of John Collier’s philosophy of cultural pluralism and goal of preserving Native cultures also helped support the federal government’s efforts to create a Navajo polity patterned after the US government. Young’s documentation of Navajo helped to create a standardized register for use in political and educational institutions, helped to teach and model the federal government’s concept of the ideal modern Navajo citizen, and attempted to create a Navajo public sphere modeled on the American public sphere. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Language; *Linguistics; *Ideology; American Indians; Political Issues
PsycINFO Classification:
Linguistics & Language & Speech (2720)

Human

Electronic

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 101
Title:
Of mergers and cultures: 'What happened to shared values and joint assumptions?'
Authors:
Riad, Sally, Victoria Management School, Victoria University of Wellington, Wellington, New Zealand, Sally.Riad@vuw.ac.nz
Address:
Riad, Sally, Sally.Riad@vuw.ac.nz
Source:
Journal of Organizational Change Management, Vol 20(1), 2007. pp. 26-43.
Page Count:
18
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Emerald Group Publishing Limited
ISSN:
0953-4814 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
organizational culture, organizational mergers, organizational acquisitions, cultural transformations, organizational behavior
Abstract:
Purpose: This paper signals departure from a theoretical perspective on organizational culture in mergers and acquisitions based on a binary opposition between coherence and pluralism. The paper aims to outline another, dialogic perspective on cultural transformations in mergers and acquisitions, based on an assumption that individuals occupy temporary positions in dynamic dialogue, negotiating equally transitory, but temporarily cohesive allegiances. Design/methodology/approach: The dialogic perspective derives from a constructionist approach and involves ethnographic research methodology. It is developed to track the complex contests of interests in post-merger pluralist cultures and to reconstruct their dynamics. While some events in the merger process contribute to cultural pluralism and contest of interest, others appear to render allegiance to cohesive cultural elements seductively appropriable. Findings: Two situations are presented. The first poses a view of culture during mergers in which contest over meaning is central and whereby the representation of a cohesive organizational culture is appropriated for political purposes. The second situation illustrates cross-cutting cultures in action, presenting the development of a "working culture" a notion based on flitting cross-organizational allegiances in the interest of confronting a central team. Originality/value: The paper contributes to critical work on organizational culture in merger integration. It points to the inseparability of binaries, the limits of cultural attribution and the tension instigated by the conflation of culture's "differences". In closing, it points to a future direction with a relational emphasis to merger integration. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Mergers and Acquisitions; *Organizational Behavior; *Organizational Climate
PsycINFO Classification:
Organizational Behavior (3660)
Population:
Human
Format Covered:

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 102
Title:
Pastoral ministry between the times.
Authors:
Gerkin, Charles V., Emory U
Source:
Journal of Pastoral Care, Vol 30(3), Sep, 1976. pp. 178-185.
Page Count:
8
Publisher:
US : Journal of Pastoral Care
ISSN:
0022-3409 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
changes in society, reevaluation of roles & maintenance of Christian commitment & reexamination of past value concepts, pastoral counselors
Abstract:
Discusses how changes in society are forcing pastoral counselors to re-evaluate their roles while maintaining their Christian commitment. Cultural pluralism and value confusion create situations where the minister's ongoing dialogue with his tradition can offer a stabilizing force within change. Examination and clarification of conflicting values can liberate persons both from old compulsions labeled "Christian" and from new social pressures disguised as "liberation." The pastoral counselor must be keenly aware of these values and their roots. He must relate to persons who live in different cultural frames; this requires sensitivity, reflection, and re-examination of past value concepts. Three case histories illustrate the need for culturally transcendent values to stabilize human relationships and establish a functional identity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Record: 103
Title:
Persisting ideologies of assimilation in America: Implications for psychology and education.
Authors:
Castañeda, Alfredo, Stanford U
Source:
Atisbos, Sum 1975. pp. 79-91.
Page Count:
13
Language:
English
Keywords:
'melting pot' ideology vs cultural pluralism, learning & motivational preferences, ethnic groups in US, educational implications
Abstract:
Early educational theory about the bilingual child was conditioned by "melting pot" ideology and by the Anglo-American conformity orientation of psychologists. The goal of democratic cultural pluralism is biculturalism. The degree of assimilation of an ethnic group is reflected in different socialization processes that stress different learning and motivational preferences. Recent developments in educational biculturalism emphasize the importance of understanding preferred modes of communication, motivation, and learning among ethnic groups at different levels of assimilation. (15 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 104
Title:
Physical education teachers’ and teacher candidates’ attitudes toward cultural pluralism.
Authors:
Columna, Luis, State University of New York at Cortland, Cortland, NY, US
Foley, John T., State University of New York at Cortland, Cortland, NY, US
Lytle, Rebecca K., California State University, Chico, Chico, CA, US
Source:
Journal of Teaching in Physical Education, Vol 29(3), Jul, 2010. pp. 295-311.
Page Count:
17
Publisher:
US : Human Kinetics
ISSN:
0273-5024 (Print)
1543-2769 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
physical education teachers, teacher candidates, cultural pluralism, teacher attitudes, diversity
Abstract:
The purpose of this study was to analyze both male and female physical education teacher attitudes toward cultural pluralism and diversity. Participants (N = 433) were adapted physical education specialists, physical education generalists, and teacher candidates. The research method was a descriptive cross-sectional survey (Fraenkel & Wallen, 1990). Data were collected using a modified version of the Pluralism and Diversity Attitude Assessment survey (Stanley, 1997). Mann-Whitney U tests showed no significant differences in attitude scores between teachers and teacher candidates. However, women’s attitude scores were significantly higher than men’s. Further Friedman's ANOVA test showed statistical differences on the survey’s constructs for gender and professional status. Post hoc analysis indicated that the groups scored significantly higher on the construct, Value Cultural Pluralism than Implement Cultural Pluralism. This means teachers generally valued cultural diversity, but struggled to implement culturally responsive pedagogy. In conclusion, physical educators may need better preparation to ensure cultural competence. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Diversity; *Multicultural Education; *Physical Education; *Teacher Attitudes; *Teachers; Cultural Sensitivity; Student Teachers
PsycINFO Classification:
Educational Administration & Personnel (3510)
Population:

Methodology:

Title:
Plural society and interethnic relations in Guinea-Bissau.
Authors:
Davidson, Joanna, Emory U, Atlanta, GA, US
Source:
Engaging cultural differences: The multicultural challenge in liberal democracies. Shweder, Richard A. (Ed); Minow, Martha (Ed); Markus, Hazel Rose (Ed); pp. 417-431; New York, NY, US: Russell Sage Foundation; 2002. xiv, 485 pp.
Page Count:
15
ISBN:
0-87154-791-0 (Hardcover)
Language:
English
Keywords:
interethnic relations, cultural differences, identity formation, cultural pluralism
Abstract:
Discusses the largely successful cultural pluralism that can be found in Guinea-Bissau. The country's major ethnic groups and their beliefs are described. It is concluded that the ethnographic and historical case of Guinea-Bissau opens up opportunities for inquiry into social boundary-making processes that might challenge deeply ingrained Western notions of identity formation and offer insights into nonconflictual processes of negotiating cultural differences. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (create)

Title:
Pluralism as a culture: Religion and civility in Southern California.

Roof, Wade Clark, Walter H. Capps Center for the Study of Ethics, Religion and Public Life, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA, US
Source:
Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science, Vol 612(1), Jul, 2007. pp. 82-99.
Page Count:
18
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0002-7162 (Print)
1552-3349 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
cultural pluralism, religion, civility, Southern California, society, religious pluralism
Abstract:
This article describes Southern California as a particular setting for the study of religious pluralism and civil society. The region's history of global religious and cultural encounters, lack of a religious establishment, hyper-modernity, and fluid identities have all contributed to "pluralism as a culture," or a style of intergroup interaction and cooperation characterized generally by openness and acceptance. Finally, the author discusses how this culture akin to what is sometimes called "rooted cosmopolitanism" and to core American values and democratic traditions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

*Community Involvement; *Religion; *Religious Groups; *Society; *Multiculturalism

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 108
Title:
Police in a plural society.
Authors:
Loree, Donald J., Canadian Police Coll, Ottawa
Source:
Canadian Police College Journal, Vol 9(4), 1985. pp. 391-412.
Page Count:
22
Publisher:
Canada : Canadian Police College Journal
ISSN:
0705-8810 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
cultural pluralism & impact on police, Canada
Abstract:
Discusses the concept, dimensions, and implications of pluralism as it relates to ethnicity, religion, language, age, sex, marital status, income and occupation, education, and political and organizational affiliations of the Canadian people. The impact of pluralism on the police is viewed as direct (when interest groups endeavor to influence police) and indirect (demographic changes that occur as the population shifts or ages). It is suggested that police must come to grips with their role in a diverse and changing society, which is affected by their generally conservative stance toward social change. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

*Police Personnel; *Social Change; *Sociocultural Factors

PsycINFO
Record: 109
Title:
Predicting school sense of community: Students’ perceptions at two Catholic universities.
Authors:
Bottom, Todd L., Department of Psychology, DePaul University, Chicago, IL, US
Ferrari, Joseph R., Department of Psychology, DePaul University, Chicago, IL, US, jferrari@depaul.edu
Matteo, Elizabeth, Department of Psychology and Counseling, Alvernia University, Reading, PA, US
Todd, Nathan R., Department of Psychology, DePaul University, Chicago, IL, US
Address:
Ferrari, Joseph R., Department of Psychology, DePaul University, 2219 North Kenmore Avenue, Chicago, IL, US, 60614, jferrari@depaul.edu
Source:
Journal of Prevention & Intervention in the Community, Vol 41(1), Jan, 2013. pp. 4-14.
Page Count:
11
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
Other Publishers:
US : Haworth Press
ISSN:
1085-2352 (Print)
1540-7330 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
sense of community, student perceptions, college students, higher education, cultural pluralism
Abstract:
Understanding the factors that predict sense of community (SOC) among college students has important implications for higher education policy and practice. The present study determined whether perceptions of inclusion and religious pluralism across 2,199 university students’ (1,442 women, 757 men; M age = 23.42, SD = 7.84) at two Catholic universities predicted levels of school sense of community (SSOC). As expected, results indicated that perceptions of both inclusion and religious pluralism significantly predicted SSOC. However, mixed results were found regarding the interaction of university setting with inclusion and religious pluralism. Limitations and future directions for research are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

*College Students; *Communities; *Higher Education; *Student Attitudes; *Multiculturalism

Title:
Preoccupied with process, annoyed with content.
Authors:
Sadler, John Z., U Texas, Southwestern Medical Ctr, Dept of Psychiatry, Dallas, TX, US, sadler@utsw.swmed.edu
Fulford, K. W. M., U Warwick, Dept of Philosophy & Mental Health, England
Address:
Sadler, John Z., Department of Psychiatry, UT Southwestern, 5323 Harry Hines Boulevard, Dallas, TX, US, 75390-9070, sadler@utsw.swmed.edu
Source:
Current Opinion in Psychiatry, Vol 16(6), Nov, 2003. pp. 659-660.
Page Count:
2
Publisher:
US : Lippincott Williams & Wilkins
ISSN:
0951-7367 (Print)
1473-6578 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
doctor-patient relationships, psychiatric trainees
Abstract:
Psychiatric trainees are often taught about the process/content distinction in working with patients, ordinarily conceived as the difference between how things are said (process) versus what is said (content) in doctor-patient relationships. The articles in this current set of reviews in Current Opinion--History and philosophy--suggest how far the process/content distinction has evolved in the past few decades and perhaps, more importantly, how the tension (creative or destructive) between the two has been compounded in a world increasingly characterized by an explosion of research findings, cultural pluralism, economic globalization, and continuous change. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 111
Title:
Preservice physical educators' attitudes toward cultural pluralism: A preliminary analysis.
Authors:
Stanley, Linda S., U British Columbia, Dept of Curriculum Studies, Vancouver, BC, Canada
Source:
Journal of Teaching in Physical Education, Vol 16(2), Jan, 1997. pp. 241-249.
Page Count:
9
Publisher:
US : Human Kinetics
ISSN:
0273-5024 (Print)
1543-2769 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
development of Pluralism & Diversity Attitude Assessment instrument, attitudes toward cultural diversity & pluralism, preservice physical education majors
Abstract:
Developed the Pluralism and Diversity Attitude Assessment (PADAA) instrument to assess attitudes toward cultural diversity and pluralism among preservice physical educators. 15 US universities were selected as test sites for validation. Five to 42 college students completed the PADAA at each institution; 215 responses were used for analysis. Results indicate that preservice physical educators may respect and value cultural diversity, but because scores decreased as the level of intensity of the scales increased, preservice students may be less likely to implement culturally sensitive teaching practices to meet the individual needs of all students. Findings suggest that teacher educators should work toward not only sensitizing prospective teachers to culturally diverse students, but need to guide and encourage these future educators in adopting and implementing educational programs that are responsive to cultural diversity. To accomplish this goal, it is recommended that teacher educators specifically provide opportunities for preservice students to implement pluralistic teaching practices. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Cultural Sensitivity; *Educational Measurement; *Physical Education; *Teacher Attitudes; Preservice Teachers
PsycINFO Classification:
Educational Measurement (2227)

Population:

PsycINFO
Record: 113
Title:
Racial/ethnic diversity in doctoral programs of psychology: Challenges for the twenty-first century.
Authors:
Highlen, Pamela S., Ohio State U, Dept of Psychology, Columbus, US
Source:
Applied & Preventive Psychology, Vol 3(2), Spr 1994. pp. 91-108.
Page Count:
18
Publisher:
Netherlands : Elsevier Science
ISSN:
0962-1849 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
racial & ethnic diversity & multicultural curriculum & cultural sensitivity in doctoral programs in psychology, response to changing demographic composition & cultural pluralism
Abstract:
Contends that changing demographics and accompanying cultural pluralism pose challenges to psychology departments in terms of multicultural curriculum, generation of culturally sensitive research and theory, and representation of racial/ethnic minority students and faculty. The impact of the European-American worldview as the foundation of the dominant culture is explored as it relates to psychology. Implicit and explicit examples of ethnocentrism, which reflect the imposition of the dominant culture on other cultures, are offered. Universal psychology is challenged for the 21st century as culture-bound and is subsequently viewed as nonexistent. Organizational and individual multicultural development models are advanced, along with specific strategies for how doctoral programs can embrace diversity through commitment to structural change and inclusion of paradigms that reflect alternate worldviews. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Cultural Sensitivity; *Diversity; *Graduate Psychology Education; *Multicultural Education; *Racial and Ethnic Relations

Title:
Rehabilitation counselor education programs' response to cultural pluralism.
Authors:
Dodd, John M., Eastern Montana Coll, US
Nelson, J. Ron
Ostwald, Steven W.
Fischer, Jerome M.
Source:
Journal of Applied Rehabilitation Counseling, Vol 22(1), Spr 1991. pp. 46-48.
Page Count:
3
Publisher:
US : NRCA
ISSN:
0047-2220 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
prevalence & characteristics of multicultural components of & cultural pluralism in rehabilitation counselor education programs
Abstract:
Conducted a survey of 28 postsecondary education programs that offer the master's degree in rehabilitation counseling to determine whether and how cultural pluralism is addressed. Most programs addressed cultural pluralism. The Black population was addressed most frequently followed by Hispanics. Native American and Pacific Islander populations were least frequently addressed separately. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 115
Title:
Research in multicultural societies: Implications of cross-cultural methods.
Authors:
Berry, John W., Queen's U, Kingston, Canada
Source:
Journal of Cross-Cultural Psychology, Vol 10(4), Dec, 1979. pp. 415-434.
Page Count:
20
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0022-0221 (Print)
1552-5422 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
transethnic research model, comparative studies of groups within culturally plural nation states
Abstract:
In recent years there has been a dramatic rise in the number of comparative studies of groups within culturally plural nation states. There are 2 models that may serve as frameworks for guiding such research—the unicultural and the cross-cultural. An argument is advanced that research in plural societies requires a new model, one that draws primarily upon the cross-cultural model, reflecting an ideology of cultural pluralism, so that the independence and uniqueness of each group in the comparison may be respected. A transethnic model is proposed for conducting comparative studies of ethunits in polyethnic societies. Guidelines for assessing issues of comparability, group independence, and the number of groups in the comparison and their cultural characteristics are discussed. (29 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Cross Cultural Differences; *Methodology; *Racial and Ethnic Groups
PsycINFO Classification:
Research Methods & Experimental Design (2260)

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 116
Title:
Review of Studies in English to speakers of other languages and standard English to speakers of a non-standard dialect.
Authors:
Arthur, Bradford, University of California at Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, US
Source:
Language Learning, Vol 22(1), Jun, 1972. pp. 143-146.
Page Count:
4
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Blackwell Publishing
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
Reviewed Item:
Jacobson, Rodolfo (Ed). (1971) Studies in English to speakers of other languages and standard English to speakers of a non-standard dialect The English Record Vol. XXI, No. 4. vi + 185 pp. Also published as New York State English Council Monograph 14
ISSN:
0023-8333 (Print)
1467-9922 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
non-standard dialect, minority groups, language norms, linguists, teachers
Abstract:
Reviews the book, Studies in English to Speakers of Other Languages and Standard English to Speakers of a Non-Standard Dialect edited by Rodolfo Jacobson (1971). The book is intended to encourage on the part of classroom English teachers an acceptance of cultural pluralism recognition of the value of the cultural and linguistic backgrounds of minority-group students. Much of the writing on the education of Black children emphasizes the differences and contrasts between standard and Black English. Such writing frequently concludes that English textbooks basic readers and spellers in particular-should be redesigned to build from the language norms students bring to the school setting. A somewhat different view is presented by the author who reports a study of the speech of five Black children. The children he studied used a mixture of non-standard and standard dialect variants. Unmarked plural and possessive, for example, were less frequent than the marked, standard variants. In the decade ahead, applied linguists may be called upon to help classroom teachers recognize and teach those children whose language norms are neither identical with nor totally different from the standard, school norms. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Dialect; *Linguistics; *Minority Groups; *Nonstandard English; Teachers
PsycINFO Classification:
Curriculum & Programs & Teaching Methods (3530)
Population:
Human
Format Covered:
Electronic

Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2013-21738-013&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Review of Studies in English to speakers of other languages and standard English to speakers of a non-standard dialect.</A>
Database:

Title:
Review of Business and politics in Britain.
Authors:
Flynn, Norman, London Business School, London, United Kingdom
Source:
The Sociological Review, Vol 36(4), Nov, 1988. pp. 854-856.
Page Count:
3
Publisher:

US : Sherratt Hughes

United Kingdom : University College of North Staffordshire

Reviewed Item:
Grant, Wyn; Sargent, Jane. (1987) Business and politics in Britain Macmillan, Basingstoke, £7.95, xii + 279pp
ISSN:
0038-0261 (Print)
1467-954X (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
business, politics, Britain, government, cultural pluralism
Abstract:
Reviews the book, Business and Politics in Britain by Wyn Grant and Jane Sargent (1987). This book, written before the 1987 General Election, is about the way business influences government in Britain with an additional chapter about business representation in the EEC. The book's thesis is that business is not well organized collectively, nor is government well placed to deal with business and therefore the government acts in ways which are contrary to the interests of business. The framework within which the analysis is conducted is essentially a pluralist one where the categories 'government' and 'business' are distinct and are the main units of analysis and the method is an empiricist account of how institutions operate. The discussion on methodology, which includes pluralism, corporatism and 'privileged interest' as alternative approaches, concludes that they in fact converge. The book is a useful descriptive account of the institutional links between various parts of business and government. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Business; *Government; *Politics; *Multiculturalism

Title:
Review of Cultural globalization and language education.
Authors:
Kinberg, Margot, Department of Teacher Education, National University, San Diego, CA, US, mkinberg@nu.edu
Address:
Kinberg, Margot, mkinberg@nu.edu
Source:
International Journal of Bilingual Education and Bilingualism, Vol 12(6), Nov, 2009. pp. 734-737.
Page Count:
4
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Multilingual Matters
Reviewed Item:
Kumaravadivelu, B. (No Year Specified) Cultural globalization and language education New Haven, CT, Yale University Press, xiii +272 pp., $45.00 9780300111101 (Paperback).
ISSN:
1367-0050 (Print)
1747-7522 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
cultural globalization, language education, multiculturalism
Abstract:
Reviews the book, Cultural globalization and language education, by B. Kumaravadivelu. The book begins with a brief account of the author’s own biculturalism. He uses this context to present three models of multiculturalism: the assimilationist model, the cultural pluralism model, and the hybrid model. Throughout the book, the author uses insights from a wide range of disciplines and perspectives, and a variety of languages, integrating his own experiences and those of others. In this way, the author models in his presentation of the topic what he hopes for in language education. The book integrates both theoretical and practical discussions of the nature of culture and language, and uses both to offer a new way of thinking about language teaching. In his discussion of cultural globalization and language teaching, the author does more than just criticize what is. He proposes what could be. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Title:
Review of Linguistic minorities in democratic context.
Authors:
Valdez, Maria Luz, Modern Languages, Salisbury University, Salisbury, MD, US, mlvaldez@salisbury.edu
Address:
Valdez, Maria Luz, Modern Languages, Salisbury University, Salisbury, MD, US, 21801, mlvaldez@salisbury.edu
Source:
Language in Society, Vol 39(2), Apr, 2010. pp. 298-299.
Page Count:
2
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Cambridge University Press
Reviewed Item:
Williams, Colin H. (2008) Linguistic minorities in democratic context New York: Palgrave Macmillan. Pp. x, 440. £58
ISSN:
0047-4045 (Print)
1469-8013 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
linguistics, cultural minorities, democracy
Abstract:
Reviews the book Linguistic minorities in democratic context by Colin H. Williams (2008). From the perspective of democratic theory and practice, the author presents an analysis of the participation of cultural minorities in European states. The sociopolitical context of each state and the minorities' relationships to their respective states are presented to make the argument that linguistic policy is part of public policy, and that the design and implementation of language policies needs to be cognizant of this context. The lack of correspondence between the formal political system and different cultural identities within it, as well as attempts to maintain linguistic diversity as opposed to linguistic standardization, provide a contradiction within which other grievances may be mobilized. Attention to data collection, language legislation, and management of language diversity is required for the formulation of public policies that reflect cultural pluralism and equality and that allow for democracy and freedom of action in a multicultural world order. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

*Democracy; *Linguistics; *Minority Groups; Culture (Anthropological)

The 10 papers in this book address the sociolinguistically interesting and--politically important topic of cultural pluralism. Whether or not the political positions taken in this book appeal to the reader, its careful analyses of the experiences of linguistic minorities must be considered valuable. Title:
Review of Muslim American youth: Understanding hyphenated identities through multiple methods (qualitative studies in psychology).
Authors:
Mir, Shabana, Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, OK, US
Source:
Anthropology & Education Quarterly, Vol 41(4), Dec, 2010. pp. 395-397.
Page Count:
3
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
Other Journal Titles:
Council on Anthropology and Education Newsletter; Council on Anthropology and Education Quarterly
Other Publishers:
US : University of California Press
Reviewed Item:
Sirin, Selcuk; Fine, Michelle. (2008) Muslim American youth: Understanding hyphenated identities through multiple methods (qualitative studies in psychology) New York: New York University Press, 243 pp
ISSN:
0161-7761 (Print)
1548-1492 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Muslim Americans, immigrants, anthropology, sociology, cultural studies, demographic characteristics, cultural pluralism, psychology
Abstract:
Reviews the book, Muslim American youth: Understanding hyphenated identities through multiple methods (qualitative studies in psychology) by Selcuk Sirin and Michelle Fine (see record 2008-09997-000). In this book, the authors use multiple research methods, surveys, interviews, focus groups, and life history interviews, to investigate the psychosocial implications of young Muslims’ resistance, resilience, and post-9/11 identity negotiation. Seeking to "stand with youth under siege" , the authors of this timely, insightful, and enjoyable book examine young Muslims’ strategies and resilience in responding to the aftermath of 9/11. Addressing a mainly non-Muslim readership and skillfully coping with the dearth of empirical research on Muslim youth, the authors build on existing work on immigrants, youth identity, moral exclusion, and social justice. This book, readable and wide-ranging as it is, could have been strengthened by a higher level of familiarity with U.S. Muslims. In situating Muslim identities temporally, for example, 9/11 is overemphasized to the neglect of pre-9/11 events like the Iranian revolution, the Gulf War, and the rival growth of Islamism and Sufism in North America, to name a few. This text addresses academic readers in psychology, anthropology, sociology, education, cultural studies, and lay readers with an interest in Muslim Americans, the study of demographics, citizenship, and pluralism. The "identity maps," pictures drawn by Muslim youth to represent their identities, which are scattered throughout the book, convey the thesis in a more immediate fashion. I would recommend it highly for undergraduate and beginning graduate students, and certainly for all readers interested in Muslim Americans, contemporary Islamic trends in the United States, and the post-9/11 political climate. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

Title:
Review of One Nation Many Voices.
Authors:
Ornstein, Eric, Jane Addams College of Social Work, University of Illinois at Chicago, Chicago, IL, US
Moses, Helene, Jane Addams College of Social Work, University of Illinois at Chicago, Chicago, IL, US
Source:
School Social Work Journal, Vol 30(1), Fal 2005. pp. 87-89.
Page Count:
3
Publisher:
US : Lyceum Books
Reviewed Item:
Author, No. (2004) One Nation Many Voices Northeastern Wisconsin In-School Telecommunications (NEWIST), 2004
ISSN:
0161-5653 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
cultural pluralism, bilingual education, language, ethnic heritage, school program
Abstract:
Reviews the video, One Nation Many Voices by E. Ornstein and H. Moses (2004). This 56-minute video with accompanying guidebook, tells the story of the Brown County Diversity Resolution or the "English Only Law." The video makes the point that for many ethnic communities, there is a danger that their cultural heritage will be lost if fewer and fewer members of the next generation speak the language. The current trend is toward cultural pluralism where individuals can embrace certain American customs while maintaining a strong sense of their ethnic and cultural identity. The video illustrates this trend by highlighting a school program in Brown County, where Anglo and Latino students are learning Spanish and English simultaneously and where on alternating days one language is dominant. The video and guidebook are useful for school social workers, teachers, and administrators. The video also addresses the complex issues around loss of language, identity, and cultural connections. The video's narrative focus reflects a postmodern sensibility, which emphasizes the cultural context and the uniqueness of each individual's ethnic heritage. Overall, we found this to be a provocative and interesting video that encouraged us to examine our own biases and feelings about issues such as the immigrant experience, cultural pluralism, language, and bilingual education. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Title:
Review of Telling stories in two languages: Multiple approaches to understanding English-Japanese bilingual children's narratives.
Authors:
Sakurai, Shogo, School of Languages and Cultures, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN, US, ssakurai@purdue.edu
Address:
Sakurai, Shogo, ssakurai@purdue.edu
Source:
International Journal of Bilingual Education and Bilingualism, Vol 15(5), Sep, 2012. pp. 617-621.
Page Count:
5
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Multilingual Matters
Reviewed Item:
Minami, Masahiko. (2011) Telling stories in two languages: Multiple approaches to understanding English-Japanese bilingual children's narratives Charlotte, Information Age Publishing, xiii 234 pp., $85.99 978-1-61735-355-0 (Hardcover); 978-1-61735-354-3 (Paperback).
ISSN:
1367-0050 (Print)
1747-7522 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
story telling, languages, English-Japanese bilingual children, narratives, literacy development
Abstract:
Reviews the book, Telling Stories in Two Languages: Multiple Approaches to Understanding English-Japanese Bilingual Children's Narratives by Masahiko Minami (see record 2011-09579-000). One of the most significant endeavors for children with respect to language and literacy development is to improve narrative ability. How this narrative ability is developed by bilingual children has not been extensively explored. Therefore, this book is a welcomed addition to the field of bilingualism not only for interested researchers but also for parents and school teachers/administrators in order to understand how narrative abilities are developed in two separate languages by bilingual children. The book consists of a compilation of several narrative studies conducted with the same 40 English-Japanese children (aged 6-12 years) living in San Francisco. Using the same narrative data, each chapter analyzes different aspects of the narratives to investigate both their universal and language-specific characteristics. The book is divided into nine chapters. The author takes an invariable position throughout the book; bilingualism is an asset which the education system needs to value in order to nurture the linguistic and cultural pluralism these children bring to school. Overall, in spite of a few minor editing errors, the book does provide the reader with invaluable resources such as complete references, subject index, and author index. This book is a great addition to the field of bilingualism research. Both researchers whose scholarship lies on narrative development of bilingual children and parents and school teachers/administrators who are concerned with bilingual children’s language and literacy development can benefit tremendously from the series of research presented in this book. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

Record: 124
Title:
School environment and the mental health of sexual minority youths: A study among Dutch young adolescents.
Authors:
Sandfort, Theo G. M., HIV Center for Clinical and Behavioral Studies, New York State Psychiatric Institute, New York, NY, US, tgs2001@columbia.edu
Bos, Henny M. W., Department of Education, Faculty of Social and Behavioural Sciences, University of Amsterdam, Amsterdam, Netherlands
Collier, Kate L., HIV Center for Clinical and Behavioral Studies, New York State Psychiatric Institute, New York, NY, US
Metselaar, Marijke, Department of Education, Faculty of Social and Behavioural Sciences, University of Amsterdam, Amsterdam, Netherlands
Address:
Sandfort, Theo G. M., HIV Center for Clinical and Behavioral Studies, New York State Psychiatric Institute, 1051 Riverside Dr, PI Unit 15, New York, NY, US, 10032, tgs2001@columbia.edu
Source:
American Journal of Public Health, Vol 100(9), Sep 1, 2010. pp. 1696-1700.
Page Count:
5
Publisher:
US : American Public Health Assn
ISSN:
0090-0036 (Print)
1541-0048 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
school environment, mental health, sexual minority youths, adolescents, school rules, gay, lesbian, same-sex attraction, cultural pluralism
Abstract:
Objectives: We examined whether structural elements of the school environment, in particular cultural pluralism and consistency and clarity of school rules and expectations of students, could mitigate the risk for mental health problems among young sexual minority adolescents. Methods: Data were collected in 2008 by means of a computer-based questionnaire completed at school by 513 young Dutch adolescents (12–15 years old) during regular class times. Eleven percent of these students, who were enrolled in 8 different schools, reported having at least some feelings of same-sex attraction. Results: Adolescents with same-sex attractions in schools where rules and expectations were experienced as less consistent and clear reported significantly more mental health problems than their peers with no same-sex attractions in the same schools. Such differences were absent in schools where rules and expectations were experienced as more consistent and clear. There were no such effects of cultural pluralism. Conclusions: Our results suggest that schools with consistent and clear rules and expectations mitigate the risk for mental health problems among students with same-sex attractions and underscore the importance of structural measures for the health of sexual minority youth. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Mental Health; *Minority Groups; *School Environment; *Sexual Orientation; Lesbianism; Male Homosexuality; Multiculturalism
PsycINFO Classification:
Classroom Dynamics & Student Adjustment & Attitudes (3560)
Population:
Human
Male
Female
Location:
Netherlands
Age Group:
Adolescence (13-17 yrs)
Tests & Measures:
Inventory of School Climate-Student Version
Social Desirability Scale
Grant Sponsorship:
Sponsor: National Institute of Mental Health, US
Grant Number: P30-MH43520
Other Details: HIV Center for Clinical and Behavioral Studies, New York State Psychiatric Institute and Columbia University
Recipients: Ehrhardt, A. A. (Prin Inv)
Methodology:
Empirical Study; Quantitative Study
Format Covered:
Electronic
Publication Type:
Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal
Document Type:
Journal Article
Publication History:
Accepted: Apr 15, 2010
Release Date:
20110214
Digital Object Identifier:
http://dx.doi.org.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/10.2105/AJPH.2009.183095
PMID:
20634453
Accession Number:
2010-25205-013
Number of Citations in Source:
26
UR:
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2010-25205-013&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2010-25205-013&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2010-25205-013&site=ehost-live&scope=site">School environment and the mental health of sexual minority youths: A study among Dutch young adolescents.</A>
Database:
PsycINFO
Section:
RESEARCH AND PRACTICE

School Environment and the Mental Health of Sexual Minority Youths: A Study Among Dutch Young Adolescents 

Objectives. We examined whether structural elements of the school environment, in particular cultural pluralism and consistency and clarity of school rules and expectations of students, could mitigate the risk for mental health problems among young sexual minority adolescents.

Methods. Data were collected in 2008 by means of a computer-based questionnaire completed at school by 513 young Dutch adolescents (12-15 years old) during regular class times. Eleven percent of these students, who were enrolled in 8 different schools, reported having at least some feelings of same-sex attraction.

Results. Adolescents with same-sex attractions in schools where rules and expectations were experienced as less consistent and clear reported significantly more mental health problems than their peers with no same-sex attractions in the same schools. Such differences were absent in schools where rules and expectations were experienced as more consistent and clear. There were no such effects of cultural pluralism.

Conclusions. Our results suggest that schools with consistent and clear rules and expectations mitigate the risk for mental health problems among students with same-sex attractions and underscore the importance of structural measures for the health of sexual minority youth. (Am J Public Health. 2010;100:1696-1700. doi:10.2105/AJPH.2009.183095)

Shocking reports appear in the press with some regularity about the bullying of adolescents who are gay or lesbian or who are perceived as such, sometimes resulting in suicide attempts and even actual suicides.[ 1-3] Such reports draw attention to the role of schools: what can schools do to protect sexual minority youths?

Studies conducted in various countries have shown that sexual minority youths are at disproportionate risk for several negative health outcomes, including victimization, witnessing and perpetrating violence, substance use, sexual risk behaviors, and suicide ideation and attempts.[ 4-9] A recent Dutch study of younger adolescents (13- to 15-year-olds) showed that those experiencing same-sex attractions had significantly higher levels of depression and lower self-esteem than did their peers not experiencing same-sex attractions.[ 10]

Sexual minority youths come of age in a society that is often hostile to their interests and needs. Increased health problems in these youths are usually understood as a consequence of discrimination by peers and family. Victimization in high school has been shown to be positively associated with mental health and traumatic stress symptoms in sexual minority youths.[ 11] In a survey of Illinois middle school students, being the target of homophobic verbal harassment was associated with higher levels of anxiety and depression, personal distress, and a lower sense of school belonging among boys and higher levels of withdrawal among girls.12

Homophobic bullying by classmates can start at an early age, as suggested by the April 2009 suicides of 2 boys, both 11 years old, in Massachusetts and Georgia, each bullied at school for being perceived as gay.[ 1][ 2] In a study involving a community-based sample of self-identified lesbian, gay, and bisexual youths (aged 15-19 years) who were interviewed about their lifetime experiences of sexual orientation victimization, the mean ages at which verbal victimization began were 11.4 years for male participants and 14.4 years for female participants.[ 13] The corresponding mean ages at which physical victimization began were 13.1 years and 14.2 years.[ 13] School was reported as the setting for 72% of first experiences with verbal victimization and 56% of first experiences with physical victimization.[ 13]

A few studies suggest that structural factors may affect how young people feel at school. In one investigation, students who reported having a Gay-Straight Alliance (GSA) at school, knowing where to go for information and support related to sexual orientation and gender identity, and having lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender (LGBT) issues included in their school curriculum were more likely to report feeling safe at school than were those who did not have these resources.[ 14]

Another study showed that sexual minority students in schools that have a comprehensive harassment policy (i.e., specifying sexual orientation or gender identity and expression) are less frequently verbally harassed and hear fewer homophobic remarks than students in schools with no policy or a policy not specifically inclusive of LGBT people; students reported that school personnel were also more likely to intervene upon hearing homophobic remarks in these schools.[ 15] Feeling safe at school seems to be a protective factor for sexual minority youths. In one study, feeling safe at school attenuated the association between sexual orientation and suicidal ideation and attempts.[ 16]

Further support for the importance of structural factors comes from a cross-sectional study that compared rates of victimization and suicidality among sexual minority adolescents in schools with and without GSAs and other school programs.[ 17] Using data from the Massachusetts Youth Risk Behavior Survey and controlling for student demographic characteristics and school characteristics, Goodenow et al. showed that sexual minority youths in Massachusetts schools with GSAs were less than half as likely as those in other schools to report dating violence, being threatened or injured at school, or skipping school as a result of fear; in addition, they were less than one third as likely to report multiple suicide attempts in the past year.

Goodenow et al. also found that peer support groups other than GSAs, nonacademic counseling, school antibullying policies, a student judiciary, staff training on sexual harassment, and peer tutoring systems were associated with lower rates of victimization and suicidality among sexual minority students. Sexual minority youths from schools where there was a perception that school staff could be approached about a problem were less likely to report multiple suicide attempts, and those from schools where antibullying policies were in place were less likely to report single or multiple suicide attempts.

Building on existing knowledge, we explored whether a protective school climate offsets negative health outcomes among young adolescents. In particular, we hypothesized that when schools support cultural pluralism and have consistent and clear rules and expectations, the relationship between same-sex attraction and mental health will be attenuated.

METHODS

Data were collected in 2008 at 8 secondary schools in Amsterdam, the Netherlands. These schools are members of the VIOS (Veiligheid In en Om School, or Safety In and Around School) initiative and were approached through the initiative. VIOS is a network of 72 secondary schools in Amsterdam exploring ways to improve safety in and around the school environment for students in general. Schools participating in the study differed in their general orientation (prevocational, general, and preacademic). In total, 518 high school students took part in the study. Only students in years 1, 2, and 3 (age range: 12-15 years) were invited to participate.

Procedure

To obtain consent from parents, the board of each school sent a letter to all parents containing information about the date and purpose (school safety and students with same-sex attractions) of the study. The letter made clear to parents that students' participation in the study was voluntary. If parents did not want their child to participate, they could indicate this by returning the letter. Seven parents refused to allow their child to participate.

Data were gathered during regular class times by means of a questionnaire administered via a computer (or, in the few cases in which computers were not available, on paper) in the presence of one of the authors (Marijke Metselaar) and one of the respective school's instructors. Students were reminded of the voluntary nature and confidentiality of their participation. Seating in the classrooms was arranged as if students were taking an individual exam; this arrangement, meant to prevent cheating, created sufficient privacy.

Measures

Sexual attraction was assessed with the question "Do you feel sexually attracted to someone of your own sex?" (l=very often, 5=never), which has been used successfully in previous research on homosexual youths in the Netherlands.[ 10][ 18] Participants who reported never having been attracted to someone of the same sex were grouped in the no same-sex attraction category, and those who felt "very often," "often," "frequently," or "sometimes" sexually attracted to someone of the same sex were grouped in the same-sex attraction category.

Mental health was assessed with items from a shortened version of the Brief Symptom Inventory[ 18-20] asking about the occurrence of 24 symptoms in the preceding week. Items were rated on a 5-point scale ranging from 1 (not at all) to 5 (extremely; a=0.93), and mean scores were used as an overall indicator of mental health problems.

We used 2 subscales from the student version of the Inventory of School Climate[ 21] to assess support for cultural pluralism (e.g., 'Tour teachers show that they think it is important for students of different races and cultures at your school to get along with each other") and consistency and clarity of rules and expectations (e.g., "Students understand what will happen to them if they break a rule"); each subscale consisted of 4 items. Internal consistencies were 0.63 and 0.84, respectively.

To explore whether participants' ratings of support for cultural pluralism and consistency and clarity of rules at their schools were a reflection of actual differences between schools or were due to random variation, we conducted univariate analyses of covariance with schools as the independent factor, participants' ratings of school climate as dependent variables, and gender, age, ethnicity, and social desirability as covariates to control for between-subject differences related to perceptions of school climate. These analyses indicated significant differences between schools (cultural pluralism: F7, 467=3.00; P<.01; n2=0.04; consistency and clarity of rules: F7, 467=4.07; P<.001; n2 = 0.06). Inspection of the schools' mean scores indicated that these results were not the effect of 1 or 2 outliers; the schools' mean scores were evenly distributed. In summary, the assessment of school climate based on students' self-reports suggests that the participants' scores reflected real differences between schools.

We used a social desirability scale with a true-false response format to assess participants' tendency to provide socially desirable responses.[ 22] The internal consistency of this scale was 0.86. A similar measure of social desirability has been used elsewhere with LGB youth.[ 23]

Data Analysis

Multiple regression analyses were conducted to test the hypothesis that school culture has a moderating effect on the relationship between same-sex attraction and mental health. Only participants with valid data on all relevant variables were included in the analyses; missing data primarily resulted from girls with no same-sex attractions for whom no mental health scores were available. Independent variables were gender, same-sex attraction, support for cultural pluralism, and consistency and clarity of rules and expectations, along with the interactions of same-sex attraction with gender, support for cultural pluralism, and consistency and clarity of rules. Age and social desirability were included as control variables. All analyses were conducted with SPSS version 16.0 (SPSS Inc, Chicago, IL).

RESULTS

Of the 518 participants, 513 (99.0%) reported whether or not they had experienced same-sex attraction (the 5 participants who did not answer this question were excluded from subsequent analyses). Approximately 11% (n=57) of these 513 adolescents reported having experienced same-sex attraction. Same-sex attraction was not significantly more prevalent among boys or girls: 24 of the 222 boys (10.8%) and 33 of the 291 girls (11.3%) reported feelings of same-sex attraction (x2 = 0.04; P>.05).

Demographic characteristics of the sample are shown in Table 1. The average age was 14.02 years (SD=1.07). The ethnic composition of the sample was 55.7% Dutch and 44.3% non-Dutch. Of the participants with a non-Dutch ethnic background, 23.9% were Surinamese, 19.1% were Moroccan, 15.1% were Turkish, and 5.2% were Antillean; ethnic background was not specified for the remaining 36.7% of the non-Dutch sample. More than one third (37.6%) of the participants attended prevocational secondary schools, and 62.4% attended general secondary or preacademic schools. Twenty-nine percent of the participants were first-year students, 30.8% were second-year students, and 40.4% were third-year students.

Same-sex attraction was related to age: participants who reported same-sex attractions were older than those who did not. No significant differences were found in the percentages of participants with same-sex attractions in relation to ethnic background or type of school.

As can be seen in Table 2, gender and sexual attraction were significantly related to mental health. Girls reported more symptoms than boys; adolescents with feelings of same-sex attraction reported more symptoms than did adolescents without feelings of same-sex attraction.

There was a main effect of support for cultural pluralism on mental health, with students experiencing more support in their school for cultural pluralism reporting lower levels of symptoms (Table 2). The same main effect was found for consistency and clarity of rules, with differences in the same direction.

We also found a significant effect of the interaction between same-sex attraction and consistency and clarity of rules and expectations on mental health. To interpret this interaction effect, we performed a median split on consistency and clarity of rules and expectations (median=3.60). Adolescents with same-sex attractions in schools with low scores on the consistent and clear rules and expectations scale reported significantly more mental health problems than did their peers with no same-sex attractions in the same schools (same-sex attraction: mean=2.35; SD=1.04; no same-sex attraction: mean=1.71; SD=0.58; F1, 259 = 27.31; P=.001; n2 = .10; controlled for social desirability and age). We did not find such differences between adolescents with and without same-sex attraction in schools that were rated more highly with regard to consistent and clear rules and expectations (same-sex attraction: mean=1.77; SD=0.78; no same-sex attraction: mean=1.63; SD=0.66; F1,203 = 0.80; P=.37; n2 = .00; controlled for social desirability and age).

DISCUSSION

Our findings suggest that schools where rules and expectations are consistent and clear offset the risk of mental health problems among youths with same-sex attractions. As hypothesized, in the schools identified as having more consistent and clear rules and expectations, adolescents with and without same-sex attraction did not differ in terms of their mental health status. We did find such differences in schools characterized by less consistent and clear rules and expectations; in these schools, adolescents with same-sex attractions reported more mental health problems than adolescents without such attractions.

We did not find support for our hypothesis that support for cultural pluralism at schools would have the same protective effect on adolescents with same-sex attractions. Regardless of feelings of same-sex attraction, support for cultural pluralism and consistency and clarity of rules were both independently related to students' mental health status. Consistent with prior research, adolescents experiencing same-sex attractions in our sample reported more mental health problems than those without experiencing such feelings; also, girls reported more mental health problems than did boys.

Our results are also consistent with research suggesting the protective benefits of school policies and programs that affirm and support sexual minority youths. Much of this research, however, has focused on policies or programs, such as harassment policies or GSAs, that are designed with sexual minority youths in mind and from which self-identified LGB youths may derive different benefits than might those who are not openly LGB. We assessed school climate in a broader way, and our findings suggest that an environment in which diversity is respected more generally and in which rules are clear and fairly applied will benefit adolescents with as well as without same-sex attractions.

We used a measure of school climate that is, to our knowledge, unique in the literature on sexual minority youths. Past research has focused on documenting the school experiences of sexual minority youths or linking individual self-reports of victimization at school to mental health outcomes and risk behaviors. Other studies have examined how school policies are correlated with harassment of sexual minority students[ 24] and how social support moderates school performance in sexual minority youths.[ 25] By surveying samples of students from 8 different schools and testing for climate differences between the schools, we were able to link climate differences to different outcomes for youths with same-sex attractions in these schools.

This study involved several limitations. For example, our operationalization of same-sex sexuality may have resulted in a diverse group of sexual minority students, some of whom may not have identified as gay or lesbian at the time of the study (and perhaps never will) and some of whom may have been more attracted to members of the opposite sex than to those of the same sex. Given the age of the adolescents who took part in our study, we believed that our operationalization was the most appropriate. We expect, however, that using this operationalization limited our chances of finding significant differences. Furthermore, our operationalization of school climate was based not on direct observations but on reports of the participants; the fact that between-school variance was significant, however, supports our interpretation that these self-reports reflected actual differences between schools.

In addition, our study design did not allow for causal statements; although we believe that it is more plausible that perceptions of school climate affect mental health, we cannot rule out the possibility that positive mental health results in a more optimistic evaluation of school climate. The latter interpretation cannot, however, explain the interaction effect of school climate and same-sex attraction on mental health. Finally, the schools that participated in the study were not randomly selected and do not represent all secondary schools in the Netherlands. The relative homogeneity of the schools in this study (i.e., they were all located in Amsterdam and were part of the VIOS initiative) makes the finding of an interaction effect even more compelling. It is, however, unclear whether the same interaction effect would be found for schools that are likely to be more conservative, such as schools in parts of the Netherlands other than Amsterdam or in other countries.

Our findings strongly suggest that, as indicated by others,[ 26] it is of crucial importance to explore how structural factors contribute to health disparities in relation to sexual orientation or how such factors might mitigate these disparities. Furthermore, our findings suggest that although policies focused on adolescents with same-sex attractions might be helpful, these youths might profit from more general measures as well, the same measures that support youths without same-sex attractions.

Title:
Sémantique, analyse et culture.
Translated Title:
Semantics, analysis and culture.
Authors:
Bril, Jacques
Source:
Revue Française de Psychanalyse, Vol 57(3), Jul-Sep, 1993. pp. 891-898.
Page Count:
8
Publisher:
France : Presses Universitaires de France
ISSN:
0035-2942 (Print)
Language:
French
Keywords:
semantics & cultural factors in psychoanalysis, analysands
Abstract:
Notes that anthropological thought generated by the cultural pluralism of the environment appears to nourish psychoanalytic thought in its wake. The analytic situation is an example of the interaction of 2 different cultures. Access to interpretation of the meaning of the patient's discourse transcends the simple decoding of a linguistic message; it implies the sharing by the 2 participants of prelinguistic semantic elements. This action exposes interpretation to the risks that may result from a countertransferential privilege accorded by the analyst to the manifest but deceptive character of same-culture-type of the situation. This theme is illustrated by 2 clinical examples (a same-culture and a different-culture S). (English, German, Spanish & Italian abstracts) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Title:
September 11th 2001: Some thoughts on racism and religious prejudice as an obstacle.
Authors:
Davids, Fakhry, fakhry@bigfoot.com
Address:
Davids, Fakhry, 4 Primrose Gardens, London, England, NW3 4TJ, fakhry@bigfoot.com
Source:
British Journal of Psychotherapy, Vol 18(3), Spr 2002. pp. 361-366.
Page Count:

Publisher:

ISSN:
0265-9883 (Print)
1752-0118 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
September 11th, racism, religious prejudice, religion, culture, world view, psychoanalysis
Abstract:
In a psychoanalytic interpretation, the article explores the strand of thinking stimulated by the events of September 11th and how racism and religious prejudice are seen as an obstacle. Today we live in a global village, and the twin towers may have been a most potent symbol of humankind's progress in sharing a basic humanity in a way that supports each to grow and develop in their own way. However, this description is of life in the metropolitan West, where progress towards cultural pluralism has gone remarkably smoothly. Cities today are increasingly multi-cultural and tolerant, and sometimes proud of it. The author wonders have the privileged few, in global terms, achieved this by projecting the uncertainties and anxieties connected with ordinary human frailty into excluded groups around the world, whose lives then become less precious than our own. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

Title:

Record: 128
Title:
Situating social attitudes toward cultural pluralism: Between culture wars and contemporary racism.
Authors:
Downey, Dennis J., U California, Irvine, CA, US
Source:
Social Problems, Vol 47(1), Feb, 2000. pp. 90-111.
Page Count:
22
Publisher:
US : University of California Press
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Oxford University Press
ISSN:
0037-7791 (Print)
1533-8533 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
social attitudes toward cultural pluralism & socio-political & symbolic conflicts & culture wars & contemporary racism
Abstract:
This research situates attitudes toward cultural pluralism between 2 bodies of research on socio-political conflicts with a symbolic emphasis: one addressing the culture wars and the other addressing contemporary racial attitudes. Analysis uses data from the 1994 General Social Survey (GSS) "multicultural module" to test a range of discrete claims emerging from each perspective in several thematic areas: attitudinal distribution/polarization, patterns of support/opposition and issue salience, political alignment and crystallization, and the attitudinal gap between principles and policy implementation. A recurring pattern in the data is the association of central theoretical variables with attitudinal extremity rather than (or in addition to) an association with support for or opposition to pluralism. Discussion links that pattern to the symbolic character of conflicts over pluralism and suggests how it impacts both the understanding of cultural pluralism and of symbolic conflicts. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved)

*Attitudes; *Politics; *Racism; *Social Issues; *Multiculturalism; Racial and Ethnic Relations; Symbolism

Record: 129
Title:
So far and yet so near? Community psychology in Australia.
Authors:
Gridley, Heather, Victoria University, Melbourne, Australia
Breen, Lauren J.
Source:
International community psychology: History and theories. Reich, Stephanie M. (Ed); Riemer, Manuel (Ed); Prilleltensky, Isaac (Ed); Montero, Maritza (Ed); pp. 119-139; New York, NY, US: Springer Science + Business Media; 2007. xxv, 443 pp.
Page Count:
21
ISBN:
978-0-387-49499-9 (Hardcover)
978-0-387-49500-2 (PDF)
Language:
English
Keywords:
community psychology, Australia, history
Abstract:
Australian community psychology (CP) has a shared history as well as regional variations, resulting in an eclectic mix of ideas, methodologies, and practices. In this chapter, we review the emergence of CP in Australia from within the dominant paradigm to its official recognition as a subdiscipline of psychology and the development of postgraduate programs. CP's formal history in Australia has links with the parallel, recent history of the subdiscipline elsewhere, particularly in the United States; informally, the climate in which it was born was distinctly Australian, resonating with the cultural pluralism and emergent debates around decolonisation and political realignment within the Asia-Pacific region that characterised the 1970s in this country. In this chapter, we critically examine a number of aspects of that history: the impact of the decision to locate the subdiscipline as a professional specialisation; the role of community psychologists in consciousness-raising around social justice within psychology and society; and the importance of geography in determining the nature of CP theorising and applications in this part of the world. We draw on the responses from a survey of 25 CP academics, practitioners, and students in order to personalise the emergence and subsequent development of CP in Australia. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Community Psychology; *History of Psychology
PsycINFO Classification:
History & Systems (2140)

<A href="https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2007-02843-005&site=ehost-live&scope=site">So far and yet so near? Community psychology in Australia.</A>
