Record: 130
Title:
Social representations of national identity in culturally diverse societies.
Parent Book Series:
Cambridge handbooks in psychology
Authors:
Andreouli, Eleni, Open University, Milton Keynes, England
Chryssochoou, Xenia, Panteion University, Greece
Source:
The Cambridge handbook of social representations. Sammut, Gordon (Ed); Andreouli, Eleni (Ed); Gaskell, George (Ed); Valsiner, Jaan (Ed); pp. 309-322; New York, NY, US: Cambridge University Press; 2015. xv, 481 pp.
Page Count:
14
ISBN:
978-1-107-04200-1 (Hardcover)
978-1-316-30900-1 (Digital (undefined format))
Language:
English
Keywords:
social representations, national identity, culturally diverse societies, migrants
Abstract:
The concept of identity, although quite recent in the social sciences, is one of the few concepts to have been so widely studied and theorized. Psychologists, sociologists, anthropologists, even political philosophers, have used the term to shed light on a variety of sociopolitical phenomena, ranging from belonging to exclusion and from stability and homogeneity to social change and cultural pluralism. As such, identity has acquired an array of conflicting meanings, from essentialist notions which focus on unity and distinctiveness to conceptions which emphasize the fragmentation of the modern subject. The challenge in defining identity stems from the fact that it refers to both an individual's sense of self as well as to an individual's relations with others. It is, in other words, a concept that resists the individual-social dichotomy which has traditionally dominated the social sciences in general, and social psychology in particular. In this chapter we adopt a social representations perspective to theorize identity at the social-individual interface. We focus on national identities which have been particularly problematized in the context of growing cultural diversity within nation-states and are often seen as declining or changing. The chapter is structured as follows: we start with a brief account of the theory of social representations and then present our main argument of identity as a social representation embedded in strategic projects. Then, in two different sections, we discuss national identity projects in culturally diverse societies with a particular focus on Britain and Greece. We conclude with a brief discussion of the implications of these national identity projects for the integration of migrants. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Social Identity; *Social Sciences; *Sociocultural Factors; Immigration
PsycINFO Classification:
Social Psychology (3000)
Population:
Human
Intended Audience:
Psychology: Professional & Research (PS)
Format Covered:

Book; Edited Book
Document Type:
Chapter
Book Type:

Release Date:
20151019

http://dx.doi.org.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/10.1017/CBO9781107323650.026
Accession Number:
2015-31235-021
UR:
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2015-31235-021&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2015-31235-021&site=ehost-live&scope=site

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 131
Title:
Social work and social development: Perspectives from India and the United States.
Authors:
Singh, Shweta, (Ed), Loyola University Chicago, Chicago, IL, US
Source:
Chicago, IL, US: Lyceum Books; 2013. xv, 448 pp.
Page Count:
448
ISBN:
978-1-933478-66-1 (Paperback)
Language:
English
Keywords:
social work, social development, cultural pluralism, democratic political structures, social welfare policy
Abstract:
The classic paradigm "think globally and act locally" is discovering a new relevance in the context of social development, as it provides a useful perspective on addressing the needs of nations as complex and diverse as India. In order to understand a country's motivation for change and social action, it is first necessary to understand the history of the people and their way of life. Social Work and Social Development: Perspectives from India and the United States compares India and the United States' approaches to social work and social development. The book highlights the similarities between the two countries, especially the cultural pluralism, democratic political structures, and social welfare policy commitments that make possible an inclusionary exchange of knowledge in the fields of social work and social development. The book's unique multicultural, multilevel approach integrates diverse perspectives, and provides a faceted picture of social structures and change in both countries. The goals are to ultimately move beyond the ethnocentric mantra of applying "developed" solutions to "developing" problems and redefine the parameters for understanding people and problems in international social work. The main features of this book include: (1) A unique framework for international comparisons that can be applied beyond the United States and India, (2) Contributions from Indian and US experts in social work, sociology, theology, philosophy, and women's studies, and (3) Concept overview preceding each part and discussion questions following each chapter. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved) (cover)

Source: Journal of Classical Sociology
Record: 132
Title:
Sociocultural guidelines for clinicians in multicultural settings.
Authors:
Moffic, H. Steven, Baylor Coll of Medicine, Houston, TX, US
Source:
Psychiatric Quarterly, Vol 55(1), Spr 1983. pp. 47-54.
Page Count:
8
Publisher:
Germany : Springer
ISSN:
0033-2720 (Print)
1573-6709 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
sociocultural guidelines for patient care, clinicians working in multicultural settings
Abstract:
Presents a set of sociocultural guidelines for clinicians to use in caring for patients from multiple ethnic backgrounds. It is noted that the increasing cultural pluralism of the US means that clinicians are more likely to encounter patients from such backgrounds. Principles of cultural psychiatry include consideration of differences in child rearing, cognitive styles, social networks, sex roles, symptom expression, and concepts of mental health and illness. Cultural differences in verbal and nonverbal communication must be understood to prevent treatment-affecting misunderstandings. It is suggested that cultural self-analysis by the clinician is necessary to alleviate countertransference problems. The difficulties of developing definitive cultural knowledge are noted. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Clinicians; *Cross Cultural Differences; *Transcultural Psychiatry; Psychotherapeutic Processes

Record: 133
Title:
Sociodemographic correlates of the size and composition of informal caregiver networks among frail ethnic elderly.
Authors:
Thornton, Michael C., U Wisconsin, Madison, US
White-Means, Shelley I.
Choi, Hye Kyong
Source:
Journal of Comparative Family Studies, Vol 24(2), Sum 1993. pp. 235-250.
Page Count:
16
Publisher:
Canada : University of Calgary/Dept of Sociology
ISSN:
0047-2328 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
sociodemographics, size & composition of informal caregiver networks, 14 yr old & older German vs Irish vs English vs African American caregivers of frail elderly
Abstract:
Examined ethnic variations in informal caregiver networks (CGNs) by testing the utility of the cultural pluralism and social class models. Data came from 2 surveys that form the 1982 National Long Term Care Survey (B. Phillips et al, 1986). Ss were 737 informal helpers (aged 14+ yrs) who assisted an elderly respondent in 6 activities including eating and dressing. Ss were 11.6% German, 12.6% Irish, 11.3% English, and 13% African-American. As income increased, CGN size decreased. Cultural but not class artifacts affected the structure of CGNs. CGN composition was associated with marital status, sex, and living arrangements among African-Americans and activity level among English-Americans. All White groups were more likely to rely on immediate family for care, while African-Americans turned to others outside the immediate family. (French & Spanish abstracts) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Caregivers; *Demographic Characteristics; *Racial and Ethnic Groups; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; Health Impairments

Record: 134
Title:
Some dominant perspectives in the literature relating to multi-racial social work.
Authors:
Denney, David, Mid-Kent Coll, Chatham, England
Source:
British Journal of Social Work, Vol 13(2), Apr, 1983. pp. 149-174.
Page Count:
26
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Oxford University Press
ISSN:
0045-3102 (Print)
1468-263X (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
approaches to multiracial social work literature
Abstract:
Provides a framework for the understanding of the social work literature relating to racial minorities. Four main themes are identified: the anthropological approach, liberal pluralism, cultural pluralism, and the structuralist position. Race relations goals of the anthropological approach are assimilation and integration; of the pluralist approach, integration and social mobility for minorities; of the structural approach, removal of racism through structural change. Relationships among the literature, social work practice, and ultimate race relations goals are discussed. (27 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

*Minority Groups; *Social Casework

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 135
Title:
Storytelling among the Veekuhane of Chobe (Botswana): Social justice, pedagogy, and vision 2016.
Authors:
Ndana, Ndana, Department of English, University of Botswana, Botswana
Mathangwane, Joyce T., Department of English, University of Botswana, Botswana
Source:
African traditional and oral literature as pedagogical tools in content area classrooms: K-12. Asimeng-Boahene, Lewis (Ed); Baffoe, Michael (Ed); pp. 217-231; Charlotte, NC, US: IAP Information Age Publishing; 2014. xiii, 267 pp.
Page Count:
15
ISBN:
978-1-62396-538-9 (Paperback)
978-1-62396-539-6 (Hardcover)
978-1-62396-540-2 (PDF)
Language:
English
Keywords:
storytelling, narratives, social justice, multicultural reality, pedagogy, educational environment
Abstract:
In this chapter, we explore storytelling among the Veekuhane of Botswana in general, and more specifically, we wish to highlight the pedagogical potential of these narratives/stories in transmitting cultural ideas to children in an obviously multilingual and multicultural educational environment. More important, we also wish to stress the promotion of diversity and social justice in a world that is increasingly conflicted and polarized, due in part to the poor management and opportunistic manipulation of cultural pluralism. The case of Rwanda readily comes to mind. Put differently, in using a sample of Veekuhane narratives, the chapter seeks to show how these stories could be deployed in promoting social justice in line with the country's Vision 2016 Pillars of a moral and tolerant; safe and secure; compassionate, just and caring; and a united and proud nation. Using ideas from social justice, the chapter posits that narratives are one of the many tools schools can use as a starting point for children to begin to appreciate the multicultural reality of their existence and subsequently its complex dynamics. The chapter is organized as follows: we begin by justifying the choice of stories and then sketch out the theoretical background in which we highlight Botswana's language situation and how it departs from the basic tenets of social justice and its Vision 2016. We then analyze two stories to show how their teaching could be explored for the inauguration of a more tolerant and united nation. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Curriculum; *Multicultural Education; *School Environment; *Social Justice; *Storytelling; Narratives
PsycINFO Classification:

Record: 136
Title:
Studying African American Families and Children: Something Old--Race; Something New-Gender.
Authors:
Slaughter-Defoe, Diana T., Center for Urban Affairs and Policy Research, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, US
Conley, Dawn, Center for Urban Affairs and Policy Research, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, US
Source:
PsycCRITIQUES, Vol 39 (10), Oct, 1994. pp. 950-953.
Page Count:
4
Publisher:
US : American Psychological Association
Reviewed Item:
Burlew, A. Kathleen Hoard (Ed); Banks, W. Curtis (Ed); McAdoo, Harriette Pipes (Ed); Azibo, Daudi Ajani ya (Ed). (1992) African American Psychology: Theory, Research, and Practice Newbury Park, CA: Sage, 1992. 424 pp. $45.00 hardcover, $22.95 paperback 0-8039-4765-8 (Hardcover); 0-8039-4766-6 (Paperback).

Staples, Robert; Johnson, Leanor Boulin. (1993) Black Families at the Crossroads: Challenges and Prospects San Francisco: Jossey-Bass, 1993. 293 pp. $37.95 1-55542-486-4.
ISSN:
1554-0138 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
African American families, Blacks, mate selection, parenting, community support
Abstract:
Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1994, Vol 39(10), 950-953. Reviews the books, African American Psychology: Theory, Research, and Practice edited by A. Kathleen Hoard Burlew, W. Curtis Banks, Harriette Pipes McAdoo, and Daudi Ajani ya Azibo (see record 1992-98690-000) and Black Families at the Crossroads: Challenges and Prospects by Robert Staples and Leanor Boulin Johnson (see record 1992-98862-000). The first book probably can be profitably read in isolation without an "interpretator," but for maximum understanding it should be studied by means of lively small group discussion with informed teacher input. Of course, as the society evolves toward cultural pluralism, it is increasingly important that others besides African American psychologists access and use the provided concepts and methods, and we would encourage these efforts through cooperative team-teaching strategies. In contrast, the second book is highly readable, though it emphasizes the use of statistical and survey data to substantiate ideas more than the reporting of discrete, focused empirical studies. This book, because it is a useful overview of theories about Black families--including mate selection, parenting, and community support--could be an excellent background to the more specific studies and ideas presented in first book. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Title:
Styles of grandparenting among White ethnics.

Abstract:
uses national survey data on six ethnic groups (Irish, English, Poles, Scandinavians, Italians, and Germans) to discuss three issues relevant to grandparent socialization and transmission / stresses that cultural diversity in grandparental functions is a socialization force in American society / suggests that the influence of grandparents as perpetrators of the cultural legacy of the family should be emphasized / indicates that White ethnics of the grandparental cohort reflect somewhat different values of what is desirable in the socialization of children than other ethnics (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved) (book)

PsycINFO
Record: 138
Title:
Sweden: The immigration and integration experience: The case of Sweden.
Authors:
Bevelander, Pieter, Malmo Institute of Migration, Diversity and Welfare, Malmo University, Sweden
Source:
Immigration worldwide: Policies, practices, and trends. Segal, Uma A. (Ed); Elliott, Doreen (Ed); Mayadas, Nazneen (Ed); pp. 286-302; New York, NY, US: Oxford University Press; 2010. xvii, 473 pp.
Page Count:
17
ISBN:
978-0-19-538813-8 (Hardcover)
Language:
English
Keywords:
immigration, integration, labor market, political participation, policy, assimilation, marginalization, Sweden
Abstract:
Studying the immigration experience to Sweden diachronically shows that migration, as well as integration into the labor market, and participation in the political arena by newly arrived immigrants, have changed character over time. A majority of the immigrants arriving to Sweden in the first decades after World War II were labor migrants from mainly Nordic and other European countries. For the most part, they were driven by economic factors. On recommendation from the Labor Organization of Sweden (LO), a change in the admission legislation took place at the end of the 1960s, where a relatively liberal policy was replaced by a more restrictive one mainly toward non-Nordic labor migrants. Assimilation policy toward immigrants also changed, and since the middle of the 1970s the integration policy of Sweden is based on cultural pluralism and the slogans of equality, freedom of choice, and partnership. Integration into the labor market and political participation have been important goals of the policy. The settlement policy implemented since the middle of the 1980s, spreading refugees who gained a residence permit to a number of municipalities, and especially those with a favorable local labor market, can be seen as a way to attain these goals. Integration policies in Sweden have not been effective during the last decades. The "multicultural" society does exist in Sweden only if we look at the number of foreign born relative to native born. However, when it comes to the two prominent measures of integration, employment integration and voting participation, it becomes clear that large groups of immigrants are marginalized by the Swedish society. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (create)
Subjects:
*Immigration; *Social Change; Acculturation; Government Policy Making; Labor Market; Political Participation; Social Equality
PsycINFO Classification:
Social Processes & Social Issues (2900)

Record: 139
Title:
Syncretism in rituals and performance in a culturally pluralistic society in the Philippines.
Authors:
Anacin, Carljohnson G., University of the Cordilleras, Baguio City, Philippines, carljanacin@yahoo.com
Address:
Anacin, Carljohnson G., University of the Cordilleras, Governor Pack Road, Baguio City, Philippines, carljanacin@yahoo.com
Source:
The Social Science Journal, Vol 52(1), Mar, 2015. pp. 40-45.
Page Count:
6
Publisher:
Netherlands : Elsevier Science
ISSN:
0362-3319 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Cordillera, Cordillera rituals, Cultural pluralism, Ibaloi, Indigenous ritual, Performance, Philippines
Abstract:
Preserving indigenous culture and practices remains a great challenge for indigenous groups living in a pluralistic, westernized, modernized/post-modernized, and globalized society. With the different elements of social change interacting with the traditional knowledge, systems and practices, it is imperative to look at the risks and changes experienced by indigenous groups in relation to its culture. This paper narrates the presence of syncretism of traditional and contemporary practices in the rituals and music of the Ibaloi community and tries to present the possibility of harmonious interface between the modern quotidian and indigenous life in an attempt to pose minimal risks in the relationship. Rituals in the culturally pluralistic society in the Philippines—Loakan, Baguio City—are still executed and observed at present but the elements of which and other preparations are being lessened because of practicality and shift in beliefs. Nonetheless, these systems and practices still exist because of the meanings attached by the people and their socio-cultural function – as social structures and institutions of social coherence and solidarity—and their outlook about the changes and preservation of performances and rituals in the Ibaloi society. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

*Culture (Anthropological); *Indigenous Populations; *Rites (Nonreligious); *Sociocultural Factors

Title:
Teaching social issues from a global perspective.
Authors:
Merryfield, Merry M., Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, US
Source:
Teaching and studying social issues: Major programs and approaches. Totten, Samuel (Ed); Pedersen, Jon E. (Ed); pp. 195-216; Charlotte, NC, US: IAP Information Age Publishing; 2011. ix, 384 pp.
Page Count:
22
ISBN:
978-1-61735-044-3 (Paperback)
978-1-61735-045-0 (Hardcover)
978-1-61735-046-7 (PDF)
Language:
English
Keywords:
cultural pluralism, ethnic diversity, global education, social studies education, curriculum development
Abstract:
This chapter is concerns global education, a field of study developed to increase student knowledge about their connections to people, events, and issues across the world and to prepare students to participate locally and globally as members of the world community. Global educators aim to "develop in youth the knowledge, skills, and attitudes needed to live effectively in a world possessing limited natural resources and characterized by ethnic diversity, cultural pluralism, and increasing interdependence". This chapter focuses on the historical development of global education and examines relevant research, implementation and resources for infusing global perspectives into programs and classrooms today. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)

Record: 141
Title:
Techniques in Transition and Open Dialogue.
Authors:
Rosenbaum, Max
Address:
Rosenbaum, Max, 150 East 56th Street, New York, NY, US, 10022
Source:
Group Analysis, Vol 20(2), Jun, 1987. pp. 157-166.
Page Count:
10
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0533-3164 (Print)
1461-717X (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
clinical intervention techniques, philosophy of life, group therapist, group psychotherapy
Abstract:
There is often an unwillingness to correlate the technique and the philosophy of the group therapist. Those nations which have a generally homogeneous population are able to use techniques which may be considered non-invasive and appear to be able to accomplish a good deal of clinical progress. The USA, my native land, a collection of fifty states and territories, with a population that migrated from many shores, is the site of many competing techniques of clinical intervention. These clinical interventions mesh with the heterogeneity of the country. Indeed, the cultural pluralism that is so much a part of the fabric of the USA is wedded to many of the group psychotherapy techniques that are at work in the USA. Let us contrast the USA with those Latin American or European nations where the majority of the people profess the same religious beliefs or where the overwhelming majority believe in the same political process. In that situation, clinical technique is closely tied to a particular philosophy of life. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Cross Cultural Differences; *Cross Cultural Psychology; *Group Psychotherapy; *Psychotherapist Attitudes; *World View

Title:
The accomodation of cultural diversity in Tanzania.

Young, Crawford
Source:

Keywords:
politics of cultural pluralism in Tanzania
Abstract:
Explores the politics of cultural pluralism in Tanzania and possible reasons why a degree of communal comity is evident, in contrast to nearby countries whose sociological parameters might appear similar. Main topics discussed in this chapter are: (1) precolonial Tanzania; (2) German colonialism; (3) British colonization: (4) decolonization; (5) the Zanzibar revolution; and (6) liberalization. The author discusses the difficulty of independence with respect to Tanzania. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 143
Title:
The concept of cultural pluralism: Issues in special education.
Authors:
Poplin, Mary S., Claremont Graduate School
Wright, Pamela
Source:
Learning Disability Quarterly, Vol 6(4), Fal 1983. pp. 367-371.
Page Count:
5
Publisher:
US : Council for Learning Disabilities
Other Publishers:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0731-9487 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
cultural pluralism, labeling & special education
Abstract:
Proposes that, within the field of education, cultural pluralism (CP) offers the right of every American child to maintain his/her identity with home and community socialization experiences. CP rejects the deficit model, which holds that children from minority culture (MC) backgrounds often come to school with cultural and linguistic defects that must be remedied. It is not suggested that English is not to be a part of the curriculum, but it is suggested that English acquisition should be an additive process, not a replacement. In terms of special education, CP is a factor because many MC children are placed in special education due to cultural, linguistic, and/or racial differences. In many public schools, cultural differences are still translated as deviant, deficient, disabled, and/or disadvantaged. For lack of a better label, many are identified as learning disabled. For those MC students who do have handicaps, the issue of cultural differences is as pertinent to their education as the issue of their learning disabilities. The problems associated with identifying disabilities in MC youngsters are complicated by a lack of understanding of the various cultures; discrimination associated with referral, assessment instruments, and placement; and the virtual nonexistence of teacher training and certification programs that combine special and bilingual/multicultural education methods. (15 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Cross Cultural Differences; *Learning Disabilities; *Minority Groups; *Special Education; Acculturation
PsycINFO Classification:
Special & Remedial Education (3570)

Title:
The context of the issue.

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 145
Title:
The Cultural Formulation: A method for assessing cultural factors affecting the clinical encounter.
Authors:
Lewis-Fernández, Roberto, Columbia U, New York, NY, US, rlewis@nyspi.cpmc.columbia.edu
Díaz, Naelys, Fordham U, Bronx, NY, US
Address:
Lewis-Fernández, Roberto, New York State Psychiatric Inst, Unit 69, 1051 Riverside Drive, New York, NY, US, 10032, rlewis@nyspi.cpmc.columbia.edu
Source:
Psychiatric Quarterly, Vol 73(4), Win 2002. Special Issue: The Fourteenth Annual New York State Office of Mental Health Research Conference. pp. 271-295.
Page Count:
25
Publisher:
Germany : Springer
ISSN:
0033-2720 (Print)
1573-6709 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
cultural factors, psychiatric illness, symptom presentations, help-seeking behavior, diagnosis, treatment, Cultural Formulation model
Abstract:
The growing cultural pluralism of US society requires clinicians to examine the impact of cultural factors on psychiatric illness, including on symptom presentation and help-seeking behavior. In order to render an accurate diagnosis across cultural boundaries and formulate treatment plans acceptable to the patient, clinicians need a systematic method for eliciting and evaluating cultural information in the clinical encounter. This article describes one such method, the Cultural Formulation model, expanding on the guidelines published in DSM-IV. It consists of five components, assessing cultural identity, cultural explanations of the illness, cultural factors related to the psychosocial environment and levels of functioning, cultural elements of the clinician-patient relationship, and the overall impact of culture on diagnosis and care. The authors present a brief historical overview of the model and use a case scenario to illustrate each of its components and the substantial effect on illness course and treatment outcome of implementing the model in clinical practice. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Cultural Sensitivity; *Help Seeking Behavior; *Mental Disorders; *Sociocultural Factors; *Symptoms; Psychodiagnosis; Treatment
PsycINFO Classification:
Culture & Ethnology (2930)
Psychological Disorders (3210)
Population:
Human
Conference:
Annual New York State Office of Mental Health Research Conference, 14th, Dec, 2001, Albany, NY, US
Format Covered:
Print
Publication Type:
Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal
Document Type:
Journal Article
Release Date:

PsycINFO
Record: 146
Title:
The development and validation of an instrument to assess attitudes toward cultural diversity and pluralism among preservice physical educators.
Authors:
Stanley, Linda S., U Wisconsin, Madison, WI, US
Source:
Educational and Psychological Measurement, Vol 56(5), Oct, 1996. pp. 891-897.
Page Count:
7
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0013-1644 (Print)
1552-3888 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
development & validity of Pluralism & Diversity Attitude Assessment, preservice physical education teachers
Abstract:
Describes the development and validation of an instrument to assess attitudes toward cultural diversity and cultural pluralism. The initial instrument consisted of 60 questions and was completed by 215 preservice teachers in physical education who were enrolled in the final 2 years of their program at 11 selected universities. Factor-analytic procedures produced a conceptually meaningful four-factor solution with internal consistency reliabilities in the range of .72 to .85 for the four factors. The final instrument, the Pluralism and Diversity Attitude Assessment (PADAA), consists of 19 statements. The PADAA measures the degree to which a respondent possesses positive attitudes toward cultural pluralism and whether an individual is comfortable or uncomfortable with diversity. The 4 scales are Appreciate Cultural Pluralism, Value Cultural Pluralism, Implement Cultural Pluralism, and Uncomfortable with Cultural Diversity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Measurement; *Teacher Attitudes; *Test Construction; *Test Validity; *Multiculturalism; College Teachers; Diversity; Physical Education; Preservice Teachers
PsycINFO Classification:
Educational Measurement (2227)
Educational Administration & Personnel (3510)

Record: 147
Title:
The double bind of personal striving: Ethnic working class women in psychotherapy.
Authors:
Kuppersmith, Judith, City U New York, Coll of Staten Island, US
Source:
Journal of Contemporary Psychotherapy, Vol 17(3), Fal 1987. pp. 203-216.
Page Count:
14
Publisher:
Germany : Springer
ISSN:
0022-0116 (Print)
1573-3564 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
psychological issues resulting from personal striving in psychotherapy, ethnic working class female clients
Abstract:
When ethnic working-class women seek psychotherapy, the process can place them in a double bind in that their personal striving threatens their ethnic and class ties. Clinical material illustrates sociological myths related to the ethnic "melting pot," cultural pluralism, and female liberation as well as common symptoms such as achievement anxiety, veneration of authority, religious conflict, experiential limitations, and a feeling of being the "black sheep" of the family. By challenging their own ethnic, racial, and class identities, clinicians can open up new treatment possibilities to help strengthen positive group identity, enhance self-esteem, and support personal striving in their patients and in themselves. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Human Females; *Lower Class; *Psychotherapy; *Racial and Ethnic Groups; Psychodynamics
PsycINFO Classification:
Psychotherapy & Psychotherapeutic Counseling (3310)
Population:

Female

Title:

Authors:

Page Count:

Keywords:

Abstract:
Reviews the educational experiences (control of the schools, language, culture, and achievement) of Mexican Americans in the US, with special reference to their efforts to preserve their heritage. It is concluded that the Anglo-dominated schools have seriously impeded these efforts. (22 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Record: 149
Title:
The Elusive Ideal of Equal Citizenship: Political Theory and Political Psychology in the United States and Great Britain.
Authors:
Conover, Pamela Johnston, University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, NC, US, conover@email.unc.edu
Searing, Donald D., University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, NC, US, searing@unc.edu
Crewe, Ivor, University of Essex, Colchester, United Kingdom, vc@essex.ac.uk
Address:
Conover, Pamela Johnston, University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, NC, US, 27599-3265, conover@email.unc.edu
Source:
The Journal of Politics, Vol 66(4), Nov, 2004. pp. 1036-1068.
Page Count:
33
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Blackwell Publishing
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Cambridge University Press
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
ISSN:
0022-3816 (Print)
1468-2508 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
equal citizenship, political theory, political psychology, liberal democracy
Abstract:
It is a fundamental ideal of liberal democracy that all citizens should enjoy fully equal citizenship. Yet many minorities are still routinely ignored, excluded, patronized, and not regarded as full members of the political community. This denial of equal standing undermines their equal citizenship. Liberalism and Cultural Pluralism each advocate strategies to improve this situation. Their arguments build upon expectations about how citizens should, can, and do understand membership in the political community. Our survey and focus group data from six matched communities in the United States and Great Britain show how citizens' understandings of membership in the political community incorporate communitarian attitudes that impede the liberal and cultural pluralist projects. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Citizenship; *Democracy; *Political Liberalism; *Political Psychology; *Social Equality
PsycINFO Classification:
Political Processes & Political Issues (2960)
Population:
Human
Location:
Great Britain; US
Age Group:

Adulthood (18 yrs & older)
Conference:
Annual Meetings of the American Political Science Association, 2002
Conference Notes:
This paper was presented at the aforementioned conference.

Record: 150
Title:
The First--Thoughtful and Exciting.
Authors:
Sarason, Seymour B., Yale University, Psycho-Educational Clinic, New Haven, CT, US
Source:
PsycCRITIQUES, Vol 18 (7), Jul, 1973. pp. 340-341.
Page Count:
2
Publisher:
US : American Psychological Association
Reviewed Item:
Adelson, Daniel (Ed). (1972) Man as the Measure: The Crossroads New York: Behavioral, 1972. Pp. 146. $7.95 cloth; $3.95 paper
ISSN:
1554-0138 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
community psychology, clinical psychology, community processes, social forces, social systems, religious factors, cultural pluralism
Abstract:
Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1973, Vol 18(7), 340-341. Reviews the book, Man as the Measure: The Crossroads edited by Daniel Adelson (1972). In this book, the editor describes the ideas and social forces that have given rise to the shift from clinical psychology's and psychiatry's traditional treatment model to a community psychology concerned with social systems, community processes, and prevention. Man, he points out, has a need to experience the sense of community, but there is much in the history and traditions of our society that prevents this, not the least of which are the facts of cultural pluralism. At the same time that ethnic, racial, and religious factors provide some basis for experiencing "community," they are also sources of group conflict. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Clinical Psychology; *Community Psychology; *Society; *Multiculturalism; Religion

Record: 151
Title:
The Future of the Death Penalty in America.
Authors:
Bedau, Hugo Adam, Center for the Study of Decision Making, Tufts University, Medford, MA, US
Source:
PsycCRITIQUES, Vol 33 (7), Jul, 1988. pp. 573-575.
Page Count:
3
Publisher:
US : American Psychological Association
Reviewed Item:
Otterbein, Keith F. (1986) The Ultimate Coercive Sanction: A Cross-Cultural Study of Capital Punishment New Haven, CT: HRAF Press, 1986. 164 pp. $14.00 0-87536-346-6 (Paperback).

Zimring, Franklin E.; Hawkins, Gordon. (1986) Capital Punishment and the American Agenda New York: Cambridge University Press, 1986. 192 pp. $22.95 0-521-33033-5.
ISSN:
1554-0138 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
death penalty, cross cultural study, capital punishment, imprisonment, society, racial minorities, America
Abstract:
Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1988, Vol 33(7), 573-575. Reviews the books, The Ultimate Coercive Sanction: A Cross-Cultural Study of Capital Punishment by Keith F. Otterbein (see record 1987-97481-000) and Capital Punishment and the American Agenda by Franklin E. Zimring and Gordon Hawkins (see record 1987-97425-000). Contributions by social scientists to the debate over the death penalty in this country have been confined largely to close scrutiny of two major issues: whether the death penalty as actually employed is a deterrent (and, especially, whether it is a better deterrent than imprisonment) and whether its use is arbitrary and discriminatory (especially against racial minorities). These two books break new ground and complement each other in their orientation. Zimring and Hawkins propose a version of cultural pluralism to characterize the death penalty in the United States. Otterbein begins his volume with a complaint against his fellow social scientists to the effect that they "have avoided conducting any studies that might show the social functions of capital punishment". He proposes to remedy this lack by examining data in the Human Relations Area Files on nearly three dozen (mostly primitive) cultures. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Capital Punishment; *Cross Cultural Differences; Countries; Minority Groups; Prisons; Society

Title:
The integration of spirituality and religion content in social work education: Where we've been, where we're going.
Authors:
Barker, Stacey L., Department of Social Work, Eastern Nazarene College, Quincy, MA, US, stacey.l.barker@enc.edu
Address:
Barker, Stacey L., Department of Social Work, Eastern Nazarene College, 23 East Elm Avenue, Quincy, MA, US, 02170, stacey.l.barker@enc.edu
Source:
Social Work & Christianity, Vol 34(2), Sum 2007. pp. 146-166.
Page Count:
21
Publisher:
US : North American Association of Christians in Social Work NACSW
ISSN:
0737-5778 (Print)
1944-7779 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
spirituality, religion content, social work education
Abstract:
In response to the growing concern among social work students, practitioners, and educators about the lack of content related to spirituality and religion in social work education, the profession of social work has seen more than a decade of scholarly activity and curriculum content changes designed to address this very important issue. This paper examines the current place of spirituality and religion content in social work education through the backdrop of the profession's history; through diversity theories, including cultural pluralism, people-of-color, populations-at-risk, and transculturality; through a human development lens, including the theories of Fowler, Gilligan, and Borysenko; and through transpersonal theory as an alternative for understanding spirituality and religion. An overview of the empirical literature related to spirituality and religion and social work education is provided. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

*Religion; *Social Casework; *Social Work Education; *Spirituality

Record: 153
Title:
The interaction of ethnic groups: a case study of Indians and whites.
Authors:
Aginsky, Burt W., CC N Y, New York.
Source:
American Sociological Review, 14, 1949. pp. 288-293.
Page Count:
6
Publisher:
US : American Sociological Assn
Other Publishers:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0003-1224 (Print)
1939-8271 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
RACE, RELATIONS, INDIAN VS. WHITE, INDIAN (AMERICAN), VS. WHITE, ETHNIC INTERACTION, CULTURES & CULTURAL RELATIONS
Abstract:
Using results of a field study of the Pomo (Calif.) Indians as an example, 3 types of interpopulational participation are considered: (1) amalgamation (total participation), which was opposed by both whites and Indians, (2) cultural pluralism (negative participation), which was accepted verbally by both, and (3) dominance-submission (restrictive participation), accepted verbally by a majority of older white residents. "In cases where both groups are opposed to the three types of solutions, there remains but one realistic program, namely a conscious program of ever-increasing functionally integrated participation." (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
No terms assigned

Social Processes & Social Issues (2900)

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 154
Title:
The Mutual Relevance of Indigenous Psychology and Morality.
Authors:
Eckensberger, Lutz H., University of the Saarland, Germany, Eckensberger@dipf.de
Source:
Indigenous and cultural psychology: Understanding people in context. Kim, Uichol (Ed); Yang, Kuo-Shu (Ed); Hwang, Kwang-Kuo (Ed); pp. 225-245; New York, NY, US: Springer Science + Business Media; 2006. xxi, 518 pp.
Page Count:
21
ISBN:
0-387-28661-6 (Hardcover)
978-0-387-28661-7 (Hardcover)
0-387-28662-4 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
indigenous psychology, morality, culture
Abstract:
The relation of morality to indigenous psychology (IP) is examined from four different yet complementary viewpoints. Basically, a western metaperspective is taken. First, the topic of morality is dealt with on a content level: If social scientists (as a first approximation) conceive of IP as a psychology that aims at understanding, explaining, and predicting people's behavior within specific cultures, then cultural rule systems, which are normative frameworks for individual behavior, can be understood as the core and the main differentia specified of such a psychology. Morality is one of these rule systems, both in the tradition of cultural relativism and cultural pluralism. The crucial question of whether or not morality is culture specific (indigenous) or universal is discussed. Second, the role of morality in the emergence of IPs is treated at the science of science level. Third, a slightly strange argument is developed based on the fact that particularly from an IP perspective, research on culture does not just serve an analytical function (answering the question "What is culture?"), but treats culture as a characteristic of a group. It is postulated that this conceptualization of cultures as more or less homogeneous entities has moral implications. Finally, basic methodical implications are discussed, though they are also addressed in the previous sections. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Cross Cultural Differences; *Cross Cultural Psychology; *Morality; Culture (Anthropological); Sociocultural Factors
PsycINFO Classification:
Culture & Ethnology (2930)
Population:
Human
Intended Audience:
Psychology: Professional & Research (PS)
Format Covered:
Print
Publication Type:
Book; Edited Book
Document Type:
Chapter
Release Date:
20060522
Correction Date:
20150126
Digital Object Identifier:
http://dx.doi.org.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/10.1007/0-387-28662-4_10
Accession Number:
2006-05375-010
Number of Citations in Source:
83
UR:
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2006-05375-010&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2006-05375-010&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2006-05375-010&site=ehost-live&scope=site">The Mutual Relevance of Indigenous Psychology and Morality.</A>
Database:

Record: 155
Title:
The personal and contextual contributors to school belongingness among primary school students.
Authors:
Vaz, Sharmila, School of Occupational Therapy & Social Work, Curtin University, Perth, WAU, Australia, s.vaz@curtin.edu.au
Falkmer, Marita, School of Occupational Therapy & Social Work, Curtin University, Perth, WAU, Australia

English
Keywords:
contextual contributors, school belongingness primary school students, adolescent health, secondary school
Abstract:
School belongingness has gained currency among educators and school health professionals as an important determinant of adolescent health. The current cross-sectional study presents the 15 most significant personal and contextual factors that collectively explain 66.4% (two-thirds) of the variability in 12-year old students’ perceptions of belongingness in primary school. The study is part of a larger longitudinal study investigating the factors associated with student adjustment in the transition from primary to secondary school. The study found that girls and students with disabilities had higher school belongingness scores than boys, and their typically developing counterparts respectively; and explained 2.5% of the variability in school belongingness. The majority (47.1% out of 66.4%) of the variability in school belongingness was explained by student personal factors, such as social acceptance, physical appearance competence, coping skills, and social affiliation motivation; followed by parental expectations (3% out of 66.4%), and school-based factors (13.9% out of 66.4%) such as, classroom involvement, task-goal structure, autonomy provision, cultural pluralism, and absence of bullying. Each of the identified contributors of primary school belongingness can be shaped through interventions, system changes, or policy reforms. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Adolescent Development; *Elementary Schools; *Primary School Students; *School Based Intervention; Contextual Associations; Bullying
PsycINFO Classification:
Curriculum & Programs & Teaching Methods (3530)
Population:

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 156
Title:
The rhetoric of experience and the study of religion.
Authors:
Sharf, Robert H., U Michigan, Dept of Asian Languages & Cultures, Ann Arbor, MI, US
Source:
Journal of Consciousness Studies, Vol 7(11-12), 2000. pp. 267-287.
Page Count:
21
Publisher:
US : Imprint Academic
ISSN:
1355-8250 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
objective & empirical vs subjective & cultural definitions of religious experience in academic literature
Abstract:
Discusses the role of and definitions of religious experience within the study of religion. It is argued that scholarship that does not attend to the experiential dimension of religious practice is dismissed by many as reductionistic, and further, that the academic literature also does not clearly delineate between religious experience and mystical experience. The reluctance and inability of scholars to clearly stipulate the meaning of these terms is discussed in light of challenges of empiricism and cultural pluralism. Also, the ideological aspect of the appeal to experience is highlighted especially in regard to mystical experience. The role of mystical experience in Western vs Asian religious streams is explored, and evidence is examined regarding the supposition that Asian religions are more experientially rooted than their Western counterparts. It is concluded that it may be ill conceived to construe the object of religious study to be the inner experience of religious practitioners. Implications of the "humanistic" drive to empower experience are addressed in light of the need for objective reality and for critical scholarship. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Religious Experiences; *Scientific Communication

Religion (2920)
Population:
Human

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 157
Title:
The role of cultural dynamics in the digital age.
Parent Book Series:
Advances in religious and cultural studies (ARCS) book series
Authors:
Kasemsap, Kijpokin, Faculty of Management Sciences, Suan Sunandha Rajabhat University, Bangkok, Thailand
Source:
Nationalism, cultural indoctrination, and economic prosperity in the digital age. Christiansen, Bryan (Ed); Koeman, Joyce (Ed); pp. 295-312; Hershey, PA, US: Information Science Reference/IGI Global; 2015. xviii, 364 pp.
Page Count:
18
ISBN:
978-1-4666-7492-9 (Hardcover)
978-1-4666-7493-6 (Digital (undefined format))
Language:
English
Keywords:
cultural dynamics, digital age, modern communication media, communication systems
Abstract:
This chapter introduces the role of cultural dynamics in the digital age, thus explaining the theoretical and practical concepts of organizational culture, cultural values and belief systems, material culture and artifacts, language and communication systems, cultural interpenetration, deterritorialization, cultural pluralism, and hybridization; the categorization of cultural dimensions; and the application of cultural dynamics in the modern business world. Cultural influences are changing dramatically as cultures are no longer dependent on local resources to formulate their characteristic tastes, preferences, and behavior and are increasingly linked across vast geographic distances by modern communication media. Membership in a culture adapts to new cultural contexts while transporting elements of one culture to another. As membership in a culture becomes increasingly transitional, unique elements are less clearly demarcated or distinctive. Understanding the role of cultural dynamics in the digital age will significantly enhance organizational performance and achieve business goals in global business environments. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Age Differences; *Business; *Cross Cultural Differences; *Multiculturalism; Communication Systems; Membership

Record: 158
Title:
The self-transformations of African American achievers.
Authors:
Hemmings, Annette, U Cincinnati, Educational Foundations Program, Cincinnati, OH, US
Source:
Youth & Society, Vol 29(3), Mar, 1998. pp. 330-368.
Page Count:
39
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0044-118X (Print)
1552-8499 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
social & personal identity, high achieving Black high school students
Abstract:
Ethnographic case studies of 3 African American student achievers attending desegregated urban high schools are analyzed in terms of theories in the new cultural pluralism in educational anthropology. The achievers are described as they sought to transform their "multiple selves" as Black persons, as women and men, and as members of social classes in transition between the "multiple worlds" of their families, schooling, and peers. They accomplished their self-transformations through the use of contrasting strategies of self-negation, self-fragmentation, and self-synthesis that were adapted in response to conflicting cultural expectations. This investigation offers crucial insights into the nature and consequences of the identity work of African American youths in urban educational contexts. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Title:
The Sunni-Shi'a conflict as reflected in the Romanian Muslim community.
Authors:
Alak, Alina Isac, Department of Philosophy, University of Bucharest, Bucharest, Romania, alina_alak@yahoo.com
Address:
Alak, Alina Isac, Matei Basarab Street, No. 72, Bl. L112, Sc. 2, Apt. 21, Sector 3, Bucharest, Romania, 030672, alina_alak@yahoo.com
Source:

Language:
English
Keywords:
Sunni, Shi'a, conflict, Salafi, converts
Abstract:
This article presents a small-scale survey of mainly Romanian Muslim converts regarding the conflict between Sunni and Shi'a Muslims throughout the world. The roots of the sectarian conflict are complex, inextricably linked with theological, political, and historical issues. The solutions proposed involve a multiple and simultaneous approach to these determinants, with a special focus on the necessity of cultivating social and cultural pluralism. Record: 161
Title:
The wandering IQ: American culture and mental testing.
Authors:
Cravens, Hamilton, Iowa State U, Program in History of Technology & Science, Ames
Source:
Human Development, Vol 28(3), May-Jun, 1985. pp. 113-130.
Page Count:
18
Publisher:
Switzerland : Karger
Other Journal Titles:
Vita Humana, Basel
ISSN:
0018-716X (Print)
1423-0054 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
cultural influences on early 20th century research conducted at Iowa Child Welfare Research Station, cultural & environmental influences & intellectual development, children
Abstract:
Reviews the history of the studies of IQ that took place at the Iowa Child Welfare Research Station in the 1930's and 1940's, which suggested that the IQs of young children could be dramatically boosted or depressed under specified environmental conditions. It is argued that the Station's scientists arrived at their conclusions primarily because they responded to larger, if often tacit, ways of perceiving reality programmed into American culture itself. It was in the mid-1920's that cultural pluralism and cultural relativism came into their own as important cultural and intellectual movements. It was in those years that the final phases of the heredity–environment controversy were taking place, and the Station scientists argued for the importance of the social environment in the development of IQ, and they were critical of the excesses of the mental testing movement. The scientists later became involved in campaigning for a national system of preschool education and in conducting research with children in state institutions. These projects led the researchers to consider themselves as part of the child welfare profession, rather than part of academic psychology. (42 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Childhood Development; *Cognitive Development; *Culture (Anthropological); *History of Psychology; *Intelligence Quotient

Record: 162
Title:
Therapist, Patient, and Cultural Milieu.
Authors:
Dudek, Stephanie Z., Université de Montréal, Montréal, PQ, Canada
Source:
PsycCRITIQUES, Vol 18 (6), Jun, 1973. pp. 275-277.
Page Count:
3
Publisher:
US : American Psychological Association
Reviewed Item:
Seward, Georgene H. (1972) Psychotherapy and Culture Conflict in Community Mental Health. 2nd ed New York: Ronald Press, 1972. Pp. x + 226. $9.00
ISSN:
1554-0138 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
cultural milieu, therapeutic methods, community mental health, psychotherapy
Abstract:
Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1973, Vol 18(6), 275-277. Reviews the book, Psychotherapy and Culture Conflict in Community Mental Health. 2nd ed by Georgene H. Seward (1972). The overall perspective of this book is that of the majority middle-class therapist who must face the complexity of minority group mental health and must come to recognize cultural pluralism as a necessary good. The dangers and pitfalls of therapy without understanding the patient in his cultural milieu are emphatically outlined. The need to distinguish pathological conflict is stressed. Seward presents many suggestions about the suitability of types of therapy for different cultural groups, such as the questionable use of long-term insight therapies with lower-class patients who present attitudes toward time that stress immediacy. She indicates the usefulness of folk medicine, suggestion, and ritual in crisis intervention and in cases where more formal therapeutic methods could not possibly bridge the communication barriers. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Community Mental Health; *Cross Cultural Differences; *Psychotherapy; *Therapeutic Processes

PsycINFO
Record: 165
Title:
Value of cultural pluralism to the generalizability of psychological theories: A reexamination.
Authors:
Kagehiro, Dorothy K., U Wisconsin-Parkside, Behavioral Science Div, Kenosha
Mejia, Juan A.
Garcia, Joseph E.
Source:
Professional Psychology: Research and Practice, Vol 16(4), Aug, 1985. pp. 481-494.
Page Count:
14
Publisher:
US : American Psychological Association
Other Journal Titles:
Professional Psychology
ISSN:
0735-7028 (Print)
1939-1323 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
cultural pluralism approach to recruitment of culturally diverse graduate psychology students as means of increasing generalizability of psychological theories & hypotheses
Abstract:
Argues that the limited generalizability of psychological theories and hypotheses may stem, in part, from a restricted sampling of psychological theorists and investigators and hence from the homogeneity of their background assumptions, biases, and values. Threats to generalizability at the hypothesis-testing, theory-development, and hypothesis-formation stages of research are discussed using examples from the literature. A cultural pluralism approach is recommended for the recruitment and training of socioculturally diverse psychologists, capable of conducting research in a wider variety of settings with a wider range of Ss. Types of short- and long-term location and recruitment techniques are discussed, and the promotion of the cultural pluralism perspective within the graduate curriculum is addressed. (3 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Graduate Psychology Education; *Psychology; *Sociocultural Factors; *Theories; Experimentation
PsycINFO Classification:
Professional Education & Training (3410)
Population:
Human

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 166
Title:
What are we seeking to sustain through culturally sustaining pedagogy? A loving critique forward.
Authors:
Paris, Django, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI, US
Alim, H. Samy, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, US
Source:
Harvard Educational Review, Vol 84(1), Spr 2014. pp. 85-100.
Page Count:
16
Publisher:
US : Harvard Education Publishing Group
Other Journal Titles:
Harvard Teachers Record
ISSN:
0017-8055 (Print)
1943-5045 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
culturally sustaining pedagogy, linguistic & literate & cultural practices, youth of color
Abstract:
In this article, Django Paris and H. Samy Alim use the emergence of Paris's concept of culturally sustaining pedagogy (CSP) as the foundation for a respectful and productive critique of previous formulations of asset pedagogies. Paying particular attention to asset pedagogy's failures to remain dynamic and critical in a constantly evolving global world, they offer a vision that builds on the crucial work of the past toward a CSP that keeps pace with the changing lives and practices of youth of color. The authors argue that CSP seeks to perpetuate and foster linguistic, literate, and cultural pluralism as part of the democratic project of schooling and as a needed response to demographic and social change. Building from their critique, Paris and Alim suggest that CSP's two most important tenets are a focus on the plural and evolving nature of youth identity and cultural practices and a commitment to embracing youth culture's counterhegemonic potential while maintaining a clear-eyed critique of the ways in which youth culture can also reproduce systemic inequalities. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Sociocultural Factors; *Teaching; Ethnic Identity; Linguistics; Literacy
PsycINFO Classification:
Curriculum & Programs & Teaching Methods (3530)

Record: 167
Title:
White suburban schools' responses to low-income Black children: Sources of successes and problems.
Authors:
Rosenbaum, James E., Northwestern U, Evanston, IL, US
Kulieke, Marilynn J.
Rubinowitz, Leonard S.
Source:
The Urban Review, Vol 20(1), Spr 1988. Special Issue: Toward cultural pluralism: Redefining integration in American society. pp. 28-41.
Page Count:
14
Publisher:
Germany : Springer
ISSN:
0042-0972 (Print)
1573-1960 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
differential educational standards & grades & student satisfaction & responses of suburban students & teachers, low income Black 6–18 yr old students moving into White middle income suburbs
Abstract:
Investigated an integration program in which low-income Black children moved with their families into middle-income, White suburbs. Ss included 114 Black mothers with 6–18 yr old children who moved into White suburbs and 48 comparable children whose families moved into Black urban neighborhoods. Three hypotheses are tested: (1) Educational standards will be higher in the suburban schools than in city schools. (2) Suburban schools and teachers will respond to these students with increased educational assistance mixed with some racial discrimination. (3) Students' grades and school satisfaction will not decline with the move to the suburban schools. Interviews with mothers and children were conducted to compare postmove experiences with reports of previous experiences and to compare these reports with those of the control group. Findings support all 3 hypotheses and suggest new perspectives on the kinds of advantages and problems arising from residential integration. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Blacks; *Geographical Mobility; *Racial and Ethnic Relations; *Social Integration; *Suburban Environments; Academic Achievement; Educational Standards; Elementary School Students; High School Students; Income Level; Junior High School Students; Student Attitudes; Whites

Record: 168
Title:
Xenophobic exclusion and the new right in Norway.
Authors:
Eriksen, Thomas Hylland, Department of Social Anthropology, University of Oslo, Oslo, Norway, t.h.eriksen@sai.uio.no
Address:
Eriksen, Thomas Hylland, Department of Social Anthropology, University of Oslo, PO Box 1091 Blindern, N-0317, Oslo, Norway, t.h.eriksen@sai.uio.no
Source:
Journal of Community & Applied Social Psychology, Vol 22(3), May-Jun, 2012. pp. 206-209.
Page Count:
4
Publisher:
US : John Wiley & Sons
Other Journal Titles:
Social Behaviour
ISSN:
1052-9284 (Print)
1099-1298 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Abstract:
Comments on an article by Joshua Marvle Phelps et al. (see record 2012-06930-001). The article, based on data from the newspaper language in Norway since 1984, contains a number of interesting observations and important findings. There can be no disagreement about the main conclusion, which is well documented, namely that the preoccupation with immigration and the fraught relationship of cultural pluralism to classic Norwegian nationhood has grown perceptibly in importance since the mid-1980s. There is one main change in the grammar of othering as it is practised in Norway, which is—somewhat surprisingly—overlooked by the authors, namely the slow but very perceptible shift from race to religion as the main marker of difference. Muslims are increasingly associated with values and practices that are inimical to Norwegian identity. The new right is viciously anti-Muslim. The new anti-Muslim ideology has several interesting features. First, its adherents are otherwise ideologically diverse, ranging from classical Marxists to libertarians and state-centric nationalists. Second, it recruits largely from segments of the middle class where there is a feeling of downward mobility, marginalisation and disenfranchisement. Third, taken to its extremes, this ideology relinquishes democratic procedures and declares war on The Other. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Boundaries (Psychological); *Immigration; *Linguistics; *Multiculturalism; *Ideology; Minority Groups; Newspapers; Society; Symbolism
PsycINFO Classification:
Social Processes & Social Issues (2900)
Population:
Human
Location:
Norway

Electronic

Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal
Document Type:
Comment/Reply

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 169
Title:
'You get to be yourself': Visual arts programs, identity construction and learners of English as an additional language.
Authors:
Wielgosz, Meg, Australian Catholic University, QLD, Australia
Molyneux, Paul, University of Melbourne, Parkville, VIC, Australia, pdmoly@unimelb.edu.au
Address:
Molyneux, Paul, Melbourne Graduate School of Education, University of Melbourne, Parkville, VIC, Australia, 3010, pdmoly@unimelb.edu.au
Source:
Journal of Language, Identity, and Education, Vol 14(4), Aug, 2015. pp. 275-289.
Page Count:
15
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
Other Publishers:
US : Lawrence Erlbaum
ISSN:
1534-8458 (Print)
1532-7701 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
curriculum, English language learners, pedagogy, schools, social identity, visual arts
Abstract:
Students learning English as an additional language (EAL) in Australian schools frequently struggle with the cultural and linguistic demands of the classroom while concurrently grappling with issues of identity and belonging. This article reports on an investigation of the role primary school visual arts programs, distinct programs with a specialist teacher, in a designated art room, can play in supporting EAL students’ identity construction and social transition. At six Melbourne primary schools, classroom observations and teacher and student interviews revealed that the visual art programs offer clear possibilities for enhanced and empowered constructions of identity. This article focuses on four students as case studies, highlighting the powerful role visual arts programs, classrooms and teachers can play in EAL learners’ identity construction. On a personal and societal level, identity construction and a positive sense of self are essential in our current era of increased linguistic and cultural pluralism, and this study offers insights into how these inclusive goals can be achieved. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Art Education; *Curriculum; *Foreign Language Learning; *Self Concept; *Teaching; Primary School Students
